Two militants were killed on Tuesday, in Ain Defla, by a detachment of the People's National Army (ANP). A detachment of the ANP, during a combing operation close to Grabiz in the town of Bathia in the Southwest of Ain Defla, killed two militants and seized "a Kalashnikov-type machine pistol, a Simonov-type semi-automatic rifle, binoculars, a grenade and a quantity of ammunitions".
Dozens of college students of Cheraga, Staoueli and Ain Benian gathered on Wednesday morning outside the directorate of Education in West Algiers (Chéraga) to demand improved education policies.

column22: Tout Sur l’Algerie; Echourouk El Youmi
column23: Unknown militants attacked two civilian trucks that were providing a military barracks with food supplies in Akerrou, 70 km east of Tizi Ouzou. A man died and some other were injured in the attack.

Two militants have been killed on Thursday during an ambush near the commune of El Adjiba (Bouira, 100-km east of Algiers) by a detachment of the People's National Army. The ANP also seized "a Kalashnikov submachine gun, a Simonov semi-automatic rifle, a homemade bomb, a pair of binoculars, ammunition and two mobile phones".

The Tunisian expatriates organised peaceful rallies and marches in a number of cities of the hosting countries to show their solidarity and condemn the attack of the Bardo Museum which killed several civilians. The demonstrations mainly took place in several French cities, as well as in Germany, in Sweden, in Japan, in Morocco, in Algeria and Egypt.
Protests over shale gas exploitation projects have resumed in Southern Algeria. Around 600 people staged a protest march in Ain Salah, demanding the termination of drilling tests in the region.

Protests over shale gas exploitation projects have resumed in Southern Algeria. In Tamanrasset, around people organised a sit-in outside the HQ of the local administration to protests against drilling tests in the region of Ain Salah.
An armed man was killed by the army units in the area of Djabahia, Bouira.

An armed combatant was killed in an ambush on Sunday by a detachment of the People's National Army (ANP) at Oued Larbaâtache in the province of Boumerdes. The operation resulted in the recovery of a Kalashnikov submachine gun, a quantity of ammunition and two cell phones.

Four militants were killed on Thursday morning by the forces of the National Popular Army (ANP) near the town of Oued Ouakser, El Kharrouba, during a sweep operation, which also allowed recovering weapons and equipment of different types, including two Kalashnikov submachine guns, one Simonov semi-automatic rifle, one Beretta automatic pistol, two wireless radio devices, one pair of binoculars, a large quantity of ammunition, means of detonation, three mobile phones and twenty-one phone chips.
Residents of In Salah opposing shale gas exploitation protested outside the regional administration of In Salah and disrupted the circulation on the national route.

column23: Hundreds of teachers, students and employees in the education sector took part in a protest march  in Tizi Ouzou to demand the improvement of working conditions in their professional sector.

Around 300 municipal guards gathered on Monday in Boufarik (10 km north of Blida) with the purpose of marching on Algiers, before they were stopped by security forces. The police blocked the highway leading to Algiers from Boufarik, forcing the protesters to organise an alternative sit-in Haouche Gros, in the surroundings of the town. A similar march, in which nearly 500 municipal guards were likewise stopped by the security forces in December near Boufarik.

Clashes between anti riot troops and Berber activists were reported in the province of Boumerdes, 55 km in eastern Algiers, during the celebrations for the 35th anniversary of what is known as "the Berber Spring,"

Algerian troops killed three armed Islamists and recovered weapons and ammunition west of Algiers on Wednesday. The three were killed at around 1:00 am (0200 GMT) in an ambush close to the town of Hamman Righa, around 100 kilometres from the capital. The operation seized three automatic rifles, ammunition and several hand grenades, as well as binoculars and mobile phones.

According to ministerial sources, an armed man was killed, on Friday afternoon, in an ambush near the town of Djaafra, province of Bordj Bou Arreridj, by Algerian military forces. During the operation, a kalachnikov, a handgun and several ammunitions were seized.

Dozens of employees of the Gold Mines Exploitation National Company (Enor) in Tamanrasset (1920 km south of Algiers) took to the streets on Sunday to protest against the possibility of selling the company to foreign owners.

Algerian soldiers on Tuesday killed six armed Islamists in the Kabylie area some 140 kilometres (85 miles) east of the capital. A unit of the ANP (Algerian army) killed six gunmen in the afternoon during an operation near the locality of Akerrou. The ministry said that the militants, who belonged to the Katibat Ennour group, were ambushed by an army patrol after a tip off. They were killed following a lengthy exchange of fire.

Workers of SETRAM, the transport company in Oran, went on strike demanding the payment of overtime work, a better organisation within the company and the resignation of the current SETRAM director. The protesters have been on strike since May 1st. They staged a sit-in outside the central station in Oran.

The circulation of vehicles in Annaba was blocked by protesters who voiced their discontent for the persistence of problems of housing. On the road in front of the port, dozens of young protesters set tyres on fire while others erected road blocks, thus creating problems to the circulation throughout the rest of the city. Police forces decided not to intervene.

column22: Algeria Presse Service; Agence France Presse
column23: Two militants were killed and a Kalachnikov machine pistol, a Simonov semi-automatic rifle and a quantity of munitions were recovered on Tuesday by the forces of the Popular National Army (ANP), following an ambush near the town of Amrouna, in the south of the province of Ain Defla.

column7: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column23: A group of gunmen has killed four "patriot" officers (paramilitary group funded by the state to help in the fight against terrorism) on a road between Batna and Setif in north-eastern Algeria. The group shot at a convoy the officers were travelling in, which set the car on fire, killing the officers on board. The group was reportedly composed of 10 individuals who shot at the convoy and killed three officers, while the fourth officer fled. This officer was then followed by the group and shot dead. AQIM later claimed responsibility for this attack.

Nearly 200 inhabitants of Beni M'Haffer gathered outside the offices of Annaba province to demand the release of the list of the recipieients of public housing. Protests over housing cause some problems to the circulation of vehicles in Annaba in the past few days.
Protests over housing problems sprung up throughout Annaba province, involving the towns of El Bouni, Sidi Amar and Sidi Salem.

For three consecutive days, the town of Ghardaia has experienced unrest due to intercommunal clashes. Several houses, stores, and cars have been destroyed, others burned completely. The violence began in the Theniet El-Makhzen district last week and spread quickly to other places to finally settle in the El-Kaouty district. The clashes were triggered when unknown young people, arriving in large numbers, attacked the El-Kaouty district in the evening and smashed the windows of cars belonging to inhabitants as well as setting fire to several houses. These facts caused the citizens to come out to defend their property, resulting in sharp clashes between the two parties and then with the security forces that intervened and tried in vain to control the situation.
The anti-riot forces resorted to teargas to try to disperse Arab and Berber rioters in Ghardaia.

Algerian military said on Tuesday it killed 22 militants in what it deemed the most important military operation in 20 years in the northern province of Bouira. Algerian security forces killed at least 22 Islamist militants Tuesday as they were meeting to plan an attack on the capital of Algiers, a security source said, adding that the rest are still under manhunt. Automatic weapons, ammunition and other weaponry were seized in the operation, said the report. A security official told Reuters news agency the militants were members of the Caliphate Soldiers, an al Qaeda splinter group that had declared allegiance to the Islamic State militant group.

column22: Algeria Press Service; Agence France Presse
column23: A dangerous Islamist militant was killed and a machine pistol recovered following an ambush Sunday a by a detachment of the People's National Army near Mount Bou Yatas, province of Sidi Bel Abbes. The operation allowed the recovery of a Kalashnikov submachine gun, a pair of binoculars and a quantity of ammunition.

Algerian forces killed three militants just east of Algiers in a counter-insurgency sweep, raising the total slain over the past two days to 25. The army continued its sweeps and killed three others who had escaped the initial attack and fled south through the rugged terrain. Algeria has been battling the local branch of al-Qaida for years but most of their operations have been restricted to attacks on security forces in the rugged central mountains. Security sources said that the leader oj Jund Al Khilafa, Bachir Kherza (also known as Abou Abdellah Al Assimi), was among the 25 militants killed by the army on 19 and 20 May in Bouira.

column22: El Khabar, Agence France Presse; Radio France Internationale
column23: An officer in the Algerian People's National Army has been killed after a bomb detonated in Chelala Mountains in northeastern Algeria. The mountains, located in Batna province, had been searched weeks ago after Katibat al-Mut (Death Brigade) killed four Patriot members (the civilian militias backed by the government) on 12 May. AQIM later claimed responsibility.
The Association of Breeders of Cattle and Milk Producers of Bejaia decided to begin an indefinite strike against rising prices for animal feed and fodder.
The residents of a neighbourhood of Oran staged a protest march to demand the authorities fulfill their responsibilities regarding land tenture regularization in their area.
People who engaged in "National Service between 1995-1999" protested in a Tizi Ouzou market to demand the government resolve their grievances.
1 militant was killed during an ambush by Algerian soldiersnear the town of Draa El Mizan southwest of Tizi-Ouzou.
An elected CPA was found dead and buried in Bejaia after disappearing on Jun.10.

A man who was injured in clashes in southern Algeria has died of his wounds. The 33-year-old was wounded during clashes between groups of youths that began late on Friday in Berriane, site of off-and-on confrontations between Berber and Arab communities, and later died in the hospital.

column11: Arab Ethnic Group (Algeria); Berber Ethnic Group (Algeria)
column23: Riot police used tear gas to disperse Arab and Berber groups who engaged in clashes in Berriane.

column8: UGTA: General Union of Algerian Workers
column23: Drivers and employees of the National Company of Transports went on strike on Sunday in Algiers, blocking the circulation of trains for two consecutive days.
Four people were wounded after that a molotov cocktail set their car on fire. The four people were transferred to the nearest hospital.

An unprecedented protest was organized by the camps residents in Tindouf. Protesters have staged numerous sit-ins and demonstrations to denounce the arbitrary seizure of their vehicles by the Polisario armed militia at the order of Algerian army officers. The sit-ins and protest demonstrations were staged at the initiative of the Youth Movement for Change (MJPC) in various camps of Tindouf, where hundreds of Sahrawis simultaneously took to the street.

column22: MENA Financial Network; Algerie Presse Service
column23: Two armed militants have been killed on Monday evening in Azzeffoun by the forces of the People's National Army (ANP). The operation allowed to recover a Kalashnikov submachine gun, a Beretta automatic pistol, a quantity of ammunition and a cell phone.
Military units killed one armed militant near the town of Tacheta Zougagha. The army seized a semi-automatic rifle and ammunitions during the operation.
Military units killed other two armed militants near the town of Tacheta Zougagha. The army seized an assault rifle, a semi-automatic gun, some grenades and ammunitions during the operation.
Violent clashes erupted in Ain Bessem after that a man was accidentally shot dead by police forces. Anti-riot police intervened and restored the calm in town.
Workers of the local tramway company (SETRAM) went on strike and stage a demonstration on Saturday outside the offices of the company in Algiers.
Intercommunal clashes continued in Berriane, between members of Arab Chaambi and Berber Mozabite ethnic groups. The two groups exchange gunfires during the night and threw molotov cocktails.
Molotov cocktails were also thrown at police units deployed in Berriane.
After a night of continuing ethnic clashes between Arab and Berber groups, police forces, supported by anti-riot units, resorted to teargas to disperse the youths and end violence in Berriane.
Other intercommunal clashes between Arab and Berber communities were reported in Ghardaia. Police forces, supported by anti-riot units, were deployed to restore order in town.
Workers of the local tramway company (SETRAM) went on strike and stage a demonstration on Saturday outside the offices of the company in Algiers.
Workers of the local tramway companies (SETRAM) in Oran and Constantine went on strike and staged demonstrations on Sunday to demand better working conditions.

Two policemen were wounded during an attack carried out in the middle of Bouira by an unidentified armed group. The gunmen, who were in a car, fired at a police patrol near the OPOW Rabat Bitat sports complex wounding two policemen who were taken to the Mohamed Boudiaf hospital in Bouira.

column22: Agence France Presse; Algerie Presse Service
column23: Interethnic fighting erupted late on Tuesday in the town of Guerara in the M'zab valley. Three people were reported dead during clashes between Chaamba Arabs and Mozabite Berbers in Guerrara, two in Berriane and one in Ghardaia on Tuesday.

column22: Agence France Presse; Algerie Presse Service
column23: Interethnic fighting erupted late on Tuesday in the town of Guerara in the M'zab valley. Three people were reported dead during clashes between Chaamba Arabs and Mozabite Berbers in Guerrara, two in Berriane and one in Ghardaia on Tuesday.

The citizens of Ath Vouali village blocked the administrative office of Ath Vouali in sign of protest against the disruption of local services in their village.

column22: Agence France Presse; Algerie Presse Service
column23: 23 people died during ethnic clashes that erupted between youth groups in the regions of Guerrara and M'zab Valley (Ghardaia, 600 km south of Algiers) between Tuesday and Wednesday. The heaviest toll was recorded in Guerrara with 19 dead, due to projectiles thrown by unknown people. These clashes were marked by fire and acts of vandalism against houses, business premises, private vehicles and palm groves, street furniture and public buildings. An increasing number of security forces were deployed on the ground, supported by the anti-riot forces of the National Gendarmerie to put an end to these clashes which continued on Wednesday.

Dozens of people from the Mozabite community gathered Wednesday in Algiers for several hours to denounce acts of violence committed in Ghardaia and call for the return of peace and security in the region.

Several shopkeepers in Ghardaia, Berriane and Guerrara closed their shops in sign of protest after a call for a general strike in the aftermath of the ethnic clashes that erupted in the region. Other Berber shopkeepers adhered to the demonstration in Batna, Sétif, Constantine, Annaba and Bordj Bou Arreridj.

A gunman was killed and another arrested by the army in Msila. The operation was carried out near the town of Ain El Hadjel when a car carrying two suspicious people was controlled by elements of the National Gendarmerie. Following a shoot-out with the men in the car, the army units killed one of the gunmen and arrested the other, seizing a Kalashnikov machine gun, ammunitions, a mobile phone and other items.

column7: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column22: Agence France Presse; Radio France Internationale
column23: At least 9 soldiers were killed in an ambush carried out by AQMI in a southern mountainous area in Ain Defla region. According to an army statement, nine soldiers were ambushed during a combing operation near the locality of Djebel Louh. AQMI claimed responsibility for the attack, saying that they killed 14 soldiers. According to Radio France Internationale, the soldiers were attacked after they recovered the bodies of other three soldiers killed on Thursday during a shoot-out in the same area.
A crowd of young people protested on Sunday outside the offices of the province against employment procedures in the train company.
A militant was killed in an ambush carried out by army units near the commune of Ifigha.

Two military personnel have suffered light wounds during a shootout with a group of gunmen divided in several small groups trying to force soldiers out of the base and attract them to an ambush. The assailants used "artisanal mortar" then started to shower the old base with bullets in a "carefully prepared operation" before helicopters were dispatched to reinforce the troops.
Young people in Bechloul resumed their protest against employment procedures in the railway company. The protesters blocked the railway near Bechloul
Dozens of citizens interrupted the circulation of vehicles in Ohanet to protest against the lack of potable water in the area.
Protesters staged marches to demand justice over the disappearance of hundreds of Saharawi refugees.
A protest movement was launched by the security personnel of Sonatrach oil camps in Ouargla region to demand the regularisation of their professional situation.
The citizens of Kechida in Batna blocked the routes of the town to protest against the interruption of water supply that has been going on in their area for one month.
The protest movement launched by the security personnel of Sonatrach oil plants in Ouargla region extended to another Sonatrach site in Illizi.
For the second consecutive day, the security personnel of Sonatrach oil plants in Ouargla region staged a protest movement to demand the regularisation of their professional situation.

Clashes occurred in ArcelorMittal complex in El Hadjar, Annaba, involving a group of strikers and the factory's security units. According to a local source, around sixty workers tried to break into the complex but clashed with the security personnel. Eight wounded reported.

During an armed confrontation between troops of the national army and a militant group, a military officer was killed near Ain Kechra on the evening of 14 August. The soldiers were ambushed by the armed group during a combing operation in the area. During the following shootout, a militant was killed and another arrested.

A police officer was shot on a foot by a gendarme in Aomar. During a routine inspection on a vehicle at a checkpoint, the gendarme noticed the presence of arms and opened the fire on the passengers, police officers in civilian dress, mistaking them for militants.
Around twenty inhabitants of Ain el Turk protested outside the offices of the province to demand that some sellers in the local market are moved somewhere else.

Two militants were killed on Saturday in the locality of Oued Zeguere, near Ain Kechra. Military units have been carrying out operations in the area since Saturday, when a soldier was killed during a shootout with militants.
Riots between residents of Mira village over land issues. Several wounded people reported.
An Islamist militant was killed on Sunday in Ain Laksar, Skikda province. Other two militants were killed on Saturday.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Algerian security forces have arrested two leading figures in Islamic State group in Tebessa Province, 20 kilometres west from the border with Tunisia. The two were reportedly Libyan nationals and were captured while trying to enter Algeria from Tunisia. The captured IS leaders were carrying two firearms and hand grenades.

column10: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column23: Two militants linked to AQIM were killed and weapons were recovered by the special units of the People's National Army during an ambush in the commune of Taher. The two militants killed were Nefla Noureddine and his assistant Bouhnika Abdelouahab.
Dozens of people from Ait Said village staged a demonstration outside the provincial administration in Chabet El Ameur to protest against the lack of potable water.

A group of citizens blocked the road connecting Tizi Ouzou to Algiers in Tadmait with boulders and trees . The protesters demanded that the authorities provide explanation over the death of two young people found deadthe week before.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Former intelligence chief, General Hassan,  has been arrested at his home in Algiers and held in a military prison near Blida. He has been charged with insubordination, plot against the state, manipulation of information and detention of firearms.
Abdou Chikh Talha, a militant who joined Islamist groups in 1993, was killed in moulay Slissene by army troops. During this operation, Algerian forces seized also guns and ammunitions.
Residents of Boudjima marched in protest against rising violence in the region
Riots erupted between residents in Oued Tlelat.
In Oued Tlelat, riots between residents and newcomers continue. 19 young people, allegedly belonging to local gangs, have been arrested
Riots between local youth gangs in Barika. Police did not intervene. Several wounded people reported.

Some Polisario soldiers, belonging to the Tekna tribe, staged a protest during the an inspection visit by Polisario leader Mohamed Abdelaziz. The soldiers were protesting the rampant corruption within the Polisario military structures placed under the command of Mohamed Lamine Bouhali.

column8: UNEA: National Union of Algerian Students
column23: Students engage in protests at university in Tiaret. They blocked the entrance to denounce university's malfunctionings.
Two Islamist gunmen were killed by the Algerian army in Boumerdes province.
A sit-in was staged outside the offices of the wilaya in Boumerdes to denounce the delays in completing a housing project.
Dozens of residents set tyres on fire and erecterd roadblocks in Mostaganem to protest against the degradation of a near garbage dump site.
A movement of protest was launched by a group of teachers in Ouled Rached to protest against the state of insecurity within school structures.
Residents of Skikda, who were assigned public housing, staged a protest in Skikda to denounce the delays in the allotment of residences.
Eleven unemployed people staged a sit-in outside the offices of the National Employment Agency in Bir El-Ater to demand jobs in the phosphate company of Djebel El Anek.
Teachers in the Faculty of Law and Political Science at Akli Mohand Oulhadj University in Bouira organised a protest to denounce the current state of insecurity in the campus.
A movement of protest was launched by a group of teachers in Ouled Rached to protest against the state of insecurity within school structures.
Eleven unemployed people staged a sit-in outside the offices of the National Employment Agency in Bir El-Ater to demand jobs in the phosphate company of Djebel El Anek.
Protesters in Sidi Bel Abbes denounced irregular employment procedures.
A movement of protest was launched by a group of teachers in Ouled Rached to protest against the state of insecurity within school structures.
Eleven unemployed people staged a sit-in outside the offices of the National Employment Agency in Bir El-Ater to demand jobs in the phosphate company of Djebel El Anek.
A movement of protest was launched by a group of teachers in Ouled Rached to protest against the state of insecurity within school structures.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: In retaliation to a sentence pronounced against nine Sahrawis from the Rguibat and Aït Oussa tribes for an alleged drug trafficking, a group of youths riding all-terrain vehicles stormed a military checkpoint placed under the joint command of the Polisario and the Algerian gendarmerie in the so-called 6th Polisario military zone, near the Laayoune refugee camp. The attackers tied up two sentinels who were guarding the post, took their firearms and ammunition before they fled on board of their vehicles. The Polisario armed militia called to the rescue conducted a sweep operation in the camp but could not get identify the attackers nor recover the stolen weapons. No violence was reported.

On the fourth day of protest, police arrested the eleven unemployed people who were staging a demonstration outside the offices of the National Employment Agency in Bir El-Ater to demand jobs in the phosphate company of Djebel El Anek.
200 people gathered outside the police commissioner's office to demand the release of the four unemployed arrested by police in the morning.

A movement of protest was launched by a group of teachers in Ouled Rached to protest against the state of insecurity within school structures. The strike enterred the fifth day on Thursday, September 17th.

A group of young residents from Mers el Kebir clashed with police forces on Friday afternoon. They started to block the routes and throw stones after that a housing project was delayed by the authorities.

column7: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column23: AQIM gunmen stormed the village of Bouarbi in Dellys. During a combing operation in the area, police forces exchanged fire with the assailants. No violence against civilians was reported.
Residents of Hassi Mameche staged a sit-in to draw attention on long-standing housing problems in their area.
A protest march was held on Wednesday in Amizour following the killing of two men last week.
Students protested and blocked access to Nacer Brahim high school in Bitam.
Residents of a neighbourhood in Jijel blocked the circulation of vehicles for about two hours to protest against the deterioration of transport infrastructure in the area.

Residents of Douar Oum Teboul in Sidi M'Hamed Ben Ali took to the streets to voice their discontent over the degradation of living conditions in the area. They interrupted the circulation of vehicles on the road CW87, which connects their town to Taouagrit.

column8: ONEA: National Organisation of Algerian Students
column23: Students of ONEA staged a sit-in outside a university building in Es Senia to protest against the allegedly unlawful detention of two students.
Residents staged a sit-in to protest against allocation of public housing.
Rioters blocked a national route in Djendel, 15km from Azzaba.
Kamel Eddine Fekhar, arrested after the riots in Ghardaia, began a hunger strike to denounce his illegal detention.

column8: RCD: Rally for Culture and Democracy Party
column23: Thousands of protesters marched in Tizi Ouzou to denounce the cancellation of investment in the region, the violation of security forces, the release of political prisoners and the recognition of Tamazight. The demonstration was called by the RCD.
Hundreds of students and teachers of the University of Bejaia marched in protest against the proposed relocation to the new campus of Amizour.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Seven caches containing a homemade bomb and 15 antipersonnel mines have been discovered Sunday by a detachment of the National Popular Army.

The residents of a village named Leftaimate erected barricades and blocked the circulation of vehicles on the national route connecting Skikda to Annaba. The protesters denounced the poor condition of the local schooling system.
A militant was killed by the army during a combing operation conducted Monday near the place called Oued Ifrane, in Beni Rached, located between the provinces of Tipaza and Chlef.

column10: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column23: The army killed a militant known as Abou El-Hacen. The man, also known as Abou Hassan and Abou Salman, is described as one of the top leaders of AQIM. He was the engineer of abductions and had participated in three significant abductions in northern Mali and southern Algeria.
Several Algerian NGOs organised a sit-in in support of migrants outside the offices of Bejaia province.
Journalists of El Watan TV protest outside the Ministry of Communication against the closure of their channel.
300 protesters gathered outside the offices of the local administration to claim public housing. Police forces were deployed in the area.
143 employees in the Direction for Urbanism and Construction of Constantine went on strike on October 12 the denounce the the office's mismanagement.

Dozens of journalists and activists have been staging protests outside the parliament against the closure of private Al-Watan TV channel. This was the second day of protests against the closure of the channel following the statements given by Madani Mezrag, the leader of the Islamic Salvation Army (AIS), in which he criticized President Bouteflika.
Due to a protest movement initiated by residents, the mayor of Benchoud could not quit his office for several hours. The villagers had also blocked the route connecting Dellys to Baghlia.
Dozens of residents of Baghlia took to the streets to demand that asphalt on the town's routes.

Protests were registered in another town of Boumerdes province. In Bordj Menaïel, residents took to the streets to denounce the condition of the town's routes and the interruption of a project that would bring natural gas to Omar village.
Protests continued on Wednesday in Ben Choud.
Other protests staged by residents were reported in Berrahmoun and Aoudia, in the town of Corso.
In Naciria, residents blocked the traffic to protest against the failed realisation of public works in town.
Dozens of citizens from Cité Tenia gathered in front of the offices of the wilaya in Mila to protest against the lack of public services in their area.

column10: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column23: Algerian soldiers killed three Islamist gunmen on Tuesday during a military operation in a region east of the capital. The army seized three Kalashnikov assault rifles as well as ammunition and nine cellphones.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: The National Demining Institute (INAD) destroyed 871 explosive devices defused from January to March in Okapanda, 14km from Ondjiva in Cunene Province.

column8: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column23: UNITA members clashed with unidentified group in Cuango Municipality when unidentified group opposed UNITA holding a political rally. UNITA's commune representative was wounded and 9 vehicles damaged.

Religious sect Seventh Day Light of the World attacked police in Sume Mountain, 25 km from Caala, as police attempted to arrest the sect's leader Kalupeteka. 9 policemen killed, 13 sect members killed.
1 died, 4 injured in Chitembo, 150km from Cuito, following the explosion of a device.
1 injured when landmine exploded in Ondjiva's Caxila III ward.
Protests in Independence Square against arbitrary detention. Police with dogs contained the crowd. One person bitten but no reports of serious injuries. Several arrested, including journalists.
50 protesters demanded the release of arrested activists. Police used batons. Several detained. No reports of serious injuries.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: 106 unexploded ordance removed from Quéssua Hill, Malanje.
100 protesters gather in Luanda to demand the release of 15 activists arrested on June 20. 20 arrested at protests.

Public healthcare workers went on a 72 hour strike, called "Dead Hospital", to demand better working conditions. They deserted hospitals and health centers and decided to strike for 48-72 hours per week until an agreement is reached.
Fulani herders clashed with youth from a local farming community.
One person died and four were seriously injured in a clash between farmers from Gangban and Fulani herders in the Tohouè area.
Justice sector employees went on a 72 hour strike to improve working and living conditions.

column8: Forum of Workers and People for a New System of Governance
column23: Hundreds marched and held a sit-in against the presdient and his party's confiscation of public media services, especially the Office of Radiodiffusion and Television of Benin (ORTB).

Activists stormed the National Institute for Social, Economic and Civil Education and chanted anti-government slogans before retreating to the opening meeting of the National Standing Committee for Consultation and Collective Bargaining between the Government and Unions
Staff of kindergartens, primary and secondary schools began a 48-hour strike.
The population of Dangoussar boycotted the general election to protest lack of electricity, preventing some from Baréi village from voting as well.
An armed group from Baréi attacked Dangoussar village in retaliation for preventing them from voting on Sunday. Two were killed and several injured.

column22: Xinhua News Agency - French; Agence France Presse
column23: After several police officers were seen outside the home of opposition leader Candide Azannai, several hundred young people stormed the streets, barricading the road towards Lome by setting fires and preventing his arrest.

column22: Xinhua News Agency - French; Agence France Presse
column23: Several hundred opposition protesters marched in the capital, throwing stones at the police who used tear gas against them.

column8: UNAMAB: National Union of Magistrates of Benin
column22: Radio France Internationale; Xinhua General News Service
column23: Judges went on strike, demanding a change in recruitment policies. The strike ended four weeks later after government talks.
Teachers went on a 48 hour strike, causing schools to close and demanding the government improve living and working conditions.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Botswana Defence Forces raided and burned four temporary fishing camps villages in Linyanti, where BDF claimed Namibian fishermen were conducting illegal fishing. Several arrested.
Botswana police detain and beat Zimbabwean immigrants with canes, causing severe injuries.
More than 100 students at the National School for Public Health protested disciplinary measures, causing the school to shut down temporarily.
Rioters set fire to Truegold mining materials in Noogo. Police forces used tear gas to take control of the area while firefighters attended to the scene.
Youth sought out supporters the TrueGold Mining company in order to damage their property, including setting vehicles on fire and ransacking homes.
Youth sought out supporters the TrueGold Mining company in order to damage their property, including setting vehicles on fire and ransacking homes.
Students went on strike calling for certain professors to be fired.

column8: SYNTB: National Union of Brewery Workers
column23: Workers at the Burkina Faso brewery (BRAKINA) and beverage distributors from SODIBO around the country went on a 48-hour strike to demand wage increases among other things.

column8: Muslim Group (Burkina Faso); Christian Group (Burkina Faso)
column23: Muslims, with Christian support, protested recent French journal Charlie Hebdo's caricatures of the prophet Mohammed.
300 people demonstrated against the damage elephants cause to their farms.

column8: SYNTB: National Union of Brewery Workers
column23: Workers at the Burkina Faso brewery (BRAKINA) and beverage distributors from SODIBO went on a 72-hour strike to demand wage increases among other things.
Justice department unionists went on strike, shutting down all juridical activities.
A group of youth accosted and temporarily detained a judge in front of the courthouse, in retaliation for recent arrests of protesters.

Students threw stones at the school and then ransacked the home of public secondary school headmaster Samate Santa and burned his vehicle in protest of disciplinary procedures against 5 students. They tried to attack the homes of other staff but were stopped by security forces.
Employees of Canal 3 television held a sit-in to demand increase in salaries and the CEO's resignation.

column8: CCVC: National Coalition against High Cost of Living, Corruption, Fraud and Impunity and for Liberty
column23: Protesters demonstrated against high fuel prices.

column8: CCVC: National Coalition against High Cost of Living, Corruption, Fraud and Impunity and for Liberty
column23: Protesters demonstrated against high fuel prices.

column8: CCVC: National Coalition against High Cost of Living, Corruption, Fraud and Impunity and for Liberty
column23: Protesters demonstrated against high fuel prices.

column8: CCVC: National Coalition against High Cost of Living, Corruption, Fraud and Impunity and for Liberty
column23: Hundreds protested  against high fuel prices.

column8: CCVC: National Coalition against High Cost of Living, Corruption, Fraud and Impunity and for Liberty
column23: Protesters demonstrated against high fuel prices.

column8: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-) Presidential Security Unit
column23: The presidential guard stormed into the weekly Council of Ministers meeting at the presidential palace, demanding benefits.
Protesters gathered at the Place de la Revolution to demonstrate against the Presidential Guard.
Protesters against the Presidential Guard were attacked by unknown assailants who damanged their vehicle, leaving one injured.
In Ouagadougou and several other locations across the country, thousands of protesters marched to demand the dissolution of the presidential guard.
Civil society organizations and members of political opposition parties marched and gave speeches in favor of the dissolution of the Presidential Guard.

A coalition of trade unions started a 48 hour general strike to demand better living and working conditions, especially lower fuel prices. The strike was well attended and affected primarily education and health sectors.
Students from the university of Ouagadougou have engaged in a 48-hour strike to demand resolution of their grievances.
Inhabitants of Rimkieta, a neighborhood on the north-west side of Ouagadougou, blocked the road leading towards Nonsin to demand maintence and restoration of the neglected roadway.
Tidjania Muslims started intercepting Sunni Muslims in the streets to stop them from praying and destroyed their property. Many Sunnis started hiding in their homes without food or water.
Tidjania Muslims targeted Wahhabist Sunni Muslims, injuring several and causing material damages including setting fire to homes and places of worship.

column8: SYNAJ: National Union of Justice System Agents
column23: Members of the SYNAJ and Union of Clerks of Burkina (GBS) began a strike to demand better working conditions.

column8: SYNTB: National Union of Brewery Workers
column23: Brakina and Sodibo brewery workers went on strike, stopping all work at the factories in Ouagadougou and Bobo Dioulassoand, holding a sit-in to demand higher wages.

column8: SYNTB: National Union of Brewery Workers
column23: Brakina and Sodibo brewery workers went on strike, stopping all work at the factories in Ouagadougou and Bobo Dioulassoand, holding a sit-in to demand higher wages.

column8: SYNACIT: Independent Union of Labour Inspectors and Controllers
column23: Workers from the Regional Direction of Labor and Social Security held a sit-in to express discontent with an incident with gendarmes they day before.

column8: SYNACIT: Independent Union of Labour Inspectors and Controllers
column23: Labor inspectors and controllers went on a 72 hour strike to demand better working conditions.

column8: UCRB: Union of Burkina Truck Drivers
column22: Le Pays (Ouagadougou); Xinhua News Agency - French; Sidwaya (Ouagadougou)
column23: Truck drivers went on a 48 hour strike to improve working conditions. They blocked the route from Ouagadougou to Bobo-Dioulasso.

column8: UCRB: Union of Burkina Truck Drivers
column23: Hundreds of truck drivers marched to demand better work and living conditions, including increased wages.

column11: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-); Civilians (Romania)
column22: Agence France Presse - English; Fasozine; Agence France Presse
column23: 5 gunmen attacked  a security vehicle near a mine, shooting and injuring the driver and a policeman and kidnapping a Romanian security officer who was unarmed. They then headed towards Mali or Niger. One month later, Al-Mourabitoun confirmed that they still had the Romanian in their custody.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column11: CDP: Congress for Democracy and Progress
column23: Authorities arrested three former ministers from the government of deposed dictator Compaore - Jerome Bougouma, Jean-Bertin Ouedraogo, and Salif Kabore. It is unclear what the charges against them are and where they are being detained.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column11: CDP: Congress for Democracy and Progress
column23: Authorities arrested two former mayors, including the current sectretary-general of the CDP party, on charges of preparing an insurrection.
About 30 protesters marched against a law that would exclude members of the former regime from upcoming elections. They were dispersed by police using tear gas.
Protesters marched against political discrimination in light of an upcoming vote to exclude members of the former regime from the next elections.

column8: CDP: Congress for Democracy and Progress
column22: Le Pays (Ouagadougou); Agence d'Informations du Burkina; Xinhua News Agency - French; Agence France Presse - English
column23: While a vote took place to block members of the former regime from upcoming elections, protesters both for and against the amendment chanted in the streets and one group blocked a road and burned tires. Small clashes broke out with the police who used teargas and arrested five.
Thousands marched in protest of high cost of living.
Protesters marched against high costs of living.

column8: CCVC: National Coalition against High Cost of Living, Corruption, Fraud and Impunity and for Liberty
column22: Agence France Presse; PANAPRESS; Radio France Internationale
column23: Unions and civil society organizations launched a general strike to protest high costs of living and around 5,000 people held a protest. Most businesses remained open, with only the University of Ouagadougou following the strike for the entire day.
Protesters marched against high costs of living.

column8: SYNACIT: Independent Union of Labour Inspectors and Controllers
column23: Labour inspectors declared a national 5-day strike from Apr.13-17.
An ongoing dispute between farmers and herders in a village near Ziniare led to riots where property was burned and some livestock killed. Police intervened with teargas and arrested three.
Workers from the African Pneumatic Society joined by the UAS union marched to demand payment of housing allowances.
Protesters marched in favor of the new electoral code which excludes supporters of former president Campaore.
Thousands protested in favor of the new electoral code that excludes supporters of former president Campaore.
University students marched in favor of changing the License-Master-Doctorate system.
Workers marched in protest of high costs of living.
Members of 33 villages in the Sabce commune protested in favor of returning a recently expelled prefect to his position in the municipality.

column8: SGB: Union of Clerks of Burkina
column23: Justice system clerks started a month long strike to demand better working regulations.
A vigilante militia lynched a presumed cattle thief in the Zorgo area.

column8: SYNACIT: Independent Union of Labour Inspectors and Controllers
column23: Labor inspectors and controllers went on a 120 hour strike to demand better working conditions.
An angry mob attacked and nearly lynched a priest accused of having an affair with a local woman. They beat him and eventually handed him over to the police.

An angry mob of women armed with knives and axes burned tires and set up barricades in front of the gendarmerie in Saaba to demand the release of an alleged serial rapist and murdered in order to enact vigilante justice.

Residents of Saaba protested to demand better security measures in the area, barricading the National Route 4. Security forces were present and stopped potential clashes between protesters and those trying to use the road.
Hundreds of protesters marched in Ouagadougou against genetically modified agriculture, especially cotton produced by the Monsanto company.

Dozens gathered at the Dagnoen cemetery in eastern Ouagadougou and chanted nationalist slogans while authorities exhumed the alleged body of Thomas Sanakara, who was assassinated in 1987. Police prevented them from entering the cemetery.
Hundreds of journalists from public and private press houses demonstrated in front of the media regulatory body against a recent suspension of live radio and TV programs.
Youth marched against homosexuality in the Sikasso-Sira neighborhood of Bobo-Dioulasso, targeting the homes of family members of suspected lesbians.
The resumption of activities by the True Gold mining activity led to riots in Namissiguima. 4 protesters and 3 security forces were injured, a security vehicle was damaged, and 15 were arrested.
Inhabitants from the Outourou and Negueni villages clashed over the proposed construction of  a middle school, leaving 3 dead and 20 injured. All of the homes in Outourou were burned.

Protesters came to the Korgho mine 20 km from Gaoua and asked miners to leave, which led to an altercation between the two groups causing at least 8 injuries and property damage. Police arrested some of the perpetrators.
Scholarship students from the University of Ouagadougou held a sit-in to demand that the government renew their scholarships.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Associated Press International
column23: Two French soldiers allegedly sexually molested two young girls at a swimming pool in Ouagadougou. The soldiers were repatriated; one was held and one freed. Local police opened an investigation.

column8: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014) Presidential Security Unit
column22: Associated Press International; Agence France Presse; Sidwaya (Ouagadougou)
column23: Two leaders of the Presidential Guard were questioned by police regarding a potential plot to overthrow President Zida. In response, soldiers from an elite Burkina Faso military unit fired shots into the air in their barracks, and a dozen were arrested after.

column8: ANEB: National Association of Burkinabe Students
column23: Students held a sit-in and submitted a letter of protest to the Ministry of Health demanding better living conditions.

After a man was taken into police custody for his involvement in an altercation at a market, an angry mob attacked the police station, breaking windows and taking the man into their custody. The crowd beat the man until he was in serious condition and the authorities were able to regain custody.
In Ouaregou, in the Beguedo district, a dispute between two Muslim brotherhoods degenerated into clashes, resulting in many injuries and material damage.

Protesters from Falangoutou, Gorom-Gorom, Essakane and Markoye came together to demonstrate against the employment practices of the IAMGOLD mining company. At least 28 were arrested for vandalism and destruction of property.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column11: CDP: Congress for Democracy and Progress
column23: Two former ministers from the CDP regime, Jean Bertin Ouédraogo (Transport) and Jerome Bougouma (Security), were jailed for "misappropriation of public funds".
650 people who were injured in the October 2014 insurrection held a protest in opposition to the candidature of the former ruling party, the CDP.

column10: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-) Gendarmerie
column22: Associated Press International; Agence France Presse; Fasozine; Le Pays (Ouagadougou)
column23: Several suspected Islamic militants launched an attack against a gendarmerie brigade near the border with Mali, seriously wounding a young girl and a gendarme who later died from his wounds.
Unidentified individuals attacked and seriously injured a security guard at the independent Radio Manegmoogo in Pissila. Then they set fire to the building.
Employees of SN SOSUCO demonstrated against a recent deal to import sugar from Brazil. They blocked the roads that lead from Banforo to Bobo-Dioulasso and Orodara.
Youth held a sit-in against the Nantou Mining company.
Protesters were arrested while holding a sit-in against the Nantou Mining company.

column8: SYNAFI: National Union of Finance Agents
column23: Workers from the Ministry of Finance went on strike and held a sit-in in front of the Ministry.
Hundreds of protesters marched against suspected fraud by public servants.

column8: SYNAFI: National Union of Finance Agents
column23: Workers from the Ministry of Finance held a sit-in as part of an ongoing strike. Police dispersed the protesters with tear gas.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-) Presidential Security Unit
column22: Associated Press International; Media Foundation for West Africa; Agence France Presse - English; Xinhua General News Service
column23: The Presidential Security Unit took hostage Prime Minister Zida, President Kafando, and two ministers and set up barricades around the presidential palace. The hostages were released late the following day and the president security unit announced it had taken control of the country in a coup. They named themselves the National Council for Democracy and declared General Gilbert Diendere their leader. The closed land and air borders for 24 hours and put a curfew in effect.

column7: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-) Presidential Security Unit
column22: Media Foundation for West Africa; Xinhua General News Service
column23: Members of the Presidential Security Unit forced radio stations to shut down throughout the capital as they executed a coup at the Presidential Palace. Some journalists were also beaten on the streets as they tried to cover the situation.

column7: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-) Presidential Security Unit
column22: Associated Press International; Xinhua General news Service
column23: Protesters flocked to the presidential palace, where military forces were holding the president and prime minister captive. Gunfire was heard, and one protester was killed.
17 trade unions call general strike until presidential guard behind the coup is dissolved.

column7: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-) Presidential Security Unit
column22: Xinhua General News Service; BBC; Agence France Presse - English
column23: At least two anti-coup protesters were killed and 60 injured by soldiers.
Anti-coup protesters took to the streets in Bobo-Dioulasso. They set fire to the home of a member of the CDP.
Protesters set up barricades in reaction to a recent coup.
Protesters set up barricades and lowered government flags in reaction to a recent coup.
Protesters took to the streets in reaction to a recent coup, setting up citizen committees to "defend democracy".
Protesters took to the streets in reaction to a recent coup, setting up citizen committees to "defend democracy".
Trade unions went on strike to protest the coup by General Diendere. It lasted 10 days and "paralyzed" the national economy.

column10: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-) Presidential Security Unit

column23: Anti-coup protesters in the Ouagadougou areas of Hamdalaye, Larle, Gounghin, Zogona, and Zone 1 erected barricades and lit tyres. Security forces shot at protesters, killing at least seven and injuring at least 80.

column23: Anti-coup protesters in the Ouagadougou areas of Hamdalaye, Larle, Gounghin, Zogona, and Zone 1 erected barricades and lit tyres. Security forces shot at protesters, killing at least seven and injuring at least 80.
Anti-coup protesters continued to march in Bobo-Dioulasso, ignoring the newly imposed curfew.
Anti-coup protesters marched in Gaoua.
The homes of two former Compaore allies (Simon Compaore and Salif Diallo) were ransacked by anti-coup rioters.
Youth and other protesters blocked the western entrance to Ouagadougou, setting fire to tires to put pressure on coup leaders.
50 anti-coup protesters gather at Independence Square before being turned away by police and heading towards Laico Hotel, where mediations were being held.

column8: CDP: Congress for Democracy and Progress
column11: Protesters (Burkina Faso); Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-)
column22: Deutsche Welle; Xinhua; Radio France Internationale
column23: Coup supporters burned tires in front of the Laico Hotel where mediations were being held, and attacked foreign ambassadors and anti-coup protesters. Security intervened and fired shots.

column8: The Citizen's Broom; Mossi Ethnic Group (Burkina Faso)
column23: 2000 protesters, including from Citizen's Broom, surrounded the home of Mossi ethnic traditional chief Mogho Naba, chanting for his surrender for suspected involvement in the coup.

Rioters burned tries in the street in protest of the draft agreement between military and coup leaders, which proposed to allow loyalists of former President Compoare and members of former ruling party to participate in elections.
Citizen's Broom rioters burned tires and stretched cables on the roads in Tampouy, protesting against the ECOWAS-mediated proposed amnesty for coup leaders.

column10: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-) Presidential Security Unit
column23: 1 presidential security soldier killed, another injured in attack by unknown group on outskirts of Ouagadougou.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-) Presidential Security Unit
column23: Interim President Kafando resumes power after week-long coup, signing a peace deal with the Presidential Security Unit.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Troops arrested Djibril Bassole, presidential hopeful and former foreign minister under Compaore, for his alleged involvement in a recent coup by the Presidential Security Unit.

column10: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-) Presidential Security Unit
column22: Associated Press International; Agence France Presse - English
column23: The army used gunfire to take over the Presidential Security Unit barracks where coup supporters were refusing to disarm. The Presidential Security Unit surrendered, and the government reports there were no casualties.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Soldiers were seen throughout the Ouaga 2000 district of Ouagadougou looking for members of the Presidential Security Unit. Marksmen were seen in positions around the Presidential Security barracks.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
column23: The vice president of the National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad was briefly arrested at the Ouagadougou airport over suspected links to the recent coup in Burkina Faso.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column10: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-) Presidential Security Unit
column22: Xinhua General News Service; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Coup leader Gilber Diendere was arrested and handed over to transition authorities. Over 800 of the 1300 member Presidential Security Unit have surrendered and taken up new postings in the military.
Students smashed windows and surrounded cars while protesting at Kossodo University, demanding that classes resume since the coup events of September have finished.
Dozens of workers from the Bissa Gold mining company held a sit-in to demand payment of September salaries.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column11: CDP: Congress for Democracy and Progress; Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-) Presidential Security Unit
column23: Authorities arrested Achille Tapsoba, the vice president of the CDP, for his role in a recent coup. Three other pro-Compaore political leaders (Colonel Sidi Pare, Leonce Kone, and Hermann Yameogo) were arrested earlier in the week. The government also officially dismantled the Presidential Security Unit of the military after their participation in the recent coup.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Radio France Internationale; Xinhua General News Service
column23: Three police were killed in a raid on their barracks carried out by at least 30 attackers - perhaps jihadists" connected to a simultaneous attack in the Mopti region of Mali, or troops associated with a recent failed coup in Burkina Faso. 1 assailant and 1 civilian were also killed.

Students blocked routes to the university in Bobo-Dioulasso and overtook canteens on campus, demanding the reopening of certain buildings, reductions in rent, increased bus access, and improvements in food service.

Students encircled and overtook the administrative building of the General Directorate of the National Center of Academic Affairs, demanding the dismissal of the Director General and retraction of previous vandalism charges.
Artisans held a sit-in to demand better conditions in the artisinal village.

column11: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column22: RPA; Radio France Internationale; Voix du Burundi
column23: Fighting between unidentified attackers believed to be from the DRC and the Burundian army as well as associated paramilitary forces, including the Imbonerakure (from Jan.1-2), between Dec.30-Jan.2 has resulted in between 99 total deaths, with 95 attackers killed and 9 captured by Burundian military forces, 2 Burundian soldiers killed, and 2 civilians dead. RPA reports that some of the attackers have been executed after surrendering their weapons by suspected Imbonerakure youths, although the government has denied this.
Followers of Euzebie, "who claims to have seen divine apparations", engaged in a "scuffle" with police, leading to at least 62 arrests. 6 police were injured during the fight.

column11: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column22: RPA; Radio France Internationale; Voix du Burundi

RPA reports that some of the attackers have been executed after surrendering their weapons by suspected Imbonerakure youths, although the government has denied this.

RPA reports that some of the attackers have been executed after surrendering their weapons by suspected Imbonerakure youths, although the government has denied this.

column11: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: An unidentified armed group of 5 people armed with AK47 rifles attacked Kagumwe hill in Ruyigi province. They killed 3 people and burned down the local Imbonerakure HQ. The victims were tied up before being shot, and one of them was the director of the primary school.
Several hundred people demonstrated in front of the Embassy of France in solidarity with the people of France following the Charlie Hebdo attack.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column11: FRODEBU: Front for Democracy in Burundi
column23: The youth leader of FRODEBU was arested allegedly for connection to rebels that attacked Citiboke.
Around 2,000 people demonstrated in favor of the country's security forces; some may have been paid by the government to participate. Opposition parties did not take part.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column22: Agence France Presse - English; Radio France Internationale
column23: Police arrested Bob Rugurika, the head of a key opposition radio station (RPA: Radio Publique Africaine) who broadcast an alleged confession of a person who murdered three Italian nuns in September.
A protest was held in front of the courthouse where a trial took place against Bob Rugurika, the director of the RPA Radio Station

Almost 30 people people demonstrated against Bob Rugurika, the African Public Radio director who was recently arrested after accusing Guillame Harushimana of killing three nuns last September. Police stood by and later asked the protesters to leave.

Dozens protested on "Green Tuesday" demanding the release of Bob Rugurika, a radio station director who was recently arrested for broadcasting alleged testimony regarding the September 2014 murder of three nuns.

column8: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column10: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column22: Radio Publique Africaine; Radio France Internationale
column23: Close to 200 armed men from the Democratic Republic of Congo fought for four days with the Burundi military and Imbonerakure youth throughout the Cibitoke area. 95 were killed and 9 jailed. There are reports that captured militants were killed on the spot.

column8: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
