Around 150 journalists and members of civil society demonstrated in support of jailed African Public Radio Director, Bob Rugurika. The protest was officially banned, but police did not intervene.
Supporters of the jailed African Public Radio director, Bob Rugurika, protested in front of the courthouse to ask for his release. The protest was technically banned, but police did not stop it.

Thousands of protesters welcomed the release on bail of African Public Radio director Bob Rugurika, who has been in jail since January for publishing an interview of a person suspected of murdering three nuns in 2014.

column22: Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse - English
column23: In the largest protest in recent years, thousands gathered to welcome the release on bail of the Africa Public Radio director Bob Rugurika and to demand change and increased democracy.

Commission Nationale de Terre et Autres Biens (CNTB) officials, accompanied by 11 police officers and an agent of the national intelligence service, were prevented from accessing the area of Buheka Hill after residents armed themselves with clubs and machetes and blocked the Buheka-Vugizo road with rocks and trees. The police beat a resident, while others threw rocks at the officers. At least one officer also fired shots into the crowd but no casualties were reported.

Thousands of Burundians took part in a "government backed rally for peace", where leaders spoke out against opposition, civil groups and the media. The rally follows a large demonstration last month following the release of a popular journalist and government critic from jail.

column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: A man was kidnapped by armed men who were allegedly Imbonerakure, taken to Rukoko and then ransomed.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Armed men raided a village in the Gihanga area, looting shops and bars and firing indiscriminately. No casualties were reported.

column22: Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse
column23: A general strike was held mostly in the private sector, primarily affecting transportation and education services. The strikers demanded abolition of a new cell phone tax and a decrease in gas prices.
Unknown gunmen attacked a military post in the Rukoko natural reserve, and they exchanged gunfire for about five minutes.
The wife of the leader of the FNL was injured in an alleged assassination attempt when unidentified attackers shot her in the head at a hair salon.

column8: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: A man was captured by Ndombolo (a group connected to the Imbonerakure) and accused of being pro-FNL Rwasa. He was then beaten until he satisfied his captors that he wasn't pro-FNL, and was dropped off in Rukoko.

column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column22: The New Times (Kigali); Radio Publique Africaine; Relief Web
column23: Imbonerakure militia members have reportedly been harassing and assaulting civilians, causing hundreds to flee to Rwanda. It is possible the Imbonerakure have also abducted youth for military training. The Kirundo province governor has reportedly authorized Imbonerakure youth to conduct patrols to prevent additional citizens from fleeing.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Unidentified assailants threw a grenade onto the home of a Bonesha FM journalist. The grenade caused no injuries but damaged the house.

column8: CNDD-FDD: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy
column23: 10,000 protesters marched in favor of the ruling party and President Nkurunziza.

column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: A man's shop was looted by armed men who then took four people hostage, including the shopkeeper, to help them carry the goods. Afterwards they released the others and ransomed the shopkeeper. A primary school teacher also in Gihanga was robbed, kidnapped and ransomed by the same men as well. The armed men involved were allegedly Imbonerakure.

column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: A man was beaten with clubs by youths who were allegedly Imbonerakure due to his affiliation with UPRONA.

column11: FRODEBU: Front for Democracy in Burundi; MSD: Movement for Solidarity and Development; CNDD: National Council for Democracy and Development
column22: Agence France Presse; Xinhua General News Service
column23: Around a thousand opposition activists ( including activists of FRODEBU-Sahwanya and Nyakuri, MSD, CNDD, UPD, independents, and members of the CNDD-FDD) marched to protest a third term by President Nkurunziza, but police blocked their path and used tear gas and water cannons. Some protesters threw stones in response, and more than 100 were arrested.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Burundi has charged 65 protestors with rebellion after they were arrested during clashes with police while calling for the president not to seek re-election.

column8: MSD: Movement for Solidarity and Development
column23: Different events took place in Bujumbura: About 500 people engaged in a "prayer walk for peace" in downtown Bujumbura under heavy police escort, with one of the main groups involved being the National Women's Forum; a demonstration occurred, including activists of the MSD, in support of the people arrested in anti-government protests on apr.17.

column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column22: The New Times (Kigali); Radio France Internationale
column23: Reports that Imbonerakure militia members continue to harass and assault members of the Tutsi ethnic group and members of opposition political parties, causing at least 8,000 to flee to Rwanda and DRC.

column22: Radio France Internationale; Xinhua General News Service
column23: Students went on strike and more than 200 marched to protest two recent arrests of their compatriots on "Black Tuesday". Police were deployed and cleared the streets.

Throughout Bujumbura, hundreds protested against a third term for President Nkunruziza. Protesters injured police by throwing rocks and police responded with tear gas, water cannons, and live ammunition that led to several injuries and three deaths.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: The Burundian Army barricaded the road connecting to the border with Rwanda at the Bugarama crossing, blocking foreigners from entering and leaving hundreds stranded, mostly Rwandans.

column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: Although banned, protests against a third term for President Nkurunziza took place throughout Bujumbura , and police responded with tear gas and live ammunition. Three protesters died overnight in clashes with police and/or ruling party militia.
About 15 students had running battles with police and three were arrested while trying to protest a third term for President Nkurunziza.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse
column23: Leading human rights activist was arrested and injured during a police raid on the headquarters of a media association. He was released the following day with minor injuries.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Opposition protesters claim to have captured four Interahamwe operatives during protests in Bujumbura. All were handed over to the police and/or military.
Students tried to protest against a third term for President Nkurunziza, but they were dispersed and about 10 were arrested.

column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: Armed Imbonerakure youth reportedly attacked people in the streets on 5th, 6th and 7th avenues in the Kanyosha urban district of Bujumbura where protests started in the morning.
In a third day of protests against a third term for President Nkurunziza, protesters and police clashed with stones and tear gas. Military forces intervened to restore calm at intervals.

column22: Isanganiro Radio; Associated Press International; Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse
column23: Protests continue regarding the third term announcement from President Nkurunziza. Demonstrators and police alike set up barricades and continue to clash with one another throughout Bujumbura and at least nine were seriously injured, including several who were shot by police. One military personnel was killed by friendly fire. Nearly 600 people were arrested throughout the week.
Detainees from recent protests have reportedly been beaten in prison, causing minor injuries.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Xinhua General News Service
column23: A grenade attack at a police post in the center of Bujumbura wounded three to five policemen.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Xinhua General News Service
column23: An attack on a police post by five people using two grenades and an automated weapon in the Kamenge district of Bujumbura killed three people including two police officers and injured around 12 others.
Calm protests against a third term for President Nkurunziza were reported in Bujumbura.

Dozens of youths erected barricades around the center of Matana and demonstrated against a third term for President Nkurunziza. The police intervened to disperse them and at least one protester was injured by live ammunition.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: The ruling party's youth wing continue to intimidate and harass civilians in the north, causing a total of more than 50,000 to flee to neighboring countries. New reports indicate the armed group paints red marks on homes of families to be targeted.

column22: Radio Isanganiro website; Associated Press International
column23: Protesters clashed with police who shot live bullets and used hand grenades to disperse them in Nyakabiga, Cibitoke, Masaga, Buterere and Mutakura communes of Bujumbura, injuring over 30.

column22: Radio Isanganiro website; Associated Press International
column23: Protesters clashed with police who shot live bullets and used hand grenades to disperse them in Nyakabiga, Cibitoke, Masaga, Buterere and Mutakura communes of Bujumbura, injuring over 30.
In the Bujumbura neighborhood of Kinindo, police used live ammunition to disperse demonstrators that had barricaded the main road, injuring two.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Associated Press International
column23: In demonstrations in the Musaga neighborhood of Bujumbura, protesters clashed with police who used live ammunition and tear gas. Three protesters died from gunshot wounds and 45 more were injured. 15 policement were also injured when protesters fired a grenade.

column22: Radio Isanganiro website; Associated Press International
column23: Protesters clashed with police who shot live bullets and used hand grenades to disperse them in Nyakabiga, Cibitoke, Masaga, Buterere and Mutakura communes of Bujumbura, injuring over 30.

column22: Radio Isanganiro website; Associated Press International
column23: Protesters clashed with police who shot live bullets and used hand grenades to disperse them in Nyakabiga, Cibitoke, Buterere and Mutakura communes of Bujumbura, injuring over 30 total throughout the city.
Dozens of protesters reached Bujumbura city center and were dispered by police. Seven were arrested and beaten.
Three protesters were seriously injured when they were shot by police on the Ntahangwa Bridge.
In clashes with police who used tear gas and live ammunition, 15 protesters were injured throughout Bujumbura, particularly in Kigobe and Ngagara.
In clashes with police who used tear gas and live ammunition, 15 protesters were injured throughout Bujumbura, particularly in Kigobe and Ngagara.
Protesters recently arrested during clashes in Bujumbura were reportedly tortured in detention.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Police arrested opposition leader Audifax Ndabitoreye for "insurrection" as he attended a meeting of foreign ministers from the East African Community. He was released hours later.
Police fired shots into the air to disperse demonstrators who had been staging a sit-in.

column11: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: Multiple people were killed in clashes between protesters, police, and government supporters on May 7. At least two were shot by police, three were killed by a grenade fired by police, and another burned body was found (fatalities disaggregated across respective events).

column11: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: Police intervened in a clash between a small group of protesters and government supporters thought to be part of the ruling party's Imbonerakure militia in the Kinama district of Bujumbura. Police opened fire on the demonstrators, killing one and wounding three.

column11: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: Demonstrators burned alive a member of the Imbonerakure youth wing of the ruling party. Two others escaped the mob.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column10: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: Demonstrators in the Mutakura neighborhood arrested young men from the ruling party's youth wing who were carrying grenades. They were handed over to the military for investigation.
Protestors blocked one of the main streets in the Bujumbura neighborhood Kinindo.
Demonstrators barricaded the road in the Musaga neighborhood.
Demonstrators protested a third term bid by President Nkurunziza in the Bujumbura neighborhood Kanyosha.
Soldiers who were trying to move a shipping container that was being used as a barricade were forced to give up when faced with hostile youth.

column22: Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse
column23: Over 200 women protested in Bujumbura's city center against President Nkurunziza's third term, marking the first significant demonstration in the downtown area of the capital in recent weeks. Police and military were present, and police tried to stop them at certain points, but no violence was reported.
Young protesters had minor clashes with police in the Cibitoke neighborhood of Bujumbura as the authorities removed barricades erected over the past weeks.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Radio France Internationale
column23: A man was shot and killed in the Musaga area of Bujumbura as police and soliders used force to remove barricades.
Protests took place in several neighborhoods of Bujumbura, including Bwisa.
Protests took place in several neighborhoods of Bujumbura, including  Jabe.
Protests took place in several neighborhoods of Bujumbura, including Kanyosha where a car was set on fire.

Small groups of young men set up barricades in the Musaga neighborhood of Bujumbura and checked pedestrians and vehicles taking part in larger scale protests. Police and army soldiers negotiated with protesters to allow trucks to pass.
Protests took place in several neighborhoods of Bujumbura, including Nyakibiga.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Agence France Presse - English
column23: One protester was killed and three others were seriously injured when police opened fire on rioters who tried to prevent them from removing barricades. Protesters may have been trying to attack the home of a police officer and injured a policewoman.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Protesters burned two cars and a motorbike during ongoing demonstrations. Police used tear gas to break up the crowd of some 200 youths.

column10: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burundi (2005-)
column22: Xinhua General News Service; Associated Press International; Agence France Presse; Agence France Presse - English
column23: A group of soldiers "mutinied" and Major General Godefroid Niyombare publicly declared a coup d'etat, but President Nkurunziza claimed the government still had control and that loyalists within the military "fought off rival soldiers". After the coup declaration, police withdrew from the streets and protesters celebrated freely. A total of 12 mutineers were killed and 30 injured in the fighting over two days.

column10: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burundi (2005-)
column22: Agence France Presse - English; Xinhua General News Service
column23: Pro-coup forces took control of the airport and shut it down. A total of 12 mutineers were killed and 30 injured in the fighting over two days throughout Bujumbura.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Hundreds of pro-coup protesters besieged the state radio and TV building as police and government troops guarded it, firing warning shots in the air.

column22: Agence France Presse; Xinhua General News Service; Dalsan Radio; Isanganiro; Associated Press International
column23: Around 300 mostly female non-violent protesters demonstrated in downtown Bujumbura as police used tear gas and live ammunition against them. Soldiers were also present in the southern part of downtown.

column22: Dalsan Radio; Isanganiro; Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Thousands of protesters came out in the major streets of the capital and battled police while trying to enter downtown.   In the Buterere neighborhood, at least one was killed and several injured. A total of two civilians and one police officer were killed and 66 injured throughout Bujumbura.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Dalsan Radio; Isanganiro; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Thousands of protesters came out in the major streets of the capital and battled police while trying to enter downtown.  In Bwiza, police fired live shots at the crowds. A total of two civilians and one police officer were killed and 66 injured throughout Bujumbura.

column22: Dalsan Radio; Isanganiro; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Thousands of protesters came out in the major streets of the capital and battled police while trying to enter downtown.  In Musaga, grenade explosions were reported. A total of two civilians and one police officer were killed and 66 injured throughout Bujumbura.

column22: Dalsan Radio; Isanganiro; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Thousands of protesters came out in the major streets of the capital and battled police while trying to enter downtown. Police fired tear gas in Ngagara as the rioters randsacked the headquarters of the ruling party and set fires. A total of two civilians and one police officer were killed and 66 injured throughout Bujumbura.

column22: Dalsan Radio; Isanganiro; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Thousands of protesters came out in the major streets of the capital and battled police while trying to enter downtown.  In Saint-Michel Parish, police fired live ammunition. A total of two civilians and one police officer were killed and 66 injured throughout Bujumbura.

column10: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burundi (2005-)
column23: Pro-government troops regained control of the airport which was taken by pro-coup forces the previous day.

column10: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burundi (2005-)
column22: Agence France Presse - English; Xinhua General News Service
column23: Rival factions within the security forces clashed around the state television and radio complex, fighting intense battles until the pro-coup troops were repulsed. A total of 12 mutineers were killed and 30 injured in the fighting over two days. Anti-coup forces repelled a major attack by rival troops, leaving at least three dead. Gunfire and clashes were reported throughout the city and smoke could be seen on Bujumbura's skyline.  A total of 12 mutineers were killed and 30 injured in the fighting over two days.

column22: Voix du Burundi; Radio France Internationale
column23: 2 people were killed during the night by unidentified assailants, although some sources believe they were "agents of documentation and police". Their bodies were found tied up in a stream the next morning.
A young man was found dead in Marangara after local residents heard someone begging for their life during the night and then a grenade exploding.

Clashes erupted in Cibitoke province around Kiruhura and Kato (lat/longs not available) after an unidentified armed group attacked a military post on the edge of the Kibira forest. At least 8 attackers were killed while 1 soldier was wounded.
8 unidentified gunmen were ambushed and killed by soldiers as they came out of the Kibira forest. A soldier was also wounded in the fighting.

2 demonstrators opposed to Presdient Nkurunziza were wounded by police gunfire as they protested near a campaign rally by the CNDD-FDD in an area with many opponents of the current president. As tensions between the groups rose, police opened fire on the opposition demonstrators.

column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: A group of suspected Imbonerakure stormed the house of an Rwasa FNL acctivist who was having a drink with another supporter. Gunfire and grenade blasts were heard, resulting in one killed and another who died of his injuries.
A grenade went off near the city centre of Bujumbura. No casualties were reported but a car was damaged.

column11: MSD: Movement for Solidarity and Development
column22: Voix du Burundi (IWACU); Agence France Presse
column23: The vice president of the MSD in Gitega was found dead after gunfire was heard in the night between 4th and 5th Avenue in Nyakabiga III.
A police officer was killed in overnight violence and demonstrations during which gunfire and explosions were heard.
Youth in Nyakabiga protested, burned tires and blocked streets after the vice president of the MSD in Gitega was found dead in their neighbourhood. Police were present.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: The African Union has begun the deployment of military observers and human rights monitors in Burundi as vote counting in the presidential election began.
A Rwasa FNL member was killed when he was shot and had a grenade thrown at him as he left his home for a meeting.

Relatives and neighbours of an FNL member who was killed carried his body in a procession to the cemetary. Police attempted to prevent the "human tide" in their procession but were unable to stop them.

column11: CNDD-FDD: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy
column23: 4 people were injured, including 3 children, when a grenade was thrown at the house of a local head of the ruling party.
A Rwasa FNL supporter was killed during the night by unidentified assailants. The exact circumstances were not clear.

6 youths connected to the FNL were evicted from a house in Kamango in Ruyaga area and then arrested due to allegedly possessing weapons and being "part of a rebellion". Some of them were allegedly beaten.
Grenade blast killed one policeman in Bujumbura.  Another policeman injured.  Gunshots were heard right after the explosion.

column11: CNDD-FDD: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy
column23: Gunmen in military uniforms kill 2 members of CNDD-FDD in their homes in Ruvyagira, 25km southwest of Bujumbura.

column10: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: A member of the Imbonerakure was killed in the Musaga neighborhood of Bujumbura.
Journalist Esdras Ndikumana was arrested at the scene of the assassination of a top general in Bujumbura and was badly beaten by government security agents.

column11: CNDD: National Council for Democracy and Development
column22: Xinhua General News Service; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Former Intelligence Chief Adolphe Nshimirimana and his driver were killed when their car was hit by rockets and gunfire by unidentified men in military uniform in the Kamenge neighborhood of Bujumbura. 7 arrests were made relation to the attack and several others are sought by authorities. The vehicle used in the attack came from a Bujumbura military camp.
Vehicles were burned by unknown groups in the Musaga and Cibitoke neighhorhoods of Bujumbura.
Vehicles were burned by unknown groups in the Musaga and Cibitoke neighhorhoods of Bujumbura.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Associated Press International; Radio France Internationale
column23: Pierre Claver Mbonimpa, one of the organizers of recent protests in Bujumbura, was injured by two bullets from unknown gunmen as he was returning home in the Kinama neighborhood.

column11: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column23: A local ruling party official was assassinated in the Kanyosha district of Bujumbura.
A soldier was injured by gunfire while in pursuit of unidentified gunmen in vehicles in Bujumbura.

Two civilians were killed by police in the Cibitoke neighborhood of Bujumbura on either the 5th or 6th of August in what appeared to be a targeted killing using either live ammunition or grenades. The victims may have been DRC refugees.
Two bodies were found by passers-by in the Buterere neighborhood of Bujumbura, an opposition hotbed. Both bodies were bound by ropes and bore signs of torture.
Two grenades were launched in confrontations between police and unidentified assailants overnight in the Cibitoke neighborhood of Bujumbura.

Gunfire, detonations, and confrontations between police and "insurgents" were reported overnight in the Bujumbura neighborhood of Jabe, where 4 grenades were launched and 2 police were injured. The following day, police conducted home searches throughout Jabe.
Gunfire, detonations, and confrontations between police and "insurgents" were reported for two hours in the Bujumbura neighborhood of Nyakabiga, where at least one grenade was launched.
During a home search, police found a weapons cache and the local population responded by lynching the two perpetrators. Police tried unsuccessfully to stop the mob by firing in the air.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Since the beginning of the week, police conducted home raids in the Jabe, Musaga, and Mutakura neighborhoods of Bujumbura where they discovered two guns, one grenade, and other military effects.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Since the beginning of the week, police conducted home raids in the Jabe, Musaga, and Mutakura neighborhoods of Bujumbura where they discovered two guns, one grenade, and other military effects.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Since the beginning of the week, police conducted home raids in the Jabe, Musaga, and Mutakura neighborhoods of Bujumbura where they discovered two guns, one grenade, and other military effects.
Grenades were heard followed by gunfire in the Bwiza, Nyakabiga, and Cibitoke neighborhoods of Bujumbura.
Grenades were heard followed by gunfire in the Bwiza, Nyakabiga, and Cibitoke neighborhoods of Bujumbura.
Grenades were heard followed by gunfire in the Bwiza, Nyakabiga, and Cibitoke neighborhoods of Bujumbura.

column11: CNDD: National Council for Democracy and Development
column22: Agence France Presse; Rwanda News Agency; Xinhua News Agency - French
column23: A man and his wife were killed by gunfire or a grenade in the Kamenge area while returning home from a bar. The man was known to be a member of the ruling party, though he may have expressed opposition to a third term by President Nkurunziza.

column22: Agence France Presse; Xinhua News Agency - French
column23: One person was killed when a grenade was launched at their vehicle in the Kinindo neighborhood of Bujumbura.

column11: CNDD: National Council for Democracy and Development
column23: A member of the ruling party and his wife were killed in their car as they were on their way home in the Bujumbura Rural Province.

Retired head of Burundi's former primarily Tutsi army, Col. Jean Bikomagu, was killed when unidentified assailants opened fire on his car outside of his home in Kinindo. His daughter was also seriously injured.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Two grenades were thrown at a car in the Jabe neighborhood of Bujumbura. The driver and his children were able to escape as the car burned completely.
At least 8 people, including 2 or 3 police officers, were seriously injured when 1 or 2 unidentified assailants threw a grenade on a bridge in the Musaga neighborhood of Bujumbura.
A grenade attack injured four people while police conducted searches in the Musaga neighborhood of Bujumbura.

column11: CNDD-FDD: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy
column22: Associated Press International; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Four people were killed in a bar in the Musaga neighborhood as an apparent revenge killing. The victims were accused of supporting the ruling party and being police informers.
A military position was attacked, leaving one dead and several wounded.
A grenade was thrown at a bar targeting the husband of Senator Spès-Njebarikanuye Caritas, the first Vice President of the Senate. Two shopkeepers were seriously injured.
Army officer Philbert Niyonjuru was found dead - apparently bound and executed and wearing civilian clothes. Another dead body was also found in the Musaga neighborhood.
Shots were fired between unidentified individuals and the police in the Cibitoke neighborhood of Bujumbura as authorities searched homes and found weapons and military equipment.

column7: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column22: Radio France Internationale; Radio Publique Africaine
column23: The administrator of the Isale commune, who is a member of the FNL party, was killed when gunmen from the Imbonerakure opened fire on a bar. Several others were injured.
Police reportedly shot and killed a fisherman in Kibenga.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Gunshots were heard in the Mukike commune as police conducted home searches.
Unidentified gunmen attacked the home of protest organizer Richard Muyuku, killing him and injuring his wife and mother.
Unidentified men abducted a protest organizer and took him to an unknown location.
Jimmy Elvis Vyizigiro, a journalist working for France 24, was attacked in his home by masked intruders who beat him as they searched for documents he collected regarding flaws in recent elections.
One person died and several were injured when an army patrol team opened fire "for no apparent reason" on protesters in the Musaga neighborhood of Bujumbura.

column11: MSD: Movement for Solidarity and Development
column22: Agence France Presse - English; Rwanda News Agency
column23: Men in military uniform fired on a home in Musaga, killing two and injuring three. The victims may have been opposition activists.

column11: CNDD-FDD: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy
column23: An "influential member" of the CNDD-FDD was found dead in Ruyaga.

column11: MSD: Movement for Solidarity and Development
column23: Abel Nzambimana of the MSD party was killed and his wife was injured by gunfire and grenades targeting their home.

column22: Associated Press Internationale; Radio France Internationale
column23: Protesters threw stones at police who responded with gunfire and explosions. One person was killed in overnight clashes.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Radio France Internationale
column23: Two "insurgents" were killed in clashes with police.
One person was killed in overnight clashes with police.
Police and protesters clashed through the night.

column22: Associated Press Internationale; Radio France Internationale
column23: Mid-day clashes took place between protesters and police who circled the Musaga neighborhood to conduct searches.

Protests broke out overnight from the 2nd to 3rd and explosions and gunfire were heard between rioters and police in Cibitoke, Musaga, Mutakura, and Ngarara in Bujumbura.  Dozens were injured on both sides and dozens were arrested.

Protests broke out overnight from the 2nd to 3rd and explosions and gunfire were heard between rioters and police in Cibitoke, Musaga, Mutakura, and Ngarara in Bujumbura.  Dozens were injured on both sides and dozens were arrested.

Protests broke out overnight from the 2nd to 3rd and explosions and gunfire were heard between rioters and police in Cibitoke, Musaga, Mutakura, and Ngarara in Bujumbura.  Dozens were injured on both sides and dozens were arrested.

Protests broke out overnight from the 2nd to 3rd and explosions and gunfire were heard between rioters and police in Cibitoke, Musaga, Mutakura, and Ngarara in Bujumbura.  Dozens were injured on both sides and dozens were arrested.
Armed men in military clothing ambushed the public prosecutor hear his home in Ruyigi. Grenades and gunfire were heard; the prosecutor escaped unharmed, while his police body guard was injured.

column22: Radio France Internationale; Reporters Sans Frontieres
column23: Jean-Claude Ciza, a journalist who previously worked for a state broadcaster and now works with Radio France Internationale, was beaten with a steel bar by a police officer while covering events in the Musaga neighborhood of Bujumbura.
In clashes between gunmen and soldiers, one assailant was killed.

column11: UPD-Z: Union for Peace and Development (Zigamibanga Faction)
column22: Premium Times; Associated Press International; Radio France Internationale
column23: Patrice Gahungu, spokesman for the UPD-Zigamibanga party, was shot dead near his home. The victim had very recently won in a complaint to the UN Committee Against Torture, claiming he had been tortured by the state in 2010 and deserved compensation.

column11: CNDD-FDD: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy
column23: A total of four people were killed overnight in the Cibitoke and Kamenge neighborhoods in Bujumbura. This included a driver for the CNDD-FDD in Cibitoke.
A total of four people were killed overnight in the Cibitoke and Kamenge neighborhoods in Bujumbura.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Radio France Internationale
column23: Gunmen wearing military uniforms attacked a military camp in Kiyenzi. Two assailants were killed and three soldiers injured.
At least four people were seriously injured in a grenade explosion that targeted a household in the Kanyosha neighborhood in Bujumbura.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burundi (2005-)
column22: Xinhua General News Service; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Two assailants, three soldiers, and one civilian were killed in an ambush that targeted the convoy of Burundian Army Chief of Staff Major General Prime Niyongabo. Niyongabo escaped unharmed. The attackers are reportedly current soldiers in the Burundian army.
Shots and screams were heard overnight, and in the morning an unidentified body was found "assassinated" in the Cibitoke area.
A dead body was found packed in a bag in Buterere. He was likely strangled. This was the fourth murdered body found in the area in the last month.
A dead body was found in the river.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column22: Associated Press International; Radio France Internationale
column23: More than 100 men in the central province were arrested over two days by security forces claiming to prevent their recruitment into rebel forces.  The men were said to be moving in large numbers towards the south.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column22: Associated Press International; Radio France Internationale
column23: More than 30 men in the southern province were arrested by security forces claiming to prevent their recruitment into rebel forces.
Gunshots and explosions were heard overnight in Mutakura and police had the area completely blocked off by the following morning.

Police on patrol in Buterere were attacked by a grenade but escaped unharmed. Gunshots and explosions were heard in the area throughout Wednesday night and police had the area completely blocked off by the following morning.
4 bodies were found in freshly dug graves. They were tied up and difficult to identify.
One person was injured in a grenade attack in Kinyankonge.
A grenade was launched near the northern bus station in Kamenge but did not cause injuries. Three suspects were arrested.

15 bodies were found in various neighborhoods of Bujumbura during the week of Sept 23rd. Assassinated bodies are found almost daily in the city, many of them opposition members and activists. The perpetrators are unknown, though many residents point to state forces and Imbonerakure.

A pyrotechnic mortar bomb launched by an unidentified group associated with other bombings was luanched in Kiriri, damaging the fence of a house belonging to Jesuit priests. Two other bombs landed in Kiriri without causing any damage.
A pyrotechnic mortar bomb launched by an unidentified group associated with other bombings was thrown in Kavumu, damaging one home.
9 were injured in a grenade attack on a bar. 5 were later arrested for suspected involvement.

column11: MSD: Movement for Solidarity and Development
column23: The president of the MSD in Muramvya commune, Jean Baptiste Nsengiyumva, was assassinated in front of his house on Mubira hill by unidentified men using guns and grenades.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse
column23: Police killed two "insurgents" in clashes in the north of Bujumbura. Two police were injured, and two houses were burned in grenade attacks. The following morning, another 4 bodies were found in the same area.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse
column23: Violence between armed groups and the police in the Mutakura neighborhood of Bujumbura spilled over into Cibitoke, where 6 corpses were found the following day.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse
column23: Violence between armed groups and the police in the Mutakura neighborhood of Bujumbura spilled over into Kamenge, and Ngagara, where gunfire and grenades could be heard throughout the day.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse
column23: Violence between armed groups and the police in the Mutakura neighborhood of Bujumbura spilled over into Kamenge, and Ngagara, where gunfire and grenades could be heard throughout the day.
Coup leader General Cyrille Ndayirukiye was severely beaten and restrained by armed police in the Gitega prison.
Three youths were killed by police officers in the Mutakura neighborhood of Bujumbura. They were reportedly told to lie on the ground before being executed.  Police closed off roads in the area.
A dead body with the arms tied was found in Mutimbizi, and a second body was found nearby with bullet wounds. Potentially connected to recent killings in Bujumbura.

Unidentified men detonated grenades and opened fire inside a compound hosting a bar and a car transport agency, injuring one and destroying the property. The owner of the car agency is said to be Rwandan, which may be the motivation behind the attack.
A corpse potentially related to recent clashes was found in Ngagara in Bujumbura.
The son of Pierre-Claver Mbonimpa, a celebrate human rights activist, was assassinated when unknown assailants threw a grenade in his car in front of his home.

column10: Police Forces of Burundi (2005-) Institutional Protection Support
column22: Xinhua General News Service; Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse - English; UN News Service
column23: "Insurgents" kidnapped and executed 2 policemen who were conducting searches, which led to clashes with police. 9 civilians were killed, including a cameraman for the national television and an employee of IOM. Government claims they died "in crossfire" while others claim they were "executed" by police.
Gunshots and grenade explosions were heard as an unidentified group clashed with police. At least one was killed.

column11: MSD: Movement for Solidarity and Development
column23: MSD activist Charlotte Umugwaneza disappeared as she was leaving the Ngagara neighborhood. Her body was later found in the Gikoma River outside of Bujumbura, with signs that she had been assassinated.
At least 15 people, including 12 security personnel, were wounded in a clash with residents of Bamali while police attempted to receover firearms allegedly stolen from Bamali palace.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Radion France Internationale
column23: Boko Haram fighters attacked a bus on the Waza-Mora road, killing 11 passengers and injuring 6 others. The fighters then took the remaining passengers hostage and transported them away using the bus.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: "Cameroon has said it is recruiting 20,000 more defence and security forces to fight Boko Haram following reports that the terrorist group, based in Nigeria, is recruiting young Cameroonians to fight for them."
The Driving Schools Trade Union has gone on strike in protest against what they see as terrible management of traffic leading to many accidents.

Boko Haram fighters attacked a Cameroonian military base in Kolofata, killing 1 soldier. The Cameroonian military claims it killed 143 Boko Haram fighters and repulsed the attack at the military base and other strategic areas around the locality over 5 hours.
3 people were killed by Boko Haram fighters while traveling in a pick-up truck.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column22: Agence France Presse -- English; Agence France Presse
column23: Chad has deployed a large military force, including at least 400 vehicles and helicopters, to assist Nigeria and Cameroon in their fight against Boko Haram. The vehicles arrived in Kousseri on Jan.17.
Thousands of Cameroonians rallied in Kousseri in support of Chadian troops which arrived there to assist Cameroon and Nigeria in their fight against Boko Haram.

column22: Associated Press Internatioanl; Deutsche Welle; Agence France Presse - English; Radio France Internationale website
column23: Boko Haram attacked the Mayo Tsanaga district - including the villages of Maki, Maba and Mmokolo. They kidnapped up to 80 people in their largest kidnapping yet in Cameroon, burning houses and killing three.
Exposives buried by Boko Haram on the Fotokol - Kousseri road have recently killed an unspecified number of military personnel.
Exposives buried by Boko Haram on the Fotokol - Kousseri road have recently killed an unspecified number of civilians. Truckers and other civilians have almost entirely ceased using the road.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse
column23: Troops fought in "heavy clashes" with Boko Haram, leaving two Cameroonian soliders injured.
A few dozens marched to protest activities of Boko Haram and in favor of the Cameroon military.
Boko Haram attacked the Gnam-Gnam area, killing three villagers and burning houses.
Boko Haram attacked the Dola village to steal a horse, and villagers fought back with bows and arrows. Three locals and three militants were killed in the exchange.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Chadian troops took position in the strategic village of Fotokol as part of their efforts to counter Boko Haram.
Boko Haram fired rockets from Gambaru to Fotokol.
Boko Haram militants killed two elderly and two youth in Ashigashiya.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Xinhua News Agency - French
column23: Boko Haram attacked a Chadian army contingent near Fotokol. 3 soldiers were killed and 12 wounded, mostly by explosive devices, and 123 militants were killed according to the military.
Hundreds demonstrated in favor of national security forces who are fighting Boko Haram in the north.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Associated Press International; Xinhua General News Service
column23: 13 - 16 Chadian soldiers and 6 - 7 Cameroonian troops were killed in a counter-attack by Boko Haram in the northern town of Fotokol before they were able to repel the militants. At least 300 militants were killed in the fighting (Xinhua).

column22: Agence France Presse; Associated Press International; Xinhua General News Service
column23: Around 800 Boko Haram militants attacked the town of Fotokol, killing 81 civilians and setting fire to buildings before being repelled by regional forces. Up to 500 civilians were wounded
Thousands marched in support of the Cameroonian army which is confronting Boko Haram.
Nine Cameroonian soldiers were injured in an attack by Boko Haram.
Boko Haram hijacked a bus of 20 passengers in the north between Koza and Mora, killing 12 and incrementally releasing the other 8.
Boko Haram hijacked a bus near Koza, taking eight Cameroonian girls hostage and killing seven, whose bodies they scattered near the border with Nigeria.
Extremists from Boko Haram attacked the town of Kolofata, looting food and livestock.
Boko Haram hijacked a bus of 30 passengers in Tourou.

In ongoing clashes, Boko Haram attacked the positions of the Chadian military and Chad continued to reinforce its positions in Fotokol. 13 militants and one Chadian soldier were killed, several were wounded.
Police officers who were patrolling the coast by boat exchanged fire with seven Nigerian gunmen that led to the death of two policemen and the disappearance of a third.

A human rights group claims Cameroon's security forces have been using torture and illegal detention in the fight against Boko Haram in the far north. 50 people reportedly suffocated while locked in a cell and were buried in mass graves.

column10: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
column22: Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse
column23: 5 soldiers and 86 militants were killed in a series of clashes in the Waza region.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse
column23: Seven or eight villagers were killed when they fought back against Boko Haram fighters who stole 70 cows and torched houses in Gaboua. Nine of the militants were also killed by the villagers who were armed with clubs, machetes and bows and arrows.
2 Cameroonian soldiers and 12 civilians died as a result of IEDs on the Mora-Limani road set by Boko Haram.

column22: Agence France Presse -- English; Associated Press International
column23: Several thousand people, primarily youths, protested to denounce Boko Haram and its leader Abubakar Shekau.

Thousands of women marched to commemorate International Women's Day, show support for the country's fight against Boko Haram, and advocate for women's rights and security. Police and their wives marched alongside of them to assure security and support.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: 2,500 Chadian troops who were fighting Boko Haram in Nigeria crossed back over to the Cameroonian towns of Fotokol and Maltam.
Around 8,000 people marched against Boko Haram and to show solidarity with the security forces.

column22: Xinhua News Agency - French; Agence France Presse -- English; Associated Press International
column23: 16 people were kidnapped when a bus was seized near the CAR border at Babio by a heavily armed group believed to be made up of ex-Seleka rebels. Those kidnapped include four traditional leaders and the head of the Organization of Women of the Cameroon People's Democratic Movement (ORDPC). Some were later released, but reports conflicted over how many.

15 heavily armed men likely from a CAR rebel group tried to carry out a kidnapping of 8 civilians but locals attacked with guns and machetes, releasing the hostages, killing several militants and taking two captive. Some were wounded but final injury and death counts are unknown.
Boko Haram attacked Dabanga village and killed three civilians.

Boko Haram militants, the deadly Islamist sect, has attacked two villages - Bia and Blaberi - overnight in northern Cameroon. Most recent death toll indicates 19 people killed in the violence; many of the victims decapitated.

Boko Haram militants, the deadly Islamist sect, has killed no fewer than 10 people in overnight attacks on two villages in northern Cameroon. There were consecutive attacks by Boko Haram in Bia and Blaberi in the district of Kolofata in the early morning, the military reported.
Boko Haram fighters attacked a Cameroonian military position and burned down houses in Amchide but were repulsed without reported casualties.
An unidentified armed group attacked a market in the district of Bétaré Oya, taking hostages. Following a clash with the local population, the hostages were released.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse
column23: Farmers started a series of protests against the Socapalm multinational firm by occupying the Dibombari palm plantation.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Xinhua News Agency - French
column23: A Cameroonian soldier was killed and two others injured while on patrol in the far north when they were ambused by Boko Haram militants.
Boko Haram clashed with the Cameroonian military on a patrol near Zevelet, killing two soldiers, and injuring three soldiers and a civilian. The military returned fire, killing around 60 militants.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Cameroon sent military reinforcements to the border with Nigeria, near Maroua, in anticipation of further fighting with Boko Haram.
Women from 11 Protestant organizations marched for peace and against Boko Haram.
Health sector workers went on strike demanding that the ministry address at least 3 of their 16 points regarding health workers' labor conditions.
Two Cameroonian soldiers were killed and around 20 injured when Boko Haram attacked using grenades in the far north.
Boko Haram attacked Dabanga and Ngassa, stealing supplies and taking hostages. Two security personnel died and many were injured in pursuit of the militants.
Boko Haram attacked Dabanga and Ngassa, stealing supplies and taking hostages. Two security personnel died and many were injured in pursuit of the militants.
Hospital workers went on strike to demand better working conditions including new equipment, timely payment, and reduced corruption.
A strike was called by the Union of Professional Drivers of Cameroon (SCPC) on the Douala-Bangui corridor due to harassment and robberies by armed gangs in CAR.
100 students at the University of Maroua protested in tribute to a fellow student who was recently killed in a fight with a uniformed military man.

column22: Radio France Internationale; Xinhua News Agency - French
column23: Boko Haram attacked the village of Bodo in the extreme north but were repelled by military forces, who killed 3-24 militants.
Boko Haram clashed with a vigilante patrol in the Mayo-Sava department, leaving three vigilantes dead.

Twin suicide blasts killed at least 13 and injured 17 others, many of them soldiers, at a bar in the border town of Fotokol. The bombers were dressed in burqas and struck as locals were breaking their Ramadan fast. Of the 13 killed (all reportedly during the first blast at the bar), 1 was a Chadian soldier, while of those wounded at least 4 were Chadian soldiers and 3 were Cameroonian soldiers. Most of the soldiers were wounded in the second attack which hit as soldiers from a nearby special forces camp approached the bar after the first blast, although other reports say the second bomber headed straight for the military camp and there was a gunfight before the detonation. The attack were claimed by Boko Haram.

Twin suicide blasts killed at least 13 and injured 17 others, many of them soldiers, at a bar in the border town of Fotokol. The bombers were dressed in burqas and struck as locals were breaking their Ramadan fast. Of the 13 killed (all reportedly during the first blast at the bar), 1 was a Chadian soldier, while of those wounded at least 4 were Chadian soldiers and 3 were Cameroonian soldiers. Most of the soldiers were wounded in the second attack which hit as soldiers from a nearby special forces camp approached the bar after the first blast, although other reports say the second bomber headed straight for the military camp and there was a gunfight before the detonation. The attack were claimed by Boko Haram.

A suspected Boko Haram militant was killed during an attack on a Cameroonian military post in the locality of Ldaoutsas (lat/longs not available) in the Far North region. A civilian was also wounded in the attack.
Residents of Lobo district in Lekie set up a protest camp on the Yaounde-Douala highway to demand compensation related to the construction of the highway for their village which has not appeared.
More than 20 civilians were killed when more than 80 suspected Boko Haram fighters attacked the village of Kamouna near Lake Chad. 7 soldiers were present but they were overwhelmed by the attackers.
More than 20 people were killed when more than 80 suspected Boko Haram fighters attacked the village of Kamouna near Lake Chad. 7 soldiers were present but they were overwhelmed by the attackers.
The village of Kaforam was allegedly occupied by Boko Haram fighters.

column22: Associated Press International; BBC Monitoring Africa - Political
column23: At least 20 people were killed, including the perpetrators, after 2 allegedly female suicide bombers blew themselves up in a busy marketplace in Maroua. At least 32 people were wounded.

column22: Associated Press International; Radio France Internationale; Xinhua
column23: A suicide bomber attacked a popular night spot in the Pont Vert neighbourhood of Maroua, killing at least 21 civilians and injuring 67.
Boko Haram behead 3 people in Tchebe-Tchebe, and set fire to land.

column22: Agence France Presse; L'Oeil du Sahel; Xinhua
column23: Boko Haram set fire to police and military facilities in Afadé, killing one. Reports differ on whether the person killed was a gendarme or an inmate. 3 other inmates died in the fires. 4 soldiers and 3 policeman reportedly missing.

column22: Associated Press International; Agence France Presse - English; Radio France Internationale
column23: Boko Haram attacked the villages of Tchakarmari and Kangaleri in the far north (geo coordinates not available). They burned houses, killed at least 8, and kidnapped up to 145 civilians.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Military and police conducted home raids in the Douala neighborhood of Bonanloka in ongoing efforts against Boko Haram.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Military and police conducted home raids in the Yassa neighborhood in Douala in ongoing efforts against Boko Haram. Nearly 300 were detained for background checks.

column22: Associated Press International; Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Hundreds of Boko Haram fighters attacked Ashigashiya and Cameroonian troops responded, leaving 10 militants and 1 soldier dead and 2 soldiers injured. Some arrests were also made.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Police sealed off the weekly market in Maroua to conduct a security raid and identity checks.
When the military attempted to shut down the offices and studios of Afrique Media in Douala, protesters surrounded the building and prevented them from gaining access.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Refugees from CAR have reportedly been involved in frequent theft and hostage taking, prompting the Cameroonian police to initiative a wave of arrests of all CAR refugees found outside of predetermined humanitarian camps.
For a  second day in a row, protesters prevented the military from gaining access to the offices and studios of Afrique Media in Douala by surrounding the building.
Boko Haram attacked the village of Blame, torching homes and killing 8 civilians and 2 soldiers.
On the third day that protesters tried to prevent the military from gaining access to Afrique Media in Douala, soldiers used batons and tear gas to clear the crowd and seal the offices.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Authorities arrested journalist Simon Ateba who was investigating the conditions of Nigerian refugees in the far north. He was deatined for four days before being released.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse; Radio France Internationale
column23: At least 30 people were killed in the far north in successive suicide attacks in Keraoua - one in the marketplace and the second near a military camp. The suicide bombers were women; no group has claimed responsibility though preliminary blame is pointed at Boko Haram.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse; Radio France Internationale
column23: At least 30 people were killed in the far north in successive suicide attacks in Keraoua - one in the marketplace and the second near a military camp. The suicide bombers were women; no group has claimed responsibility though preliminary blame is pointed at Boko Haram.
Hundreds of angry passengers demonstrated in front of the Camair-Co office after their flights were repeatedly cancelled. They burned tires
Nearly 1000 soldiers marched to protest lack of payment for service as peacekeepers in CAR.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Radio France Internationale
column23: At least 9 were killed and 14 injured in twin suicide attacks by two teenage boys likely linked to Boko Haram. The attacks took place in the Latin Quarter and the main market of Kolofata.
The army pushed back an attack by Boko Haram, killing at least three.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: A suicide bomber with likely ties to Boko Haram was arrested with explosive devices before he could pull the trigger.
Boko Haram ambushed soldiers on patrol in Dabanga, killing two and burning two vehicles.
About 9 civilians were killed by suspected Boko Haram assailants who also burned several houses.

Two Boko Haram suicide bombers detonate 200 meters from each other in the market in Mora. Civilians were targeted. 5 killed, including an off-duty policeman, two civilians, and the two suicide bombers. 29 wounded.
Clashes between military and Boko Haram in Amchide. 2 Boko Haram killed on Sept 21.
Clashes between military and Boko Haram in Amchide for second day. 15 Boko Haram killed on Sept 22.
2 women suicide bombers of Boko Haram killed themselves and injured two farmers.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Xinhua News Agency - French
column23: Boko Haram killed 8 and kidnapped a young girl in an attack on a village in the Tika area. Over 100 houses were burned along with at least one vehicle, and several were injured.
Around 300 pro-government youth held a flashmob in central Yaounde to demonstrate patriotism and support for troops fighting Boko Haram.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column22: Xinhua General News Service; Xinhua News Agency - French
column23: Over 10 Boko Haram attacked the village of Siguel, near Bodo, setting it on fire. No victims were reported.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Xinhua News Agency - French
column23: After Boko Haram attacked the village of Siguel, they headed towards Bodo where a vigilante milita fought back and captured 5 militants.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column22: Xinhua General News Service; Xinhua News Agency - French
column23: In retaliation for arrests in Bodo, Boko Haram attacked the nearby village of Mafoufou, burning most of the homes.
Suspected Boko Haram gunmen launched rockets at two commercial trucks near Dabanga, injuring at least one.

column22: Associated Press International; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Twin suicide bombings by young women likely affiliated with Boko Haram killed at least 9 and wounded dozens in the town of Kangeleri, near Mora.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: Military Forces of the United States
column22: Associated Press International; Agence France Presse - English; Cameroon POSTline
column23: About 90 US troops were deployed to Cameroon to help stop the spread of Boko Haram. A total of 300 troops will eventually be deployed, meant to be armed for protection but not for combat.

column10: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
column23: Boko Haram ambushed a military vehicle, killing an officer from the Rapid Intervention Force and injuring three other soldiers.
Boko Haram raided Cameroonian territory near the village of Soueram in the Far Nort. Military response led to "heavy fighting".

column10: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
column23: Boko Haram ambushed military forces from the Rapid Intervention Battalion. Casualties unknown.
Boko Haram attacked Ashigashiya. Military response led to violent clashes.
A motorcyclist was killed and another was seriously injured when troops fired on them in an attempt to impose nightly travel restrictions.

column10: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
column22: Xinhua News Agency - French; Xinhua General News Service
column23: Angry at the recent death of a motorcyclist at the hands of the military, protestors clashed with the military and set fire to a military base. One soldier was injured and military equipment was damanged.
Boko Haram raided the village of Doulo, killing 8 and injuring 9.
Military responded to a Boko Haram raid on the town of Doulo, engaging in a gun battle with the militants. Casualties unknown.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Agence France Presse - English
column23: About 20 Boko Haram militants on motorcycles attacked Keraoua, killing at least 9 and kidnapping 20.
One day after attacking Keraoua and killing several civilians, Boko Haram "seized control of the town" as military forces were sent in for reinforcement.
The military retook control of Keraoua after Boko Haram took control earlier in the morning. Reports indicated that Boko Haram fled as additional troops arrived, and there was no continued fighting.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of Central African Republic (1993-2003)
column10: Military Forces of Central African Republic (1993-2003)
column11: MISAB: Inter-African Mission to Monitor the Bangui Accords
column23: The mutinous soldiers signed a truce with the army.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column22: Crisis Group Africa Report N°136, 13 December 2007
column23: France withdraws its troops from Bangui.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: MINURCA: United Nations Mission in the Central African Republic (1998-2000)
column22: Crisis Group Africa Report N°136, 13 December 2007
column23: UN withdraws its mission.

column7: Police Forces of Central African Republic (1993-2003)
column23: The Bambari police executes a recidivist wrongdoer.
A clash between students at the University of Bangui leaves six injured.
Public-sector unions start a three-day strike over pay arrears.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column22: United Nations Development Programme; UN Integrated Regional Information Networks
column23: Prime Minister launches national disarmament campaign.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Sudanese troops arrive in CAR paving the way for a peacekeeping mission.

column8: GEPPIC: Group of Publishers of the Private Independent Central African Press
column23: Press protest after a newspaper editor was accused and arrested.

column8: GEPPIC: Group of Publishers of the Private Independent Central African Press
column23: Reprsentatives of the national independent press protest in front of the Ministry of Communication.
Public-sector unions start an eight-day strike over pay arrears.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column22: UN Integrated Regional Information Networks; Agence France Press
column23: CAR Government and UNDP launch the disarmament, demobilisation and reintegration (DDR) process.

column7: Military Forces of Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column22: Agence France Press; Radio France Internationale; UN Integrated Regional Information Networks
column23: Clashes between government troops and unidentified armed groups.

column8: USTC: Labor Union of Central African Workers
column23: Teachers strike over Government pay arrears.

column7: Sangaris: French Mission in Central African Republic in Support of MISCA (2013-)
column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column23: Between December 2013 to June 2014, at least 10-12 children were reportedly sexually abused by French soldiers and AU peacekeepers at a camp for IDPs at M'Poko airport, according to an internal UN report.
A member of the ex-Seleka shot dead a man in his own home

Combo Bombo village, 37km from Amada-Gaza, was attacked by a group of armed Peuhls in retaliation for the theft of their cattle by Anti-Balaka elements, resulting in 7 deaths, the burning of several houses and the displacement of an unverified number of people who sought refuge in the bush.
At least eight people were killed in the villages of Bombo and Tanga in attacks by the Anti-Balaka.
At least eight people were killed in the villages of Bombo and Tanga in attacks by the Anti-Balaka.
Ex-Seleka and Fulani attack Mbali village, killing five.
In Kolo village, Anti-Balaka bury alive a woman and her child, as she had been accused of witchcraft by one of her husband's other wives.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Fulani herders set fire to Bomian village.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Fulani herders set fire to Gbanto village.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Fulani herders set fire to Ngoumbo village.
Ex-Seleka and Fulani attack Mengué village, 7km from Batangafo, killing one and injuring a number of others.

Five people were killed and several injured between 6th and 7th of January 2015 in clashes in Bambari between two Anti-Balaka groups. It is reported that the victims were, for the most part, Anti-Balaka.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Fulani herders set fire to homes in Boyo village, in revenge for a confrontation with Anti-Balaka.

Five people were killed and several injured between 6th and 7th of January 2015 in clashes in Bambari between two Anti-Balaka groups. It is reported that the victims were, for the most part, Anti-Balaka.
Following the clashes in Bambari, some Anti-Balaka went to the house of a local community leader and killed him, accusing him of betraying them. The attackers also burned his house.
Further clashes between two Anti-Balaka groups. One death reported.
Fulani herders attack health workers at Ndogoli village, 176km from Bouar, killing one and injuring others. One health worker remains missing as of 10th January 2015.
A hunter was shot and beaten to death by an unidentified armed group 30km from Obo.
Armed groups reportedly based in Cameroon attacked Boyango village, west of Koui (Ouham Pende Province). One person was killed and another injured, and houses were burned.

column11: Sangaris: French Mission in Central African Republic in Support of MISCA (2013-)
column23: Around 30 people were assaulted by armed Anti-Balaka. Sangaris intervened to stop the beatings.

In the village of Béboï 4, 38km from Paoua, a group of men beat to death a village leader who had just returned to the village, having been in Cameroon since 2013. They accused him of betraying them and being an accomplice of the ex-Seleka.
Teachers began a strike in Bangui to demand the payment of three months of salary arrears. The strike is due to end on 16th January 2014.
Staff of the Association of Muslims of Africa NGO protested outside their building to demand the payment of salary arrears. They blocked to entrance to prevent the head of the NGO from entering.
Sixteen people were killed in the village of Konga, in Kouango, by a group believed to be ex-Seleka. Several houses were also burned.
A hunter was shot dead and his body burned by a group of unidentified people. Witnesses claim that the attackers were Sudanese.

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: A firefight broke out between the Anti-Balaka and the Cameroonian contingent of MINUSCA, which resulted in MINUSCA arresting General Andjilo of the Anti-Balaka.

People protested in Berberati to express their anger against the Congolese contingent of MINUSCA, which they feel does not help prevent crime. This event followed the recent killing of a hunter by unidentified individuals.
Anti-Balaka protested the arrest of General Andjilo on the 18th and 19th January 2015 in Boy-Rabe. Several witnesses reported kidnapping attempts and robberies, and reports of one death on the 18th.
The brother of Pachomius Pabandji, a well known journalist, was beaten and kidnapped by unidentified men, close to where the Iraqi MINUSCA employee was taken.
Anti-Balaka protested the arrest of General Andjilo on the 18th and 19th January 2015 in Boy-Rabe. Several witnesses reported kidnapping attempts and robberies.

A female French aid worker who was working for the Catholic medical organisation CODIS was kidnapped alongside a local co-worker by the Anti-Balaka when they seized their vehicle. They were later released on 23/01/2014.

column10: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: A Spanish convoy of the EUFOR-RCA force exchanged fire with an armed man. The armed man was shot and injured.

column10: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: In a separate incident, a group of armed Muslims exchanged fire with a EUFOR-RCA patrol. One minor injury on the part of the armed Muslims reported.

column11: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: An Iraqi UN staff member who works for MINUSCA was kidnapped by the Anti-Balaka. She was released the following day.

column10: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: EUFOR-RCA revisit the scene of the confrontation in Kokoro for investigation. A rocket is fired at their convoy, causing them to fire warning shots. No casualties.
About 400 Muslims protested in Bangui to express their dissatisfaction at being excluded from the reconciliation process.

column22: Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; Associated Press International; Agence France Presse -- English; Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI); UN Integrated Regional Information Networks (Nairobi)
column23: The Minister of Youth and Sports (and former rebel chief) was kidnapped by armed men believed to be anti-Balaka militiamen as he came out of church. He was taken at a roadblock 10km outside of Bangui, and a number of vehicles were stolen at the same time.

column22: Associated Press International; Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI); UN Integrated Regional Information Networks (Nairobi)
column23: An 8 person team conducting public consultations ahead of the national peace and reconciliation forum were kidnapped by former Seleka fighters in Kaga Bandoro. The team included the regional prefect, one of his deputies and the town's mayor. They were released the next day, but their vehicle and other equipment were kept.
Former Seleka and armed Fulani attacked villages in the Nana Gribizi region, killing at least 5 and injuring others.

Muslim youths protested against the arrival of a consultation team. The youths looted the home of the Prefect of Ouaka and took a company car. Weapons fire was also heard, although no injuries were reported.
People demonstrated in support of the consultation team which arrived in Bambari, at the same time as a counter-protest against the consultations.

column22: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
column23: "9 people were killed in attacks by armed groups in Botto village (Nana Grebizi Province)."
Teachers began a strike to demand the government address their grievances.

column22: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
column23: 8 people were killed in an attack on Agoudou-manga village, and another 4 in Mbrobaga village, both near Bambari, encouraging residents from Bambari, Ngakobo and Kouango to flee.

column22: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
column23: 8 people were killed in an attack on Agoudou-manga village, and another 4 in Mbrobaga village, both near Bambari, encouraging residents from Bambari, Ngakobo and Kouango to flee.
28 people were kidnapped near Nzako. There were 9 unidentified men who attacked the people before capturing them and demanding a ransom.

column7: Sangaris: French Mission in Central African Republic in Support of MISCA (2013-)
column23: 4 vehicles carrying former Seleka rebels threatened a consultation delegation near Ndélé. An Operation Sangaris helicopter was sent to intercept the armed men and firing a warning shot and then destroying their vehicles after they had escaped. The son of the Kaga village leader was shot during the incident.
A protest march against the abduction of the Minister of Youth and Sports was held by various sports federations and youth associations.
An undentified group of youths killed a woman they believed was a witch. Police are seeking the suspects.
A pastor, his wife and 4 other residents of a village in the north of the country were abducted. All were released the next day except for the pastor.
Public sector students protested, demanding the government respect their right to education.
At least 3 people were killed and several others injured in attacks by armed Mbarara Fulani from the Kabo region on villages in the region of Kaga Bandoro.
A young girl was reportedly abused by Ugandan soldiers based in Obo.

column8: Sangaris: French Mission in Central African Republic in Support of MISCA (2013-), MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: Residents of Bambari marched to demand a return to normal for their city, and the departure of Seleka General Ali Darassa. Sangaris and MINUSCA forces were present to ensure the safety of those involved.

Around 100 young people armed with Kalashnikovs and knives gathered outside the Central Mosque IDP site and threatened to attack the displaced there following the death of one of their friends whom they accused the displaced of killing.
A man abducted by Fulani herders on 05/02/2015 was found dead near the Sali river outside of Batangafo.

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: Former Seleka fighters and armed pastoralists attacked the Ngakobo IDP site. UN peacekeepers secured the site and repelled the attack. 7 civilians were wounded during the fighting.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: A Burundian soldier was killed by "one of his comrades" in their lodgings at Bangui.

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: Former Seleka rebels attacked a sugar factory in Ngakobo where IDPs were seeking refuge, which is guarded by Congolese peacekeepers in Ngakobo. One of the attackers, a Fulani, was killed, while several other people were wounded. The attackers fired rockets at the sugar factory.

column11: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column22: Xinhua News Agency - French; Agence France Presse; Radio France Internationale
column23: 7 rebels were killed, 9 wounded, and 20 arrested in clashes between Seleka rebels of the PRGF and French/MINUSCA forces, including dozens of French vehicles and 4 helicopters. MINUSCA forces claim to have taken control of public buildings formerly controlled by Seleka forces.
At least 10 people were killed and 12 others injured in an attack on Boloum, near Batangafo, attributed to armed Fulani.
An old man was found dead near Bornu. Weapons fire was heard in the area the day before. Residents of the area believe former Seleka were behind the killing.

Parts of the Muslim community protested against the eviction of a Seleka officer who had been offering them protection by international forces. They set up "roadblocks that restricted the movement of more than 10 humanitarian vehicles."
Leaders of some political parties, including the AFDT, ACDP, CPAPs and UPPRN, and their supporters marched to call for peace and demand full implementation of UN Security Council resolutions.

During the night of Feb.14-15 and the next morning gunfire and grenades were heard going off in PK5, a predominantly Muslim neighbourhood, following the killing of a young Muslim the day before. 2 Muslims were killed during the violence.
A young Muslim was killed by armed men near the Prime Minister's office. Anti-Balaka forces suspected.
Armed Fulani attacked the village of Bolov, in the Batangafo area, killing a former anti-Balaka colonel and another man. MINUSCA elements were alerted and arrived at the village later.

During the night of Feb.14-15 and the next morning gunfire and grenades were heard going off in PK5, a predominantly Muslim neighbourhood, following the killing of a young Muslim the day before. 2 Muslims were killed during the violence.
Anti-Balaka militia fighters fired their weapons and temporarily blocked traffic during violent protests related to the killing of a young Muslim.

column22: Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI); Agence France Presse
column23: The killing of a young Muslim sparked violent protests in PK5, a predominantly Muslim area, including the closing of all shops. Demonstrators kidnapped 3 leaders of the Muslim community, who tried to calm them down before later releasing them.

column8: Anti-Balaka, MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: Anti-Balaka members protested against the occupation of the Court of Appeals by Muslims, leading to clashes which killed 3 young Muslims and injured 10 others, and killed 2 anti-Balaka and injured 2. International forces fired teargas to disperse the crowds, and cleared the building. The secretary-general of the Bambari young Muslims association says they were fired on by international forces.
At least 2 people, including the mayor, were killed and several wounded in an attack on "a village in northwest Central African Republic" by armed Fulani and former Seleka rebels.
