column10: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-) Gendarmerie
column23: Anti-Balaka gunmen held up some Bouca gendarmerie in the "4th District" and stole their vehicle.

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: A car which was discovered to have weapons in it broke down. Youths starting throwing stones at it and the occupants, which included a former Minister of Trade, before setting the car on fire. MINUSCA forces arrived to save the people on board, and fired tear gas to disperse the crowd.

The association of "Conscious Generation" and some human rights activists held a sit-in at the "UN rounadabout" to demand that international forces impose strict disarmament on armed groups in the country.
2 men were attacked by unidentified armed men believed to be attempted kidnappers. They both escaped but one of the men was wounded and later died at a health centre.
The National Organization of Disabled People Associations of Central African (ONAPHA) protested over the death of a visually impaired person in Batangafo recently.

Students protested at the University of Bangui to demand the payment of scholarships. They erected barrcades and threw projectiles. Traffic was disrupted for several hours on the Avenue des Martyrs and Kongowara Avenue. French forces dispersed the protesters using tear gas.

A man who allegedly bewitched people was killed by 4 unidentified attackers. Later that day, the parents of the victim killed one of the attackers, who allegedly had proof of his involvement on his person. One other person was killed in connection with these incidents via "mob justice" but the circumstances were unclear.

column7: AU-RTF: African Union-led Regional Task Force (2011-)
column23: 5 LRA rebels have been killed by the Uganda contigent of the AU-RTF in Quanda, near Mboki.

Two strikes started in Bangui: The Union of Central African Magistrates have begun a 3-day strike to demand the government provide sick pay and liability premiums; motorcycle taxi drivers also started a 3-day strike following the murder of a driver on Mar.1.

column11: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: 2 elderly women were buried alive by residents of Bouchia who accused them of witchcraft. Police attempted to intervene as residents of  Bouchia buried 2 women alive whom they accused of witchcraft, but the population attacked them and drove them off.

column7: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: 3 policemen were killed in an ambush near the village of Nguerengou by unidentified armed men. The policemn were reportedly unarmed.
After completing a 2-day strike earlier in the week, the Central Magistrates have announced they will be engaging in another 8-day strike to demand their grievances be addressed.
An ex-Seleka fighter was shot on his way to Bria when he refused an order by an ex-Seleka commander to disarm at the gate.
Thousands of women held a march for peace and national unity.
Women marched to protest violence against women and children and to demand respect for human rights, empowerment, and education.
Around one hundred women staged a sit-in outside the MINUSCA headquarters to demand the restoration of the Central African Republic Armed Forces (FACA).
Angry students who believed their teachers were stealing school supplies rioted and injured at least one teacher.
A farmer was shot and killed allegedly by armed Fulani herders after a dispute between the farmer and a herder.

Following a MINUSCA operation to dismantle illegal roadblocks, Anti-Balaka fighters came back to Kouloumadja village outside of Bangui, accused a man of being a traitor,  took his mother and brother hostage, then set fire to three houses.
Clashes were reported between armed groups in areas of Mambéré Kadéï, Nana-Grébizi, Nana-Mambéré, Ouham, and Sangha-Mbaéré provinces.
Clashes were reported between armed groups in areas of Mambéré Kadéï, Nana-Grébizi, Nana-Mambéré, Ouham, and Sangha-Mbaéré provinces.
Clashes were reported between armed groups in areas of Mambéré Kadéï, Nana-Grébizi, Nana-Mambéré, Ouham, and Sangha-Mbaéré provinces.
Clashes were reported between armed groups in areas of Mambéré Kadéï, Nana-Grébizi, Nana-Mambéré, Ouham, and Sangha-Mbaéré provinces.
Clashes were reported between armed groups in areas of Mambéré Kadéï, Nana-Grébizi, Nana-Mambéré, Ouham, and Sangha-Mbaéré provinces.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: France has begun a phased withdrawal of the soldiers participating in Operation Sangaris. So far total troop numbers have dropped from 2000 to 1700.

column22: Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI); Agence France Presse
column23: 10 people were killed, including 2 students, and several others injured when unidentified gunmen, allegedly from Chad, attacked the Ngaoundaye area.
At least 10 people, including two children, were killed and several others injured during an armed-group attack in Nganoundaye, a few kilometres from the Chadian border

column7: Sangaris: French Mission in Central African Republic in Support of MISCA (2013-)
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column22: Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI); Agence France Presse
column23: French forces responded to violence by armed individuals in the Boy Rabe neighbourhood of Bangui. They came under small arms and grenade attacks. MINUSCA and Central African Republic police forces joined French forces in dealing with the violence. At least 3 students and 1 French soldier were wounded during the fighting.
A state-certified nurse who had been seeking refuge in an IDP site was killed by alleged Anti-Balaka fighters.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: EUMAM: European Union's Military Advisory Mission in the Central African Republic (2015-)
column22: Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; Associated Press International
column23: The EUFOR-RCA force has withdrawn from the Central African Republic and been replaced by a training and advisory mission called EUMAM (European Union's Military Advisory Mission in the Central African Republic).
Nursing staff colleagues of a man who was allegedly killed by Anti-Balaka fighters began a 72-hour strike to protest his murder.

At least 11 people were killed by a group of heavily armed Muslim herders after their cattle were allegedly stolen. They attacked villages in the Kaga-Bandoro area, resulting in residents vacating at least 9 villages and their residents seeking refuge in Kaga-Bandoro.

3 people were killed and several others injured after a photographer who was allegedly drunk dropped a grenade in the middle of a meeting of five evangelical churches after they took away his camera. He attempted to flee but was captured by a group of young people who beat him to death.

3 people were killed and several others injured after a photographer who was allegedly drunk dropped a grenade in the middle of a meeting of five evangelical churches after they took away his camera. He attempted to flee but was captured by a group of young people who beat him to death.
Protests occurred during/related to the meeting of five evangelical churches. This meeting was later the target of a grenade attack after a photographer was prevented from taking pictures.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: A powerful anti-Balaka chief named Wilikondji, a.k.a. Songolè, accused of "serious crimes" was arrested by National Police forces.

Between 9-12 Fulani herders were killed, at least 4 injured, and 50 others kidnapped by anti-Balaka fighters in attacks on 4 villages near Kaga Bandoro, allegedly in response to attacks carried out by Fulani during the weekend of Mar.21-22. Several herds of cattle were also stolen.
Young Muslims and Christians from Bangui's 3rd arrondisement organized a peaceful march to demand the release of former Minister and ex-Seleka member Ousman Mahamat Ousman.
Chadian soldiers have raided a village in Ngaoundaye and kidnapped 4 women and 2 men as a reprisal for a recent attack by the CAR rebel group Revolution and Justice (RJ).
Two rival factions of former Seleka rebels battled for control of a customs post in Bema, 900km east of Bangui, leading residents to take refuge in the DR-Congo.
The Mayor of Kabo called for a general strike, which was followed by a march in support of Médecins Sans Frontières, following a number of robberies in the town targeting MSF.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: The Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka groups have signed a peace agreement to stop hostilities and commit to political stability.

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column22: Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; UN News Service
column23: Following the arrest of 2 suspected criminals who are Muslims in the Bornu 5 area of Bangui, a group of Fulani Muslims asked for their release. MINUSCA forces attempted to intervene to ease tensions. A violent confortation followed leading to 30 injuries, damage to the vehicles of the convoy (broken windows), and unconfirmed reports of a death.
Rioters angry over the arrest of 2 suspected criminals who are Fulani Muslims who had attacked a MINUSCA convoy earlier in the day proceeded to burn down at least a dozen houses.

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column22: Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI); Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; UN News Service; Reliefweb
column23: Around 400 residents of Kaga Bandoro armed with knives and other weapons attacked the MINUSCA base during protests to demand protection from armed Fulani who have recently attacked nearby villages. Gunfire was exchanged outside the base, while demonstrators threw stones and other objects at MINSUCA peacekeepers and attempted to set the camp on fire. Warning shots were fired by the peacekeepers. At least one protester was killed, and more than 12 people were wounded. Some reports have the number as high as 3.
LRA fighters took a hunter hostage in the Obo area but he managed to escape.

column8: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: Police in the capital have gone on strike over "non-consideration of their special status" in relation to their advancement/promotions, impeding the functioning of the Ministry of Public Security and the General Police Directorate.
A young man was attacked and shot by armed Fulani herders in the village of Kangamon 1, 17km outside of Batangafo.

A group of young people beat a young Fulani Muslim to death whom they accused of setting a fire which led to the death of 2 children at an IDP site near Bambari. Other reports say the fire was started by the children.
Refugees from the DR-Congo staged a peaceful march to denounce their poor living conditions and demand the UNHCR take charge of them and their security guaranteed.

column8: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: Police in the capital have renewed their strike and staged a demonstration in the capital.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: A march calling for freedom of mobility and goods and social cohesion was organized by the NGO Search for Common Ground. The marchers walked from Independence Avenue to Koudoukou Avenue. MINUSCA and gednarmerie forces kept watch over the march.

A vehicle holding 8 passengers was fired on by unidentified armed assailants. Most of the passengers escaped but one man was taken hostage, and their goods were stolen. The vehicle was then set on fire.
5 people were killed by Fulani herders after livestock was killed by farmers.
10 farmers were killed in 4 villages around the town of Kaga Bandoro by Fulani pastoralists armed with guns.

column8: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: Police have engaged in a demonstration related to their strike to protest against inaction by the government to resolve their demands.
The Coordination of Central African Muslim Organizations (COMUC) organized a peaceful march in the KM5 area of Bangui to demand more representation and respect for their rights.

column7: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column23: 1 person was killed and several were wounded in an attack allegedly carried out by FDPC rebels in which they opened indiscriminate fire on a bus in the Baboua area, traveling from Garoua-Mboulaï to Bouar and Bangui.

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column22: Radio France Internationale; Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI)
column23: After the end of the Bangui Forum, what started as peaceful protests to demand the release of an anti-Balaka leader and the resignation of the president turned into riots as angry anti-Balaka leaders felt their demands were not being taken into account. Gunfire was heard, grenades went off, and barricades were raised, while MINUSCA forces responded with tear gas. Some witnesses reported anti-Balaka and former Seleka protesting together.

Several hundreds people, some in military uniforms, erected barricades to protest against the decisions of the Bangui Forum. The protesters blocked traffic with burning tires but were dispersed peacefully by police. They were allegedly largely composed of anti-Balaka members but anti-Balaka leadership said they did not condone the protests.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: As many as 357 child soldiers were released by a combination of Christian and Muslim armed groups at 3 ceremonies in the town of Bambari.

column7: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column23: Gunmen allegedly affiliated with the FDPC attacked public transport vehicles traveling from Gara to Mboulai and robbed the occupants, and shot a motorcyclist, injuring him. It was not clear if any deaths resulted. The head of the FDPC says their group does not recognize the forum in Bangui.

1 person was killed when unidentified gunmen opened fire on residents of a mine site outside the town of Nzacko. They then went on to another site and assaulted more people, before stealing food and property.

After being expelled from adminsitrative buildings in Bria, former Seleka rebels have occupied active mining sites, including Carefree, Dawango, Kalaka, Aigbando, Mouka, and Ngbehidou Town near Bria, and demand tolls to allow entrance by miners.

After being expelled from adminsitrative buildings in Bria, former Seleka rebels have occupied active mining sites, including Carefree, Dawango, Kalaka, Aigbando, Mouka, and Ngbehidou Town near Bria, and demand tolls to allow entrance by miners.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Amnesty International visited 12 towns and villages in western CAR in May living without the protection of UN troops and found many Muslims were being forced to convert to Christianity by anti-Balaka militias.
As many as 12 people were abducted and at least 10 of those abducted were killed from a village between Bouca and Maraze Kozoro.
Armed Fulani allegedly from Lolo village in Cameroon attacked villages in the Gamboula area, including Koko where they were fought off by a self-defense group.

Armed Fulani allegedly from Lolo village in Cameroon attacked villages in the Gamboula area, including Saheri, Gbombo and Gadawa. At least 20 people were injured and others killed in the attack on Gbombo. Deaths were also reported during the other attacks (collectively coded as 10), houses were burned and at least 100 people were displaced in the violence.

5 young traders were attacked by armed Fulani herders outside of Kaga-Bandoro as they were returning from Baziki, with one of the traders being beaten by the gunmen before the rest abandoned their goods and bikes and fled.

column22: Radio France Internationale; Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI)
column23: A gunfight broke out between men on a motorcycle and unidentified assailants near the UN HQ in the PK5 area. At least one person, the nephew of an influentiel former Seleka leader, was injured. Two people were reportedly killed during the gun battle and subsequent riot.

column10: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column22: Radio France Internationale; Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI)
column23: Following a gunfight which broke out near the MINUSCA HQ, some angry Muslim youths gathered in front of a police station and demanded the police take a person injured in the clash to the hospital. The crowd threatened the police with knives and grenades before stealing a car, using it to transport the injured person, burning it, and returning to ransack the police station. Two people were reportedly killed during the gun battle and subsequent riot.

column22: Radio France Internationale; Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI)
column23: Following the murder of a Muslim shopkeeper on May 27 by unidentified assailants, some armed Muslim youths killed a young girl in retaliation.

column22: Radio France Internationale; Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI)
column23: A Muslim shopkeeper on May 27 by unidentified assailants.

column7: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column23: 1 person was killed and 4 wounded in an attack allegedly by FDPC rebels 18 km from Baboua on the Baboua-Garoua-Mboulaï axis. Unconfirmed sources say that they attacked a Cameroonian MINUSCA vehicle, while others say it was a passenger motorcycle.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: MINUSCA has officially started its DDRR operatons in CAR in cooperation with the government of CAR and armed groups.
Butchers in Ndele have gone on strike due to harassment they've faced over rising prices and insecurity.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: A Burundian MINUSCA contingent and Anti-Balaka forces reportedly engaged in a heavy exchange of gunfire in the 4th District (Boganda) area of Bangui near a high school after an allege failed arrest of a Anti-Balaka leader in the area. 2 peacekeepers were injured along with as many as 40 high school students who were caught in the crossfire. The MINUSCA forces claimed that the Anti-Balaka gunmen used the students as human shields.
2 young men were killed by suspected armed herders in Dewili (exact location not available), near Kabo.
An accused thief was captured and tortured by young people before dying of his injuries.
To mark Father's Day, men in Damara marched for peace and social cohesion, ending in the central market.
A young boy was assaulted by armed Fulani outside Kabo, 3km outside the village of Tago (lat/longs not available).

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column11: Military Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: National and international forces launched an "aggressive operation" against gunmen camped near Zoukombo who have ambushed commercial vehicles and attacked villagers in the Baboua area. 6 civilian hostages killed (circumstances unclear) and one released, one person arrested, and livestock recovered during the operation.
Unidentified gunmen interrupted a ceremony to officially launch the entry of electoral lists by assaulting the deputy mayor, causing other officials to disperse to prevent further violence.
More than 500 merchants in the KM5 district protested against the municipalities decision not to relocate them.
2 people were kidnapped by 6 unidentified gunmen with AK47s and military uniforms in Kabo. One was later released after a ransom was paid.
2 people were killed and 4 wounded when unidentified gunmen opened fire on a car in the village of Foro. The reason for the attack is not clear but nothing was reported stolen.
State officials/employees protested over grievances related to sub-prefecturals elections and the alleged failure to keep records.

column10: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-) Gendarmerie
column22: Associated Press International; Agence France Presse -- English; BBC Monitoring Afria - Political
column23: Between 6-12 unidentified gunmen, some of whom were disguised as UN peacekeepers, surrounded the state radio station but were repelled by forces of the national gendarme. At least one member of the security forces was injured.

A man from the Yabera neighbourhood of Bozoum was kidnapped and tortured for 3 days by youths who accused him of putting an enchantment on their little sister. He later died of his injuries in hospital.
Patients in the hospital and university centre of Bangui protested against the departure of MSF.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: MINUSCA peacekeepers arrested 4 individuals during security operations and allegedly used excessive force, resulting in the deaths of 2 of the individuals and a third taken to the hospital (specific location of the incident not given). The peacekeepers involved, 20 in all, were repatriated to their home country.
2 Fulani herders on their way from Mboki to Obo were attacked and robbed by LRA rebels.
Gunmen believed to be Chadian soldiers attacked the Kota Gbangoro area, killing one civilian and causing "enormous material damage".

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: A convoy of WFP supplies escorted by MINUSCA peacekeepers was attacked, resulting in the death of one of the drivers and injured others.

column11: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: The mayor and deputy prefect of Baboua were taken hostage by unidentified gunmen. Other people were also kidnapped but they were released.
A CAR drivers' union (USCC) has gone on strike following assaults on several drivers on the Bangui-Garou Boulai road by armed gangs.
Enumerators protested for 2 days to demand that the government pay their training cost and give them access to vehicles.
Enumerators protested for 2 days to demand that the government pay their training cost and give them access to vehicles.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column10: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column23: The head of the FDPC says that Boko Haram is operating in western CAR, including around Bouar, Baroua-Boulai, and Baboua, and that attacks attributed to the FDPC have actually been carried out by Boko Haram or armed Fulani. This report is unconfirmed.
3 traders were kidnapped in the Nzako area, allegedly by LRA members.
Taxi and bus drivers went on strike against the actions of "enforcement officers" including perceived extortion.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Former Seleka militia members from Kaga-Bandoro have created a new political party, the Patriotic Movement for Central (MPC) which has committed itself to peace and the democratic process.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column22: Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; Agence France Presse
column23: A group of unidentified gunmen opened fire on a Bangladeshi MINUSCA patrol in Diba, near Baboua. At least 2 MINUSCA peacekeepers were injured.

column11: Military Forces of the United States
column23: A man was kidnapped by armed men believed to be ex-Seleka rebels. The man was allegedly kidnapped as he was considered a traitor for working at the US army base in Sam-Ouandja.
2 people vandalized an election registration centre in a kindergarten in Bozoum.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: At least 1 MINUSCA peacekeeper was killed and several others wounded in fighting which erupted when the peacekeepers, backed by CAR police, attempted to arrest an unidentified faction leader in PK5.

column7: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-) Gendarmerie
column23: A constable of the gendarme was killed at his house in Bria by unidentified gunmen who stole his weapon.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: According to testimonies collected by Amnesty International, a MINUSCA peacekeeper allegedly raped a young girl during operations in PK5.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column22: Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse
column23: 4 ex-Seleka militiamen and 1 Cameroonian MINUSCA peacekeeper were killed in a clash in the KM5 neighbourhood of Bangui as the peacekeepers attempted to arrest a former Seleka rebel commander. 8 other people were wounded according to MSF.

column22: Agence France Presse; Agence France Presse -- English; Radio France Internationale
column23: Between Aug.2-3, 4 people were killed and 4 injured in attacks by anti-Balaka on Malegbassa village, inhabited by Fulani herders, where they looted cattle.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: According to testimonies collected by Amnesty International, MINUSCA soldiers allegedly shot 2 civilians, one of whom died on the spot while the other died of their injuries in hospital.

column22: Agence France Presse; Agence France Presse -- English; Radio France Internationale
column23: Between Aug.2-3, 4 people were killed and 4 injured in attacks by anti-Balaka on Malegbassa village, inhabited by Fulani herders, where they looted cattle.

column22: Agence France Presse; Agence France Presse -- English; Radio France Internationale
column23: In retaliation for an attack on their camp the day before, former Seleka members and Fulani herders attacked Ndoma village, neighbouring Malegbassa, leaving 8 dead and more wounded. They allegedly also took prisoners.
A man who allegedly stole a solar panel was beaten by people who caught him, and later died in the hospital.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: Three young females report that UN peacekeepers from DRC raped them in early August.
Former Seleka gunmen tortured a student in Bino, a village on the Batangafo-Bouca axis, after attempting to rob him.
About 60 people were taken hostage by suspected LRA members from the village of Mbari, although 45 later escaped.
4 people were taken hostage by LRA gunmen from Kpokpo village in the Yalinga area.
LRA members kidnapped one man while he was on his way from the "kpo-kpo site" while he was on his way to Bria.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column22: Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; Agence France Presse -- English
column23: A Rwandan soldier of MINUSCA opened fire on his colleagues, killing 4 other Rwandan soldiers, in their base in Bangui. He was also killed during the gunfight while 8 other soldiers were wounded. The reason behind the shooting was unclear.
The village of Badibiri in Obo was raided by LRA fighters. The townspeople fired warning shots into the air to scare the rebels away, but a youth was shot by the rebels during the incident.

column11: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: At least 18 prisoners escaped from a central prison in Ngaragba after taking weapons from the guards. Most of the criminals are suspected to be former members of armed groups. The prson was also protected by international forces.

column22: Cameroon Tribune; Voice of America; Radio France Internationale
column23: Truck drivers along the Douala-Bangui Corridor went on strike, siting security concerns. The strike lasted 10 days until an agreement was reached that soldiers from Cameroon, Gabon, and Congo will henceforth accompany the trucks on the route.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: The secretary-general of the Kwa Na Kwa party of Francois Bozize was arrested as he was about to board a plane for Paris, allegedly related to charges of "inciting disorder".
Election officials in the Bimbo area protested outside the National Authority of Elections headquarters to demand payment of their registration fees.

AFP has reported that a "cattle war" is ongoing in CAR, with violence including the killing and looting of livestock, kidnapping of breeders, and killings and rapes occurring in the western regions, primarily targeted members of the Mbororo ethnic group (fatalities coded as 10).
Anti-balaka reportedly killed a young Muslim man.

Bertan Bea, the former Secretary General to ex-President Francois Bea who was arrested on the 15th, was liberated by militants who attacked the court in Bangui. Military and MINUSCA forces around the court reportedly did not fight back.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Radio France Internationale
column23: A total of ten people were killed and five injured in religious clashes between Anti-balaka and Seleka rebels plus non-Seleka Muslims after a young Muslim was killed by Christians the day before. Volunteers from the Red Cross, both local and international, were also attacked and injured with knives during the clashes.

column11: ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent
column23: Red Cross officials and CAR citizens are attacked by Muslim youth while trying to attend to the injured during communal violence between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka fighters.

column22: Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse - English
column23: In continued clashes in Bambari, an additional 10 people were killed over the weekend.

column22: Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse - English
column23: In continued clashes in Bambari, an additional 10 people were killed over the weekend.

column22: Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Gunshots and explosions were heard in Bambari as part of ongoing intercommunal clashes.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: At least 5 people were killed and 8 injured in intercommunal clashes between Fulani and Anti-Balaka in the Bria mining community. UN forces intervened to help stop the violence.
Ex-Seleka militiamen clashed wth anti-Balaka in Bambari, causing deaths and forcing people to flee the town (fatalities coded as 10).
2 people were killed and another died of his injuries in hospital after an attack by suspected armed Fulani herders on Bougourou village.
A woman accused of witchcraft was killed by youths in Yamondo village, located 20km from Sibut.
Some anti-Balaka youth allegedly robbed a shop and killed the owner when he attempted to pursue them.
An unidentified armed group accused of creating insecurity in the Bakouma area opened fire on passers-by at the Ndeguilo-Bakouma-Bangassou axis. No specific casualties were reported.

column22: Thomas Reuters Foundation; Associated Press International
column23: A charity network has reported that former Seleka rebels and anti-Balaka forces have been attacking and looting schools, with as many as 73% of schools in the Kemo district in the centre of the country and 51% in the Bangui area affected.

column22: Thomas Reuters Foundation; Associated Press International
column23: A charity network has reported that former Seleka rebels and anti-Balaka forces have been attacking and looting schools, with as many as 73% of schools in the Kemo district in the centre of the country and 51% in the Bangui area affected.

column22: Thomas Reuters Foundation; Associated Press International
column23: A charity network has reported that former Seleka rebels and anti-Balaka forces have been attacking and looting schools, with as many as 73% of schools in the Kemo district in the centre of the country and 51% in the Bangui area affected.

column22: Thomas Reuters Foundation; Associated Press International
column23: A charity network has reported that former Seleka rebels and anti-Balaka forces have been attacking and looting schools, with as many as 73% of schools in the Kemo district in the centre of the country and 51% in the Bangui area affected.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: 4 suspected anti-Balaka members attacked and looted a vehicle of the NGO JUPEDEC, causing no injuries.
Ex-Seleka militiamen and anti-Balaka forces clashed in Bambari, after anti-Balaka allegedly attempted to steal a  motorcycle from a young Muslim. No casualties were reported.
At least 1,800 new refugees were displaced to the DR-Congo following clashes in the Mobayi-Banga area of CAR between anti-Balaka and Seleka forces.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: MINUSCA has declared Bambari a weapons-free zone after rival militias clashed in the area.
"An agent of the Town Hall was found dead" in the Boukako area of Bambari. It is not clear under what circumstances the municipal worker was killed.
Residents of Bangui's 2nd district protested against power outages which have allegedly been ongoing for 3 weeks.
A group of unidentified armed men invaded invaded a village near Gbodoro, 12km from Bakouma, and stole property and money from the villagers. They also beat them before leaving.
Following grenade attacks in Bangui's 6th district by allegedly Muslim youths on motorcycles, youths in the area erected roadblocks to block the movement of traffic and protest against the attacks.

At least 2 people were killed and 22 injured in grenade attacks by unidentified allegedly Muslim youths in Bangui's 6th district. The attacks involved at least 2 grenades, at least one of which was thrown at the Air Force One bar, and another near a church in the Fatima area.
A group of unidentified armed men took about 50 villagers in Gbodoro, located 12km away from Bakouma, hostage and stole their food and money before leaving their village.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column22: Agence France Presse; Radio France Internationale
column23: Rwandan MINUSCA forces were ambushed in the 4th district of Bangui by unidentified assailants armed with heavy weapons which caused "extensive damage" to their armoured vehicles. No casualties were reported.
Residents of Bangui's 6th district engaged in a peaceful march to protest against a grenade attack which occurred on Sept.9.

An unidentified armed group attacked the village of Kpabou near Mboki, killing 3 people and attacking and robbing a motorcycle driver. According to the man who was robbed, the armed men also wore turbans and spoke in Arabic.

column7: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: 11 striking health workers of Bimbo hospital were arrested during ongoing strike action.

column10: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: Anti-Balaka protesters took to the streets and erected roadblocks to stop traffic in the 4th district of Bangui. It was not clear why they were protesting, but some sources say it had to do with the resignation of the transitional head of state. They also raided the local gendarmie headquarters and released those being held there.

column10: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: One person was killed and another wounded in a clash between anti-Balaka elements and local police in the Kounde area. The fight appeared to grow out of a threat an anti-Balaka member made to a policeman's wife.
The Youth Association Gobongo (AJG) organized a peace march in the 8th district of Bangui to condemn violence and the erection of barricades in Gobongo market.

column10: Sangaris: French Mission in Central African Republic in Support of MISCA (2013-)
column11: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column22: Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI); Agence France Presse -- English; Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; Radio France Internationale
column23: At least 24 people were killed and over 100 injured during riots following the killing of a Muslim motorcycle taxi driver. The initial violence saw Muslims (including ex-Seleka members) attacking a Christian neighbourhood (which included Anti-Balak members) in retaliation for the killing, until international forces (French/UN) intervened to end the violence. Shops and houses were also allegedly burned, and St. Michael's Parish was looted.

column22: Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI); Agence France Presse -- English; Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; Radio France Internationale
column23: At least 24 people were killed and over 100 injured during riots following the killing of a Muslim motorcycle taxi driver. The initial violence saw Muslims (including ex-Seleka members) attacking a Christian neighbourhood (which included Anti-Balaka members) in retaliation for the killing, until international forces (French/UN) intervened to end the violence. Shops and houses were also allegedly burned, and St. Michael's Parish was looted.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: More than a dozen international and national NGOs were looted during violence in Bangui between Sept.26-28.
A Muslim motorcycle taxi driver was killed by alleged anti-Balaka attackers in the PK5 district of Bangui, sparking renewed violence in the city.

Anti-Balaka militiamen retaliated against attacks on a Christian neighbourhood by Muslims (including ex-Seleka) from PK5. Gunfire was heard between the two neighbourhoods. 36 people were said to have died in all between Sept.26-27 (24 were coded in previous events).

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column22: Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; Radio France Internationale; Associated Press International
column23: The offices of various humanitarian organizations, including IOM, Mercy Corps, Cordaid, Premiere Urgence, the French Red Cross and War Child were looted by anti-Balaka militiamen and local residents during violence in Bangui between Sept.27-28 (unconfirmed reports also said WFP offices were targeted).

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: The government of CAR has put in place a curfew in Bangui due to the recent violence which has hit the city.

A civil society movement dedicated to re-establishing the Central African Armed Forces and restoring peace to CAR organized a demonstration at the Monument of the Martyrs which continued overnight and included a meeting the next day.

Residents of the 3rd and 5th districts of Bangui erected barricades following violence in their areas. The protesters were also said to be displaying hostility towards international forces and humanitarian workers, along with journalists.

Residents of the 3rd and 5th districts of Bangui erected barricades following violence in their areas. The protesters were also said to be displaying hostility towards international forces and humanitarian workers, along with journalists.

column10: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: Anti-Balaka militiamen allegedly attacked the offices of the national gendarmerie but were repulsed by the police, resulting in the deaths of 2 of the attackers.
Fighting continues between ex-Seleka and anti-Balaka forces in Bangui.

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column22: Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; Radio Ndeke Luka; Agence France Presse -- English; Deutsche Welle
column23: A protest march was organized and a civil disobedience movement was called in response to the ongoing violence in Bangui. MINSUCA forces allegedly fired upon the several hundred marchers who were heading to the Office of the President to demand the resignation of the President with live bullets, killing 3 and injuring several, but UN sources dispute this. Most sources agree that three were killed.

column22: Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; Deutsche Welle
column23: 1 prisoner was killed during a mass escape by hundreds of prisoners, including anti-Balaka militiamen, from Bangui's main prison. After the escape, local residents looted the prison after the gates were left open.
Protesters in Bangui continued to maintain barricades on the streets following overnight violence in the capital.

column10: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column23: Anti-Balaka gunmen attacked the offices of the national radio station, but they were repelled by the security forces. 3 of the attackers were killed, including an infamous member of the anti-Balaka group, named Mazimbele.

At least 53 prisoners escaped during an attack on a prison in Bouar by about 30 unidentified gunmen. They captured 2 policemen and stole their weapons and looted computers. It was not clear whether they were later released.
Several people were injured when unidentified gunmen threw a grenade in the central market of Kaga-Bandoro. Some shops were also burned.
Protesters in Bangui continued to maintain barricades on the streets following overnight violence in the capital.
2 people were killed in continued clashes in Bangui. The report did not identify which groups were fighting. The violence was particularly notable around the airport.

column8: MCADP: The Patriotic Movement for the Appropriation of the Destiny of the Country
column23: A protest was organized by the Patriotic Movement for the Appropriation of the Destiny of the Country which is calling for the withdrawal of international forces.
Exchanges of fire were heard, including fighting near the National Assembly. Two Total stations at Boy-Rab, in an anti-Balaka stronghold, were also looted and vandalized.

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column22: Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; Radio France Internationale
column23: An attempt to dismantle barricades erected in the 8th district of Bangui led to a clash between the unidentified controllers of the barricades and MINUSCA elements. The violence reportedly also spread to the 3rd and 5th districts. At least 1 civilian was killed, although no official death toll was given.

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: An attempt to dismantle barricades erected in the 8th district of Bangui led to a clash between the unidentified controllers of the barricades and MINUSCA elements. The violence reportedly also spread to the 3rd and 5th districts. At least 1 civilian was killed, although no official death toll was given (coded as 10 across the 3 events).

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: An attempt to dismantle barricades erected in the 8th district of Bangui led to a clash between the unidentified controllers of the barricades and MINUSCA elements. The violence reportedly also spread to the 3rd and 5th districts. At least 1 civilian was killed, although no official death toll was given (coded as 10 across the 3 events).

1 person was killed and several injured during a shootout between anti-Balaka forces and armed youths from Bangui in the area of Bogoula village. The fight allegedly started after the armed youths were stopped at a barricade erected by the anti-Balaka forces.
At the call of civil society, most shops, government offices and drivers went on strike to protest against the violence which has hit Bangui over the past few days.

column22: Agence France Presse; Human Rights Watch
column23: The National Transitional Council say that 77 people were killed and 300 injured during violence around Bangui around the end of September following the death of a Muslim motorcycle taxi driver (57 fatalities were coded in other events) based on body counts at morgues around the city. The fatalities include both those engaged in violence and civilians caught in the crossfire.

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: Unidentified gunmen opened fire on the MINSUCA HQ in Bangui, prompting a return of fire from MINUSCA forces. The attackers then fled on a motorcycle. No casualties were reported.
3 people were killed and several others injured during an attack by unidentified gunmen on Lakouetene, near Mbres. The gunmen fired at youths as they were returning from their fields.
The Muslim community in PK5 organized a peace rally in PK5 following the violence experienced over the past week.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column22: Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; Associated Press International
column23: A Burundian MINUSCA peacekeeper was killed during an attack by an unidentified group on a convoy traveling between Damaraand Ngerengou. Another was also injured by the attackers.
A group of allegedly anti-Balaka gunmen attacked a convoy of vehicles near Boali, firing on the vehicles and looting them, leading to 2 deaths and several injuries.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: Sangaris: French Mission in Central African Republic in Support of MISCA (2013-)
column22: Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI); Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; Les Dépêches de Brazzaville; Radio France Internationale
column23: MINUSCA and French forces clashed just outside the Sibut area with former Seleka rebels, specifically PRGF, who were marching on Bangui. The clashes continued from Oct.10-11. Helicopters bombed Seleka positions during the fighting. 10 Seleka were killed over the 2 days of fighting.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: Sangaris: French Mission in Central African Republic in Support of MISCA (2013-)
column22: Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI); Les Dépêches de Brazzaville; Radio France Internationale
column23: MINUSCA and French forces clashed just outside the Sibut area with former Seleka rebels, specifically PRGF, who were marching on Bangui. The clashes continued from Oct.10-11. Helicopters bombed Seleka positions during the fighting. 10 Seleka were killed over the 2 days of fighting.
Unidentified assailants kidnapped 4 MSF staff members from their office in Bangassou. They were released half an hour later, with one international employee suffering serious injuries.
Former Seleka rebels from the PRGF faction raided the town of Kouango, shooting in all directions and setting buildings on fire. At least 2 people were wounded during the incident.

column22: Centrafrique Presse Info (CPI); Réseau des Journalistes de RCA; Agence France Presse -- English
column23: 1 person was killed and 10 wounded, primarily civilians, after anti-Balaka forces attacked the neighbourhood of PK5 in Bangui. They were opposed by self-defense committees from the district. Heavy gunfire was heard for about an hour.

3 people were killed and 7 injured after clashes between two groups of anti-Balaka related to a conflict over the chain of command. The "author of the disorders and other anti-Balaka" were among those killed. Calm returned after the intervention of MINUSCA forces.

column10: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2013-)
column22: Radio France Internationale; UN News Service
column23: The Deputy Chairman of the National Transitional Council was kidnapped along with two police officers by anti-Balaka forces about 90km north of Bangui. They were kept for 2 hours, before being released and given a list of demands for the government.

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column22: Radio France Internationale; Xinhua General News Service; UN News Service
column23: 7 UN police were kidnapped by a 50 member anti-Balaka force and disarmed near Boali before being released in the evening after negotiations with the government.

column10: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column23: 3 unidentified gunmen attacked a MINUSCA forces post in Damara. 1 assailant was killed when the peacekeepers returned fire, while the other two escaped.
Darfur rebels crossed the border into Chad and clashed with Chadian soldiers, resulting in 3 dead. 12 rebels were captured (specific location not given).
MSF estimates that 2,000 suspected Janjaweed launched an attack from Darfur into Chad against nomads in Koulbous, stealing 800 camels and taking them across the border.
16 Janjaweed were killed in a clash with Chadian troops near Agam (lat/longs not available) near the border with Sudan. 1 Chadian officer was also killed.
Chadian troops repulsed an attack by Janjaweed militiamen near Am Djerima, a border town with Sudan.

On Mar.16, it was reported that for the past few weeks Janjaweed have been mounting almost daily attacks on Chadian territory to steal livestock from Darfurian refugees. These attacks have been accompanied by rape, murder and looting (coded as 10 fatalities per event). (4 events coded at Time Precision 2)

On Mar.16, it was reported that for the past few weeks Janjaweed have been mounting almost daily attacks on Chadian territory to steal livestock from Darfurian refugees. These attacks have been accompanied by rape, murder and looting (coded as 10 fatalities per event). (4 events coded at Time Precision 2)

On Mar.16, it was reported that for the past few weeks Janjaweed have been mounting almost daily attacks on Chadian territory to steal livestock from Darfurian refugees. These attacks have been accompanied by rape, murder and looting (coded as 10 fatalities per event). (4 events coded at Time Precision 2)

On Mar.16, it was reported that for the past few weeks Janjaweed have been mounting almost daily attacks on Chadian territory to steal livestock from Darfurian refugees. These attacks have been accompanied by rape, murder and looting (coded as 10 fatalities per event). (4 events coded at Time Precision 2)
Janjaweed attacked a refugee site 30km north of Tine on the Chadian side of the border.
Janjaweed attacked refugees and Chadian civilians before clashing with Chadian soldiers.
GoS aircraft bombed the village of Kulbus.
Janjaweed attacked refugees and Chadian civilians before clashing with Chadian soldiers.
Janjaweed and Chadian soldiers clash near Birak.
Chadian police entered Farchana camp, following riots which had seen humanitarian workers attacked, and shot dead 2 people.
Janjaweed are allegedly continuing to make cross-border raids into Chadian territory (specific locations not given).

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: French military forces have begun flying humanitarian aid into eastern Chad and helping Chad secure its border with Darfur, in cooperation with Chadian forces.
2 suspected Janjaweed crossed into Chad and killed 4 men (specific locations not given).

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column10: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column23: Former rebel leader Abdel Kader Baba Ladde was extradicted to Chad from CAR
Tens of thousands marched in support of Chadian troops heading to Nigeria and Cameroon to fight Boko Haram.

High school students rioted against new Baccalaureate regulations, ransacking school facilities. Security forces intervened, and four students and one onlooker were killed. Eight people were seriously injured including five security forces and five students.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Two women from Nigeria were arrested outside of N'Djamena for possession of explosives. They may be members of Boko Haram and were planning to carry out suicide attacks in N'Djamena.

Boko Haram fighters crossed from Baga into Ngoubo and started firing indiscriminately, torching 2/3 of the town. Chadian forces returned fire and routed the militants. At least one civilian - the village chief- and one soldier were killed, along with two Boko Haram fighters.
Chadian military planes destroyed 5 boats of Boko Haram combattants that were trying to enter the country on Lake Chad.
The Cameroonian community in Chad organized a march in support of Chadian and Cameroonian soldiers fighting Boko Haram.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Deutsche Welle; Alwihda; Radio France Internationale
column23: Students protested against a rise in helmet prices after their use became obligatory this month, setting fire to several vehicles and blocking access to schools. They broke out in clashes with security forces who used tear gas to disperse them, leaving 1 - 4 dead, several injured and several arrested. They also attacked motorcyclists, stealing and breaking their helmets. 12 police officers were later arrested in an inquiry into the incident.

column7: Police Forces of Chad (1990-) Mobile Intervention Unit
column23: At least 8 police officers from the elite mobile intervention unit tortured protesters after they were arrested on March 9th.
Chadian and French troops exchanged fire due to a misunderstanding. Two people were injured.
Hundreds of Nigerians marched to support Chadian and Cameroonian troops fighting against Boko Haram.
Boko Haram ambushed civilians going to market and killed 7 with knives and guns.
Teachers went on strike due to delayed payment of salaries, causing secondary and high schools in the Ndjamena region to close.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Boko Haram militants attacked the market town of Ngouboua looting property and stealing as many as 500 head of livestock. No casualties were reported.
After a suspect died in police custody, protesters burned vehicles and markets and ransacked offices. Police responded with gunfire; four died and more than ten were injured in the violent clashes.
Seven were killed and several injured in inter-communal clashes in the Salamat area.
Boko Haram attacked Chadian military forces on the island of Choua in Lake Chad. 4 soldiers and 33 militants were killed.
Chadian military planes targeted Boko haram positions on Lake Chad and destroyed food, fuel, and munitions belonging to the insurgents.
Chadian military planes targeted Boko haram positions on Lake Chad and destroyed food, fuel, and munitions belonging to the insurgents.

column22: Leadership (Abuja); Associated Press International; Deutsche Welle; Xinhua General News Service
column23: Suicide bombers on motorcycles simultaneously attacked police headquarters and the national police academy, killing at least 23 immediately, with a final death toll of 37. They also wounded more than 100 others and security agents returned fire. At least four of the dead were suspected Boko Haram fighters.
Two men tried to detonate suicide bombs outside the central police station but were intercepted and arrested.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Alwihda website;
column23: After an exchange of gunfire, police arrested Boko Haram's leader for Chad and Northern Cameroon, Baana fanay alias Mahamat Moustapha, with at least two of his accomplices.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Alwihda website
column23: Six militants blew themselves up, initially killing themselves as well as five Chadian police officers and injuring at least one other, during a police operation launched Monday against Boko Haram. The death toll was later revised upwards to 13.
Boko Haram attacked the village of Memorom on Lake Chad, killing at least 3 and wounding around 12.

column22: Xinhua General News Service; Radio France Internationale; Jeune Afrique
column23: A Boko Haram suicide bomb attack killed 15 and wounded at least 74 others near the central market in N'Djamena.

15 people were killed, including one gendarme, and 80 injured in a suicide attack at the entrance of a central market in Ndjamena. The suicide bomber was allegedly wearing a burqa and detonated the bomb when a municipal police officer and paramilitary official stopped the bomber to search him. The attack was claimed by Boko Haram.

Boko Haram fighters attacked Tetewa Island on Lake Chad, near the border with Nigeria. Chad army reported 117 Boko Haram militants killed and 2 soldiers killed in clashes the last two weeks of July in the Lakes region (30 fatalities coded for July 13 clashes in Bol, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Médi Koura, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Blarigi, and 29 coded for July 27 clashes in Telia).
19 Boko Haram fighters and 1 Chadian soldier were killed in an attack on a military position in Konguia (lat/longs not available).
1 villager was killed and 3 others injured in a suspected Boko Haram raid on Midi on the banks of Lake Chad.

Clashes between military and Boko Haram in Médi Koura, during a search operation for Boko Haram hiding on the lake's islands. At time of fighting, reported that 6 Boko Haram killed, 15 wounded. One soldier killed. Later, Chad army reported 117 Boko Haram militants killed and 2 soldiers killed in clashes the last two weeks of July in the Lakes region (30 fatalities coded for July 13 clashes in Bol, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Médi Koura, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Blarigi, and 29 coded for July 27 clashes in Telia).  In Médi Koura, Boko Haram reported to have kidnapped women and children.

Clashes between military and Boko Haram in Blarigi Island on Lake Chad. Chad army reported 117 Boko Haram militants killed and 2 soldiers killed in clashes the last two weeks of July in the Lakes region (30 fatalities coded for July 13 clashes in Bol, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Médi Koura, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Blarigi, and 29 coded for July 27 clashes in Telia).

Clashes between military and Boko Haram 20kms south of Baga Sola, Lake Chad. Boko Haram reportedly abducted an unknown number of soldiers. Chad army reported 117 Boko Haram militants killed and 2 soldiers killed in clashes the last two weeks of July in the Lakes region (30 fatalities coded for July 13 clashes in Bol, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Médi Koura, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Blarigi, and 29 coded for July 27 clashes in Telia).
In a battle between Boko Haram and the Chadian military near Tchoukou Telia on Lake Chad, 7 Islamists were killed and 2 soldiers were injured.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: The President of the National Union of Chadian Students, Nadjo Kaina, was arrested for "disturbing public order" while attempting to organize a solution to unpaid student scholarships. He was released a couple weeks later.
Some 10 people have been killed in clashes between rival tribes (Toubou and Zaghawa) near a gold mine.
Two suspected Boko Haram members blew themselves up on Lake Chad while being pursued by the Chadian military.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Chad executed 10 alleged members of Boko Haram by firing squad one day after they were found guilty of a terrorist attack perpetrated in June. At least one was a Nigerian citizen.

column8: UST: Union of Chadian Trade Unions
column23: Trade unions started a three day strike nationwide, claiming there is a delay in paments of wages, grants, pensions, and scholarships.

column22: Deutsche Welle; Agence France Presse - English
column23: Boko Haram carried out a pre-dawn strike near Lake Chad, killing 11 soldiers and wounding several. 17 Boko Haram militants also died in the clashes.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; Associated Press International; Xinhua General News Service
column23: Suicide bombers, including 3 women and 2 children likely affiliated with Boko Haram, attacked a fish market and IDP camps, killing 47 and injuring dozens.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Police arrested 62 women for wearing full veils in public and also arrested 8 suspected "jihadis" in the first major arrests since the veil ban.

column7: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column10: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column11: RCD-K-ML: Rally for Congolese Democracy-Kisangani-Liberation Movement
column23: Several people killed and wounded, and hundreds of homes burnt in Djugu area due to conflict between the Hema and Lendu tribes since early June. Displaced populations reported to be heading towards the Lake Albert plain. RCD Ugandan and Congolese soldiers were involved in the violence.

column7: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column10: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column23: Ethnic clashes have reportedly been raging since mid-June between the Walendu and Wahema groups in areas around Bunia. Some deaths have been reported, along with looted and burnt houses.

column7: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column10: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column23: 194 people have died in ethnic clashes in Djugu area in Ituri between the Lendu and Bagegere (Northern Hema) tribes in June. the Lendu launched a major attack on the Bagegere, killing over 190, and four rebel soldiers of MLC.

column7: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column11: Lendu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column23: Hema militias and UPDF forces killed at least 25 including several civilians in an attack on Dhendro village in Walendu Pitisi community

column7: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column10: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column23: Massive clashes following ethnic tensions between Hema and Lendu over property rights kill 200 between 19-20 June; Uganda soldiers reportedly took part in clashes alongside Hema militias. Clashes will rapidly expand to other territories.

column7: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column11: Hema Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column23: Some 370 Wahema pastorialists killed by Lendu farmers in the early hours of 14 September in Ituri. Thousands are affected by the conflict

column7: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column11: Hema Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column23: Hundreds of Hema civilians killed in Lendu attacks on villages in Dhendro locality; victims have been burried in communal graves. Dozens of villages have also been burnt and looted by militiamen

column7: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column11: Lendu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column23: Dozens of Lendu civilians, including at least 15 minors and women, killed in Hema attacks on Fataki village. All Lendu civilians left the village, which became was overtaken by Hema militias.

column7: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column10: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column23: Renewed clashes between Hema and Lendu in December were most intense in Djugu area and sent 20,000 to 30,000 displaced people towards nearby towns including Bunia

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Row erupted in Bunia between governor of Ituri-Kibali region and RCD-Kisangani rebel soldiers, as the latter were disarmed by Ugandan soldiers reportedly supporting the governor
100 nurses from the Uvira highlands health zone went on strike to demand wages and risk premiums they say they are not receiving.
LRA members raided the village of Mangasaba, near Dungu, stealing food and taking 2 people hostage, forcing them to carry the goods they stole. The hostages were later released.
Armed men believed to be members of the LRA ambushed three men on a motorcycle, seriously injuring 2.

column7: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column11: PPRD: People's Party for Reconstruction and Democracy
column23: Unidentified armed men attacked a former deputy national chariman in charge of youth for the PPRD. He was allegedly targeted due to his opposition to constitutional reforms.

column7: Shari Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column10: Kunda Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column23: After a gold trader was found killed, Shari youth went to Kunda armed with knives and clashed with the people of Kunda. A soldier attempted to intervene and stop the fighting but was lunched and burned alive by the crowd. No other casualties were reported.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
column10: FRPI-Cobra Matata: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri (Cobra Matata Faction)
column23: The leader of the FRPI militia, Cobra Matata, has been taken into custody by Congolese security forces and transfered to Kinshasa, raising fears that the militia may begin attacking communities in protest.

column7: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
column8: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column10: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column23: FARDC and MONUSCO forces regained control of the town of Abya, in Virunga National Park northeast of Beni, after heavy fighting with the ADF. 5 rebels were killed and 4 others injured.

column8: PPRD: People's Party for Reconstruction and Democracy
column23: Members of the PPRD protested against the suspension of the mayor of Kisangani by the provincial governor.

column7: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
column23: 4 youths arrested in Dr'dza village after 2 police were burned to death there, were found dead in the jail of the district prosecutor in Bunia. They were allegedly tortured to death or starved, but it is still unclear how they died. An investigation has been opened.

column7: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column23: 4 people, including 2 Ugandans, were kidnapped by an unidentified armed group. They were later released.

column7: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
column8: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column10: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column23: FARDC and MONUSCO soldiers have taken control of Mavume, "an important position of the ADF", after heavy fighting with the rebels. 11 rebels were killed during the fighting and 3 FARDC soldiers were injured.

column7: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
column8: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column23: FARDC and MONUSCO soldiers have recovered all bases controlled by the FNL on the Uvira plateaus, and specifically around the town of Ruhoha. No casualties were taken by the joint forces, while casualties for the FNL were not reported. Provisional casualties were announced at 2 FNL fighters dead and 29 wounded during the operation.

column7: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
column23: Clashes broke out between residents of Kebya-Kamwanga and the police, which were only dispersed by the police firing their weapons into the air. Calm was returned by the arrival of FARDC soldiers. It is not clear what started the situation but allegedly a member of the security services was humiliating a resident, which led to the riot.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column7: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
column23: Police arrested dozens of activists ("opponents of the regime of President Joseph Kabila") who were distributing invitations to a meeting off the political opposition on Jan.11.

Hundreds of employees of the Panzi General Hospital have protested outside the facilities of the Directorate General fo Taxes (DGI) against the freezing of assets of their hospital and collection of taxes on their income.
Truck drivers have gone on strike to protest against alleged police harassment.

column7: Yatota Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column10: Zambo Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column23: 3 people were killed and several others injured by knives and firearms during a land dispute between the villages of Yatota and Zambo in Bumba locality. Police intervened to restore order shortly after.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Nyanderema, the head of a Raia Mutomboki Mayi Mayi militia which bears his name, surrendered to FARDC forces in the locality of Luizi in Kabare, accompanied by 9 of his men bearing 12 weapons.

column7: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column23: A journalist was stabbed by two unidentified armed men. He was seriously wounded.
The National Press Union of the Congo staged a march in solidarity with the French press following the Charlie Hebdo attack in Paris. The march began in the Gombe commune of Kinshasa.

column7: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
column8: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column10: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column23: FARDC and MONUSCO forces took control of the Pilot and Issa camps of the ADF in Virungu National Park.

column7: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column23: 2 shells fell in farmers fields near the road leading to Kisangani. It is uncertain who fired them, but they destroyed "several hecatres of farmers' fields".

column8: UNC: Union for the Congolese Nation, FIS: Front for Social Integration, MLC: Movement for the Liberation of Congo, UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column10: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
column22: Radio Okapi; Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse
column23: About 300 people (including members of the UNC, MLC, UDPS, and Front for Social Integration, FIS) participated in an opposition march against amendments to the electoral law. The march was quickly dispersed with violence by police who beat protesters and fired tear gas. 15 people were wounded and 30 others arrested. The police also reportedly fired on protesters, some of whom had bullet wounds, including the President of the FIS. The police claim that the protesters were violent and threw stones, injuring 7 police officers and 4 Transco bus employees.

column10: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
column23: Opposition parties have continued to protest against the proposed electoral law. The police attempted to disperse protesters with tear gas and shots fired into the air.

column7: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
column23: FARDC soldiers have "dislodged" the Mayi Mayi militia led by Cheka from 4 localities in Walikale, including Mpofi, Luvungi, Kigoma and Kailenge.

column7: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
column23: FARDC soldiers have "dislodged" the Mayi Mayi militia led by Cheka from 4 localities in Walikale, including Mpofi, Luvungi, Kigoma and Kailenge.

column23: FARDC soldiers have "dislodged" the Mayi Mayi militia led by Cheka from 4 localities in Walikale, including Mpofi, Luvungi, Kigoma and Kailenge.

column23: FARDC soldiers clashed with the Yakutumba Mayi Mayi militia, killing 2 militiamen, in Tulongye, near Lulimba. 1 FARDC soldier was killed as well.

column8: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column11: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column23: Two factions of UDPS clashed in front of their HQ in Mbuji-Mayi after dissident UDPS youth attempted to put up the flag of the "presidential majority". Afterwards, the dissident youth attacked the home of the Vice President of the UDPS youth league. In retaliation, youth league members attacked one of the dissident UDPS members houses with stones. Police intervened and arrested several people. At least 1 person was injured.

column8: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column10: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column23: Fighting began between FARDC soldiers and FRPI militiamen in the village of Aveba, and spread to other villages in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi (in Ituri), including Tchekele, Kaswara and Bavi. Thousands of people were displaced during the fighting. In Aveba, UN helicopters assisted the Congolese forces, and at least 14 FRPI and 6 FARDC soldiers were reported dead in Aveba.

column7: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
column10: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column23: Fighting began between FARDC soldiers and FRPI militiamen in the village of Aveba, and spread to other villages in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi (in Ituri), including Tchekele, Kaswara and Bavi. Thousands of people were displaced during the fighting.

column23: Fighting began between FARDC soldiers and FRPI militiamen in the village of Aveba, and spread to other villages in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi (in Ituri), including Tchekele, Kaswara and Bavi. Thousands of people were displaced during the fighting.

column10: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column23: Fighting began between FARDC soldiers and FRPI militiamen in the village of Aveba, and spread to other villages in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi (in Ituri), including Tchekele, Kaswara and Bavi. Thousands of people were displaced during the fighting.
