Protests took place in Giza, Sharqyia, Kafr Al-Shiekh, Fayoum, and Behira after the pro Morsi Anti Coup Alliance (ACA) called upon its supporters to demonstrate the coming parliament describing it as "bloody".

A policeman was killed and two others injured on Saturday evening when a blast targeted their patrol in Arish city of Egypt's North Sinai province, the Interior Ministry said in a statement. The explosive device was planted by unknown assailants on the side of the Ring Road in Arish city.
Several activists and intellectuals in Alexandria staged a protest with books on Saturday, outside small bookstores that had been destroyed at al-Raml Station.
A bomb exploded in Al-Arish, North Sinai on 18 October, killing a police conscript and injuring a lieutenant.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Sappers dismantled on Sunday [18 October] a makeshift bomb which was found at Quhafa School near a polling centre in Al-Fayyum.

column8: BDS: Boycott Divestment and Sanctions Egypt
column23: Protesters gathered in front of the Press Syndicate on 18 October in solidarity with Palestinian resistance as part of an event jointly organised by the Egyptian branch of the Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) movement, the Press Syndicate and the Popular Movement to Support the Intifada.
On Sunday, prominent figures and politicians participated in a press conference that followed a demonstration stand organised in front of the Press Syndicate in Cairo.

In Kafr al-Sheikh, hundreds of students staged a protest outside the governor’s office condemning a recent decision by the Education Ministry to add marks for attendance and discipline, demanding the marks to be abrogated.
Two sound bombs exploded Sunday morning, on the first day of parliamentary elections, in front of one of the schools in Kerdasa. No injuries were reported.

In Port Said, students at several high schools refused to attend classes and chanted slogans critical of Education Minister al-Helaly al-Shirbiny and condemning a recent decision by the Education Ministry to add marks for attendance and discipline.
Clashes between coordinators of candidate campaigns broke out in the neighborhoods of Waraq and Atfeeh in South Giza but were dispersed by security forces.

Minor clashes were witnessed between different candidates' supporters in the Al-Badrasheen district of Giza. A police car was also attacked by unknown assailants while passing by the Cairo-Assiut road in Badrasheen, north of Cairo.
Clashes between coordinators of candidate campaigns broke out in the neighborhoods of Waraq and Atfeeh in South Giza but were dispersed by security forces.

Violent clashes took place between two families in front of one of the voting committees in the Motamadiya neighbourhood of Kerdasa. Voting was suspended temporarily until the dispute was settled. Security men were able to interfere to restore the security and the voting process.
Dozens of Ibrahimeya City residents in Sharqiya protested lengthy and daily water cuts on Tuesday.
Students staged a protest outside Saray al-Qobba Secondary School, Ansaf Saray al-Qobba School and Al-Aziz Bellah School in the Zatoun and Saray al-Qobba neighborhoods in Cairo on 20 October.
Students staged a protest outside Saray al-Qobba Secondary School, Ansaf Saray al-Qobba School and Al-Aziz Bellah School in the Zatoun and Saray al-Qobba neighborhoods in Cairo on 20 October.
Eleven people were injured in Al-Arish, North Sinai on Wednesday after a bomb exploded near a military tank in the district of Masaed near Al-Arish. No group claimed responsibility.

Workers at Egypt’s major textile manufacturer declared on Wednesday an open-ended strike over the government’s decision to backtrack on disbursing a 10 percent bonus for its workers previously approved by President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Masked and armed Egyptian security forces raided the office of an organization in Cairo that trains and aides journalists on 21 October. The forces detained all staff members present in the office of the Mada Foundation for Media Development on Wednesday, later releasing females but keeping some 20 male staff members on the premises.

Hundreds of high school students in Minya, Gharbiya and Monufiya protested Wednesday against the decision of the education minister to allocate ten grades for discipline and attendance. In Minya, security forces chased hundreds of high school students in streets around the Minya Education Directorate.

Hundreds of high school students in Minya, Gharbiya and Monufiya protested against the decision of the education minister to allocate ten grades for discipline and attendance. In Monufiya, students protested outside the governor's office. They raised banners that read: "Day and night, we oppose the decision," and "Down with an education system that seeks for the student to be an animal," and other slogans that call for the cancellation of the decision.

Hundreds of high school students in Minya, Gharbiya and Monufiya protested Wednesday against the decision of the education minister to allocate ten grades for discipline and attendance. In Gharbiya, students and some parents protested outside the Tanta governor's office.

column22: Aswat Masriya; MENA news agency; Daily News Egypt
column23: Egyptian security forces carried out raids in Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuwaid that left a total of 20 militants dead, 12 wounded and 78 suspects arrested, the armed forces said in a statement Thursday. Fatalities divided between events. 7 fatalities recorded in Rafah; 6 fatalities recorded in Sheikh Zuweyid.

column22: Aswat Masriya; MENA news agency; Daily News Egypt
column23: Egyptian security forces carried out raids in Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuwaid that left a total of 20 militants dead, 12 wounded and 78 suspects arrested, the armed forces said in a statement Thursday. Fatalities divided between events. 7 fatalities recorded in Al-Arish; 6 fatalities recorded in Sheikh Zuweyid.

column22: Aswat Masriya; MENA news agency; Daily News Egypt
column23: Egyptian security forces carried out raids in Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuwaid that left a total of 20 militants dead, 12 wounded and 78 suspects arrested, the armed forces said in a statement Thursday. Fatalities divided between events. 7 fatalities recorded in Al-Arish; 7 fatalities recorded in Rafah.

column22: Agence France Presse; Associated Press International
column23: A roadside bombing killed a police officer and wounded three others in the town of El-Arish. The Islamic State affiliated grou - State of Sinai later claimed responsibility for the attack.

column22: Agence France Presse; Daily News Egypt
column23: Four people were wounded on Friday by a bomb planted at the Rimaya intersection near the Giza Pyramids. The Islamic State (IS) group in Egypt - 'State of Sinai' claimed it had planted the device. It detonated when police used water cannon to try to defuse it, injuring two policemen and two hotel security guards.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Security forces have arrested 40 middle-ranking leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood [MB] in a new security crackdown on wanted elements who were involved in attacks on public facilities and rioting across Egypt.

Gunmen shot dead an Islamist candidate in Egypt's parliamentary elections in North Sinai on 24 October. A candidate for ultraconservative Salafist Al-Nur party which is seen as pro-government, was gunned down by two assailants on a motorbike outside his home in the town of El-Arish. Police officials say they believe Islamist militants targeted the candidate to undermine the elections.
Three Egyptian policemen were killed in a roadside bombing in Al-Arish in Sinai on 24 October. The State of Sinai group claimed responsibility.
A policeman was shot dead by unknown assailants who were driving a motorcycle.
Police officers in Equatorial Guinea on Saturday beat up a Nigerian diplomat, Noah Ichaba, on the street of Bata. He was later taken to a hospital where he was treated and discharged on the same day

An Eritrean opposition group has reportedly raided a government owned garage facility in the capital Asmara. Eritrean National Salvation Front (ENSF) in a statement said its armed wing has carried out the attack on Wednesday at the garage located in Qohawta neighbourhood in retaliation to the regime’s oppression against citizens including deny economic rights of the people. The statement didn’t disclose if there were causalities from government side following the attack but it admitted one of its fighters have sustained light wounds.

Tension remains high on Ethiopian and Eritrea border after a series of clashes in mid-March. The situation deteriorated on the second weekend of the month (March 14 or 15) following a surprise attack by Eritrean military around Badme area. Several personnel of an Ethiopian National Defense Forces (ENDF) unit were killed by the ambush, as HornAffairs was able to confirm from firsthand sources.
An unidentified target near Barentu [in western Eritrea] was hit on 20 March by Ethiopian missiles shot from Tigray [Regional State, bordering Eritrea] in Ethiopia. The missile did not cause damage.

The mining complex at Bisha [in western Eritrea] in Eritrea was hit on 20 March by Ethiopian missiles shot from Tigray [Regional State, bordering Eritrea] in Ethiopia. The mine sustained a slight damage.

A military facility located between the villages of Tukhul and Wutuh in the Mai Edaga [both in southern Eritrea] area was hit on 20 March by Ethiopian missiles shot from Tigray [Regional State, bordering Eritrea] in Ethiopia. The military facility was heavily destroyed.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: An Ethiopian court last week handed down prison terms to three British citizens convicted on terrorism-related charges. According to the federal high court, the trio had links to local members of a jihadist group seeking to turn the Horn of Africa nation into an Islamic state

column8: UDJ: Unity for Democracy and Justice
column23: At least 26 protesters were injured when Ethiopian police broke an opposition protest rally in the capital, Addis Ababa, today.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Five Somali nationals, suspected to be Al-Shabab members, have been arrested in the Ethiopian capital Addis Ababa. They are said to have been planning suicide attacks in some of the city's recreational areas, privately-owned pro-government Ethiopian newspaper The Reporter website, thereporterethiopia.com, reported on 1 March

Clashes between police and protesters erupted at Meskel Square, Addis Ababa in Ethiopia on 19 April 2015 when Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn was making a speech, and some protesters were injured in the fracas. The protest rally was held to condemn the execution of Ethiopians in Libya by the IS group.

A young leader of the opposition Semayawi [Blue] Party was beaten and stabbed to death on Monday night [16 June], allegedly by members of the security service of the TPLF regime [Tigray People's Liberation Front, reference to incumbent Ethiopian government]. A government spokesperson denied the allegations
Ethiopian Muslims held peaceful protests on Friday 26 June to demand the release of their leaders who were arrested in August 2012

Thousands of Eritrean refugees in Ethiopia yesterday held demonstrations in Addis Ababa, Afar and Tigray refugee camps demanding the international community to take urgent action to stop human rights abuses and oppression by the Asmara regime.

Thousands of Eritrean refugees in Ethiopia yesterday held demonstrations in Addis Ababa, Afar and Tigray refugee camps demanding the international community to take urgent action to stop human rights abuses and oppression by the Asmara regime.

Thousands of Eritrean refugees in Ethiopia yesterday held demonstrations in Addis Ababa, Afar and Tigray refugee camps demanding the international community to take urgent action to stop human rights abuses and oppression by the Asmara regime.

column7: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column23: An Ethiopian armed opposition group,  "Arbegnoch [Patriotic] Ginbot 7" for Unity and Democratic Movement (AGUDM), carried out a surprise attack on Ethiopian troops in Kafta Mesil, Urjamo and Maisegel areas of Tigray region - exact locations not available. Some sources claim over 50 Ethiopia soldiers were killed, while Ethiopian government’s spokesperson dismissed the report as fictitious. The number of casualties on the rebel side is not known.

Ethiopian police have killed 30 armed people, believed to be trained and supported by Eritrea, who tried to illegally enter the country's territory from Eritrea, from the western part of the Tigray Region, an official said Friday. A number of them have been arrested
The OLF forces on 16 July attacked a military camp at Bobasa, Fedisa District Hararge Zone in eastern Oromiya, eastern Ethiopia during which 13 government soldiers were killed and 23 others wounded
Butchers in Addis Abeba closed their shops on the eve of the end of a one month fasting season for orthodox Christians, in protest over tax confusion

Eight Ethiopian government military officers were killed in a battle with the Ogaden National Liberation Army in Wadhile of Degeh Bur district, Jerar province [southeastern Ethiopia], on 12 August 2015

On 17 August 2015, Ogaden National Liberation Army [ONLA, military wing of ONLF] fighters and Ethiopian troops clashed in Wartimire locality, Degeh Bur District, Jerar Province. Ten soldiers were killed and 14 others wounded in the fighting.
On 18 August, the Ogaden National Liberation Army staged an attack on Ethiopian troops in Dig locality, Jerar Province. Four soldiers were killed and six others wounded in the attack.

On 19 August 2015, ONLA fighters carried out a heavy attack on Ethiopian government troops in Deyr locality, Aware District, Jerar Province. Nineteen soldiers were killed and 20 others wounded in the attack.
Violent confrontations erupt on 21 August in Oda Bultum District, West Harerge, between locals and Ethiopian forces searching for OLA fighters. Four soldiers are wounded by machetes.
Four Ethiopian soldiers were killed and one other wounded on 23 August when residents of Mada Talila in Doba District, West Harerge, clashed with government forces.

On 24 August 2015, the ONLA and Ethiopian colonial troops engaged in a heavy battle in Gomoshka in Galalshe District, Nogob Province. Unspecified human and material losses were inflicted on the enemy.

On 24 August a heavy battle occurred in Suqweyne in the town of Fik between confused colonial forces and fighters who stand for the liberation of Ogadenia. Colonial forces suffered heavy losses, details of which could not be obtained.

On 26 August a battle between the ONLA and Ethiopian soldiers occurred in Madax Maroodi, Kebri Dehar District, Korahe Province. Three soldiers, among them officers, were killed and three others wounded.

Oromo Liberation Army fighters operating in eastern Oromiya zone have put more than 11 Ethiopian soldiers out of action and destroyed an Ural truck carrying a ZU machine-gun on the highway linking Harer and Addis Ababa (Kara Garbu or Hula Chufa in Firna area, West Harerge). Three soldiers were killed and more than nine others wounded. Ethiopian forces reportedly harassed and detained many people in the area for not disclosing OLA locations.
On 29 August the ONLF and colonial forces clashed in Dulgaban in Aware District, Jerar Province. The fighting left four enemy soldiers dead and six others wounded.
On 29 August the ONLA staged a sneak attack on Ethiopian government forces in Hankokinka in Birqod District, Jerar Province, killing four soldiers and wounding three others.
Three suspected Ethiopian government spies have been killed by a special unit of the Oromo Liberation Army in East Welega Zone, western Oromiya
On 30 August the ONLA carried out a well-planned attack on colonial troops in Dulgabo of Garbo District, Nogob Province, killing eight soldiers and wounding seven others.
On 30 August, Ethiopian soldiers killed four related young men and wounded one in Kebri Dehar District in Korahe Province in retaliation for ONLA attacks
The Oromo Liberation Army killed two Woyane policemen reportedly terrorizing people in Jimma village
On 31 August a fierce battle occurred in Turdhig of Degehmedo District, Jerar Province, between ONLA and Ethipian forces. Four Ethiopian soldiers were killed and five others wounded in the fighting.

The ONLA killed six government soldiers and wounded more than seven others at Sakate in Hawi Gudina Woreda of West Hararghe Zone. Three AK-47 assault rifles and a variety of materiel were also captured in the attack.

The ONLA ambushed a truck carrying government soldiers at Gola Buba, Gemechis Woreda of West Hararghe Zone. They killed five soldiers,wounded three others, destroyed the truck, and captured four AK-47 assault rifles in the ambush.
The ONLA attacked government forces a Gachana in Midaga Woreda of East Harerge Zone, killing nine soldiers and wounding more than 12 others, as well as capturing an assortment of weapons.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column22: Ethiopian Broadcasting Corporation TV; Government of Ethiopia
column23: A group of 800 fighters of the Eritrea-based Tigray People's Democratic Movement (TPDM) returned to Ethiopia with all their manpower and weapons in an organized manner

column22: Radio Freedom, Voice of the Ogadeni People
column23: Fighting between ONLA combatants and Ethiopian troops killed six weyane soldiers and wounded another seven

column22: Radio Freedom, Voice of the Ogadeni People
column23: Fighting between ONLA fighters and Ethiopian troops killed seven government soldiers and wounded another eight

column22: Radio Freedom, Voice of the Ogadeni People
column23: Fighting between ONLA fighters and government forces killed four government soldiers and wounded another four

column22: Radio Freedom, Voice of the Ogadeni People
column23: A heavy battle between ONLA fighters and Ethiopian  forces led to unspecified human and material losses on government soldiers.

column22: Radio Freedom, Voice of the Ogadeni People
column23: ONLA combatants staged an ambush on government forces, destroying two trucks carrying many Ethiopian  soldiers, none of whom survived.

OLA special unit attacked government forces in Dalota in Haro Limu District, East Welega Zone, killing three soldiers and wounding more than nine. 120 rounds of ammunition and six hand grenades were also captured.
Government forces were deployed in Haro Limu District, East Welega Zone, to search ONLA fighters; they reportedly terrorised Oromo civilian populations
ONLA fighters and government forces fought a heavy battle in Kebri Amadin, Dolo province. Six enemy soldiers were killed and eight others were wounded in the fighting
heavy fighting erupted between Ogaden freedom fighters and government troops in Hodanweyne of East Imi, Shebelle province. Unspecified casualties were inflicted on weyane troops in the fighting.
A heavy battle occurred between ONLA and Ethiopian troops at Dulanod in Duhun District, Nogob Province. Ten government soldiers were killed and 15 others wounded.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Ethiopia had finalized preparations by deploying troops and mechanized forces along the border with Eritrea to launch targeted attacks against Eritrea.
ONLA fighters and government forces fought in Dhererweyne locality of Shilabo District, Korahey Province. Six government soldiers were killed and eight others wounded.
Ogaden fighters carried out a heavy attack on government forces stationed in Deyr in Aware District, Jerar Province. Unspecified casualties were inflicted on government forces.
OLA special forces unit, using a landmine, blew up a vehicle at Qarsa Alati in Bale Zone, killing two government soldiers and four of their bodyguards
Government forces alledgedly harrassed and beat up civilians in Qarsa Alati while searching for OLA fighters
OLA soldiers planted anti-personnel mine where three roads meet in Melka Ade in Laga Dharo. The explosion killed eight government soldiers and wounded six.
OLA fighters attacked government forces in Mudhi Balli, Midhaga Lola area of Fadis District, east Hararghe Zone, killing four soldiers and wounding seven others. Material was captured in the attack.

OLA fighters attacked government forces inHaro Dimtu in Kebele 25 of Boke District, west Hararghe Zone, killing five soldiers, wounding six others, and forcing the rest to flee. Arms were captured during the attack.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Six bloggers from the Zone 9 website were arrested in April 2014 and charged with terrorism for having links to an outlawed group and for planning attacks. There detention was accused of being unlawful by rights group. Two were released in July 2015 after charges were dropped, and three others in October 2015. The last one was acquitted of all charges in absentia

column8: FUOPA: United Opposition Front for Change
column23: Opposition party protesters held a silent march in support of France in light of the Charlie Hebdo attacks.

column22: Agence France Presse - English; BBC Monitoring Africa; Xinhua News Agency - French
column23: A gang of around 200 - 350 youth attacked the home of opposition leader Jean Ping, throwing stones and lighting fires. Ping says the authorities paid the youth to assault his home and that police refused to intervene; it is unclear whether opposition supporters or the police ended the attack, detaining several people.

column8: SNEC: National Union of Teachers and Researchers
column23: Public sector trade unionists, particularly educators, marched to the General Assembly to file a strike notice but were blocked by police forces.
Gabon Telecom workers began a general strike.

column8: SYNAPS: National Union of Health Personnel
column23: Health workers went on a limited service strike following the general assemby meeting of the National Union of Health Workers. The strike is in response to government silence on previous demands.
The Dynamic Unit [Dynamique unitaire] union protest outside the government administrative offices of Ogooué-Maritime. The demonstrators were eventually turned away by police.
Hundreds of people gathered at a rally to mark the renewal of a general strike called by a union coalition at a Oulabou Martine public school in Libreville.
Students protested to demand the end of teacher strikes.
Civil servants extended their general strike which began in early February to demand wage increases.

Under the direction of Dynamique Unitaire, 3,000 public workers conducted a sit-in in front of the National Assembly and were dispersed by police using tear gas. They regrouped at the University Omar Bongo and announced their decision to continue the general strike that began in early February.
Students marched to demand reestablishment of classes that have been cancelled due to teacher protests. Armed police blocked their route.

The PDG organized a "peace march" which culminated in a rally involving several political parties of the president's coalition. Another march and rally was held by the United Opposition Front. A wall of police separated the two rallies.
Opposition members rioted following the death of Mba Obame, setting fire to cars and buildlings, including the Embassy of Benin, and erecting barricades in Libreville.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Police were deployed for added security following unrest in Libreville, at sites including the National Assembly, oil offices, and major intersections near the headquarters of the National Union party.
Crowds of mourners prevented the remains of opposition leader Andre Mba Obame from flying from Libreville to the town of Oyem.

Crowds awaiting the delayed arrival of the remains of opposition leader Andre Mba Obame threw rocks at public buildings and torched market stalls. Police responded with batons and stun grenades and arrested at least three.
Workers at the National Council of Communication went on strike over wage demands.
Primary and secondary school teachers went on strike to demand payment of wages.
The public sector union Dynamic Unit relaunched a general strike that had been on pause since May 11.
Teachers at the Omar Bongo University went on strike to demand unpaid compensation and blocked the road into the university with their cars.
453 migrants from Senegal, Mali, Nigeria and Burkina Faso were expelled by Gabonese authorities, and human rights groups claim they were abused in the process. The government denies the claim.
UPG loyalists gather at the Research Directorate General building to demand justification for the arrest of former minister Mabiala. Police fired tear gas.
Gabonese Union Bank employees go on strike over unpaid bonuses.
Clashes between bank employee rioters and police.
In July 2005, armed groups killed three people, including two relatives of President Jammeh, and former NIA director Jasaja Kujabi

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of Gambia (1994-)
column23: In March 2006, after an attempted coup was thwarted, security forces detained 50 suspects, several of whom were held in prolonged detention at NIA headquarters. The whereabouts of five soldiers suspected of being involved in the coup plot remain unknown

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of Gambia (1994-)
column10: Military Forces of Gambia (1994-) National Intelligence Agency
column23: In March 2006, after an attempted coup was thwarted, security forces detained 50 suspects, several of whom were held in prolonged detention at NIA headquarters. The whereabouts of five soldiers suspected of being involved in the coup plot remain unknown

column7: Military Forces of Gambia (1994-) National Intelligence Agency
column23: Alleged NIA officers arrested Ebrima Manneh, a reporter for the Daily Observer, at the paper’s offices just outside of Banjul. His whereabouts are still unknown and the Gambian government has repeatedly denied ever having him in custody

Over one month in February and March 2009, authorities rounded up nearly 1,000 people from several villages in Foni Kansala and tried them in so-called “witch trials” that included arbitrary detention, torture, and rape of numerous villagers. Jammeh had invited Guinean religious leaders, socalled marabouts, to purge the country of “witches”; authorities were also supported by Junguleurs

column7: Military Forces of Gambia (1994-) National Intelligence Agency
column23: Imam Baba Leigh, a human rights activist and religious leader, was arrested by the NIA after he criticized the government’s use of the death penalty in one of his sermons. During his five month incommunicado detention, he was severely tortured
Col. Ndure Cham, former chief of staff of the armed forces, who was implicated in leading the 2006 attempted coup, went missing after having fled towards the border with Senegal in August 2013

column7: Military Forces of Gambia (1994-) National Intelligence Agency
column23: A man suspected of homosexuality was detained by NIA agents, held for eight days at NIA headquerters and then detained at Mile 2 prison for nine months with another man, subject to regular abuse at the hands of NIA officials for "unnatural acts". They were relased in July 2015

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Dozens of military personnel and civilians were arrested and a large cache of weapons and explosive found in the aftermath of an attempted coup earlier in the week. There is a heavy security presence throughout Banjul, including checkpoints, roadblocks, and house-to-house searches.

column7: Military Forces of Gambia (1994-) National Intelligence Agency
column23: Five people reportedly abducted by men believed to be members of the NIA.

column8: Military Forces of Gambia (1994-); Police Forces of Gambia (1994-)
column23: Hundreds of security force members held a rally in support of President Jammeh, four days after an attempted coup.

column7: Military Forces of Gambia (1994-) National Intelligence Agency
column23: One man was reportedly abducted by men believed to be members of the NIA.
Thousands marched in favor of the government in light of the Dec 30 attack on the presidential palace.

column7: Military Forces of Gambia (1994-) National Intelligence Agency
column23: One man was reportedly abducted by men believed to be members of the NIA.
Gambians in Brikama took to streets to denounce the December 30th attack  on the presidential palace in Banjul
The people of the Lower River Region (LRR) last Thursday turned out in their numbers to line up the streets of Jarra Soma in strong condemnation of the December 30th terrorist attack on State House

The Mourid community in The Gambia Sunday joined the global condemnation of the December 30th attack on State House. The Khalifa general of the Mourid, Pap Demba Jobe, led the condemnation that came in the form of a protest march at the Kanifing Municipal Council
Malians living in The Gambia Friday marched in their numbers from the Arch 22nd to the City Council in Banjul, in denouncement of the December 30th terrorist attack of State House.
Ahlu Tivaouane Federation, a religious Tijaniyya sect representing all the Daras in The Gambia Thursday strongly condemned the 30th December terrorist attack on State House in Banjul.

column8: Federation of Jamiatul Ansar Ud Deen
column23: The Federation of Jamiyatul Ansarudeen, a Muslim group of the Nyassen sect, on Tuesday joined the global condemnation of December 30th attack on State House, by organising a march in Banjul.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: In March, a secret military court sentenced three soldiers to death and three other soldiers to life in prison on charges of treason, desertion, conspiracy, and mutiny, relating to their alleged involvement in the failed December 2014 coup.
A sit-down protest organized by the University of the Gambia was held by students from 26 to 31 March, to denounce the new grading system.
A sit-down protest organized by the University of the Gambia was held by students from 26 to 31 March, to denounce the new grading system.
A sit-down protest organized by the University of the Gambia was held by students from 26 to 31 March, to denounce the new grading system.
A sit-down protest organized by the University of the Gambia was held by students from 26 to 31 March, to denounce the new grading system.
A sit-down protest organized by the University of the Gambia was held by students from 26 to 31 March, to denounce the new grading system.
A sit-down protest organized by the University of the Gambia was held by students from 26 to 31 March, to denounce the new grading system.

column7: Military Forces of Gambia (1994-) National Intelligence Agency
column23: Brothers Muhammed Fadel Hydara and Hatabu Hydara were reportedly picked up from their homes in Serekunda by alleged NIA members. They have not been seen since

column7: Military Forces of Gambia (1994-) National Intelligence Agency
column23: Alagie Abdoulie Ceesay, manager of Taranga FM radio station, was picked up by NIA agents on July 2 and released July 13, without charge; he was reportedly severely tortured. Ceesay was seen forced into a car in Banjul four days later. He is on trial for sedition and has been refused bail
An armed gang attacked members of the Mim Traditional Council as part of a plot to forcibly remove the local chief.
An angry mob stormed the office of the Mim Police Commander, asking him to step down for failing to stop an armed gang from disrupting a festival that day.
Metro Mass Transit workers held a nationwide demonstration to express their discontent over missing buses at regional depots.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Eight Nigerians were arrested at the weekend by the Ghanaian Navy for allegedly hijacking a fuel vessel from the Nigerian waters.
Residents of Akweteman, a suburb of Accra, on Saturday demonstrated against the Electricity Company of Ghana (ECG) for the erratic power supply in the area

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Police in the Eastern Region have arrested 72 people in Senchi for disturbing the peace in the area. The suspects were arrested on suspicion of "provocation of riots and unlawful assembly."
A Ghanaian fisherman, has been reported dead and three other fishermen missing after a Chinese fishing vessel was hijacked by pirates near Takoradi in the Western Region

Thousands of Ghanaians have taken to the streets in protest of the worsening power outages in the country. The country's opposition New Patriotic Party (NPP),with its leader Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo, leading the proceedings, organised the picket on Thursday.

Mr. Gordon Asubonteng, Dormaa Central Municipal Chief Executive (MCE) was on Monday was welcomed with a miniature-sized rubber bucket of brownish water at Benekwaakrom, a farming community in the Municipality, as a way of registering the community’s concern and displeasure about the Municipal Assembly's failure to address the critical water situation in the area
A group calling itself Muslims Rights Front on Friday petitioned the President to personally intervene to put a stop to the violation of human rights of Muslims in the country

Some members of the Convention Peoples Party (CPP) have embarked on a justice protest to demand the return of confiscated properties belonging to the party after the overthrow of the first President Dr Kwame Nkrumah
Thousands of Ghanaians on Wednesday took to the streets of Kumasi, Ghana’s second most populous city, to protest against the worsening power situation and economic condition in the country

Residents of Asennua, a community in the Kwabre East District of the Ashanti Region, are yet to come to terms with circumstances under which a 49 year old man was killed by a suspected group of military personnel and a police officer at his private residence on Thursday night

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column8: UNMIL: United Nations Mission in Liberia
column23: 234 troops, including 20 Commissioned Officers of UNMIL GHANBATT 21 of the Ghana Armed Forces on Monday departed Ghana for a one-year Peacekeeping Mission in Liberia

The District Chief Executive of Tain, Mr. Samuel Jones Tawiah was held hostage in his official residence several minutes by some irate youth of Nsawkaw, the district capital on March 6, 2015. The action of the youth prevented the district from celebrating the Independence Day. The Nsawkaw Police, with support from the Wenchi Divisional Police Command intervened to bring the situation under control
Hundreds of youths clashed with police in the southern Ghanaian city of Tema, some 38 kilometers east of the capital Accra, during a demonstration against unstable power supply in the area.

Hundreds of traders at the Kejetia lorry terminal on Tuesday besieged the offices of the Kumasi Metropolitan Assembly (KMA) to protest against the planned demolition of their shops under the proposed reconstruction of the Kumasi Central Market

The Forum for Accountable Leadership (FAL) on Thursday led some residents of Tamale to demonstrate against recent ethnocentric pronouncements by Mr Yaw Osafo Marfo, a former Minister of State and member of the New Patriotic Party (NPP)

column8: Civil Society Organizations Platform on Good Governance
column23: Members of the Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) Platform on Good Governance, a network of CSOs in the Northern Region, on Tuesday embarked on a demonstration to register their displeasure at the manner district level elections were being managed in the country
A demonstration by party supporters of the New Patriotic Party (NPP) to draw attention to economic hardships in the country was held on Thursday in Bolgatanga, the Upper East regional capital

Some fishermen from the Central, Western, Volta and the Greater Accra regions on 30 March protested against the dissolution of the Board of the National Premix Commission by the Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development. The fishermen converged at the sector ministry for the demonstration.

About 50 people set ablaze a bull-dozer, which was working on a disputed land in Shai-Osudoku District and almost destroyed a police pick-up vehicle that took the policemen to the site. The police officers and court officials had gone to the area to accomplish an order of execution by an Accra High Court. Their leader has now been arrested by police.

The unending street protests over the prevailing harsh economic conditions took another dimension in Kumasi on Thursday, when an education consultant staged a four-hour, demonstration, to denounce the political leadership

Youth of Ayanfuri staged a demonstration to protest against what they said was the refusal of Perseus Mines to cede part of its concession for small-scale mining. Perseus Mining Companyhas advised the youth of the area to use dialogue
Members of the Ghana Mine Workers Union (GMWU) of Newmont Gold Ghana Limited (NGGL), Ahafo Mine on Tuesday demonstrated against the Management of the company for their unpaid wages and allowances

A group purported to be supporters of the National Democratic Congress (NDC) disrupted a lecture at the Akatsi Teachers' Training College Friday. The lecture was set to be delivered by Vice Presidential hopeful Dr Mahamadu Bawumia of the New Patriotic Party (NPP). The incident, which lasted about two hours was eventually resolved by the intervention of the police.

A clash erupted between supporters of the New Patriotic Party (NPP) and the National Democratic Congress (NDC) on Monday April 20 at Sankore in the Asunafo North District of the Brong-Ahafo Region. Police and military personnel later moved in to restore peace.

There were clashes between the Dagomba and Zamrama traders on Tuesday April 21 after allegation of assault on a Dagomba woman, whose child defecated at an area overseen by a Zamarama man. Police officers fired rubber bullets to dispel the crowd after some exchange of gunfire announced hostilities between the two groups. Reports indicate that two people reported to have died in the tribal clash are alive and receiving treatment at the Korle Bu Teaching hospital

column8: Dagomba Ethnic Group (Ghana); Zamarama Ethnic Group (Ghana)
column23: There were clashes between the Dagomba and Zamrama traders on Tuesday April 21 after allegation of assault on a Dagomba woman, whose child defecated at an area overseen by a Zamarama man. Police officers fired rubber bullets to dispel the crowd after some exchange of gunfire announced hostilities between the two groups.
Residents of Zenu and Atadeka near Ashaiman, on Tuesday embarked on a protest march over the murder of a seven year old girl, Ruth Ankomah, who was allegedly kidnapped and raped by a young mason.

A protracted chieftaincy dispute at Tuobodom in the Brong-Ahafo Region, nearly turned bloody on Monday when supporters of one of the paramount chiefs in the town fired gunshots indiscriminately to scare those of the rival, to register their protest against the District Assembly for failing to invite the other paramount chief to attend the function. Police had to intervene to control the situation.

Residents of Dumasua in the Sunyani West District of the Brong-Ahafo Region on Monday dumped garbage collected from their various homes in front of the chief's private residence in protest against lack of a refuse dump in the town. Police, who were called to the scene, failed to arrest the protesters as they were shielded by the community

Police on Friday clashed with youth of Ejisu demonstrating against their chief, Nana Afranie Okesse 1V, and the Municipal Assembly, over the sale of a portion of the market to a private developer. The scene turned violent when the protesters started throwing stones at the police who responded by throwing teargas
Thousands of Ghanaians marched peacefully through parts of the capital Accra to protest the government's failure to solve a three-year long electric power crisis.
Judicial workers in Ghana went on a strike from Tuesday over unpaid allowances

A fierce confrontation between supporters of Mr Adams Mahama, the deceased Upper East Regional Chairman of New Patriotic Party (NPP) and Mr Paul Afoko, National Chairman of the party was curtailed by the police in Bolgatanga

A misunderstanding between supporters of the chief of Gomoa Otwekrom, a farming community near Agona Kwanyako in the Central Region, Nana Otwe Odartia X and the Abusuapanin of the Asona royal family, Nana Kwabena Abaka last Friday degenerated into an open fight between the two factions leading to two persons sustaining injuries.
A senior reporter with Oman Fm, was on Monday reportedly beaten by two military guards from the Flagstaff House at Ashaiman in the Greater Accra Region.

Staff of the Agricultural Development Bank (adb)on Thursday begun a nationwide sit down strike action demanding the removal of the Managing Director of adb, Stephen Kpordzih and the dissolution of the bank’s Board.

A riot broke out on Saturday at Bolgatanga Technical Institute after a fire reportedly erupted at a three-storey boys’ dormitory on Friday and a first-year student fell from the building in the ensuing stampede. Police had to come in to avoid a breakdown of law and order.
A group calling itself "Concerned Drivers Association of Kumasi" on Tuesday staged a six- hour street demonstration to register their displeasure at their relocation from the Kejetia bus terminal

Sunyani Polytechnic students blocked a portion of the road passing through the front view of the Polytechnic with tyres, logs and stones, in protest against misappropriation of funds by some executives of the student representative council. Police and the military had to use tear gas and rubber bullets to contain the situation and arrested 19 students

A section of traders from the Central Market in Kumasi last Friday evening walked to the Rattray Park which was to be commissioned by His Excellency President John Dramani Mahama to protest against the proposed redevelopment of the Kejetia and Central market project

Protesters from one of Ghana’s biggest slums clashed with police in the capital Accra on Monday, after city authorities demolished shanties as part of measures to combat heavy flooding. Riot police fired teargas at the demonstrators and about 20 people were arrested with a number of officers also injured.

Heavily armed security personnel dispersed traders who had gathered to demonstrate through the principal streets in Kumasi and later present a petition to the Asantehene, Otumfuo Osei Tutu II against plans to evict them to pave way for a redevelopment project. Attempts to evict traders and tram operators at the main Kejetia ended in fiasco yesterday.

Some senior citizens in the Kumasi Metropolis on Wednesday staged a peaceful street demonstration to protest against the intermittent power outages being experienced in the country, popularly known as “Dumsor.”

About 200 young men believed to be Dagombas, on Sunday, June 28, stormed the Ashaiman District Police Headquarters in an attempt to forcibly release from police cells two murder suspects. A team of officers of the Rapid Deployment Force from the Tema Regional Police Command, brought the situation under control with the help of some opinion leaders, who appealed to the irate group to leave the premises.

Some supporters of the New Patriotic Party (NPP) in the Sunyani Municipality, on Tuesday hit the principal street of the Brong-Ahafo Regional capital, to register their protest against the Electoral Commission.

Following by-elections in Talensi, there were clashes between supporters of the ruling NDC and the opposition NPP, including firing of ammunition, leading to the hospitalisation of some victims and the destruction of vehicles.

At last 12 people have been killed in fighting between butchers and guards of a chief in Bimbilla in Ghana’s Northern Region. Police say the shooting involved some butchers and guards of the regent of Nanumba after some butchers allegedly refused to present a portion of their meat to the chief in the area as demanded by tradition

column8: ICU: Industrial and Commercial Workers Union
column23: Over 700 members of the Industrial and Commercial Workers Union (ICU) on Thursday, demonstrated through the streets of Tema against the economic hardship in the country

A misunderstanding on Thursday afternoon between a resident and some worshipers at a mosque at Changli, a suburb of Tamale, led to protests by the worshippers. Police officers were initially chased away before a reinforcement team came that fired warning shots to disperse the crowd.

The Cocoa Farmers Association of Techiman, has petitioned government to intervene in order for Ghana Cocoa Board (COCOBOD) to rescind its decision to relocate the Techiman Cocoa District Office to the western side of Brong-Ahafo Region. The petitioners marched through the principal streets of Techiman Township and ended up at the office of the Municipal Assembly to present a copy of the petition

Some people protested about the current power outage during a ceremony to mark the Eid-Ul-Fitr festival at Nima presided over by National Democratic Congress Member of Parliament (MP) for East Ayawaso.
On July 20, 2015, about 12 naval personnel stormed a beach, stripped civilians of Tema Newtown naked and assaulted them with weapons. Eight people sustained injuries

Students from T.I Ahmadiyya Senior High School in the Northern Regional town of Salaga on Thursday stormed the school's premises and later at the Salaga Police station to protest against the arrest of their mates, where shots were fired resulting in the death of one resident, who joined the students' protest. The clash ensued following the alleged prevention of a slippers-wearing female student from sitting terminal examinations on Wednesday, July 29
Doctors in Ghana have stopped providing emergency care in a strike over allowances and training, union leaders form Ghana Medical Association (GMA) said on Friday

Four people were on Wednesday confirmed dead around 1630 hours, with seven others seriously injured during a shooting incident between two chieftaincy factions at Tuobodom in the Techiman North District of the Brong-Ahafo Region

Some youth crashed with the police at Kwapong in the Asunafo South District on Saturday August 15, 2015, who broke into a ploice station and took away a man whom they lynched, despite the police firing several warning shots. Two people were reportedly shot by the police and one died.
Youths break into a police station and forcebly release a man accused of stabbing an associate to death. They then proceed to fatally lynch the suspect.
Hundreds of traders at the Tema Community One market have demonstrated against the increase in property rates levied by the Tema Metropolitan Assembly (TMA)

Ellenda group organised some youth to riot against the burial of their former chief, Nana Kyeku Anyimiah the IV. Rioters blocked the access road to the town with woods and logs and in the process injured a Police officer on Patrol duties. 10 suspects have been identified

The National Democratic Congress's office was closed for three days by some aggrieved supporters of Mr Samuel Ofosu Ampofo, the 2012 Parliamentary Candidate for the party in the Constituency, who has refused to contest the seat for the second time. Supporters locked the office with padlocks.

200 macho men and 100 NDC supporters in Tema West Constituency raided the constituency office to demonstrate their readiness to attack any executive member who attempts to open the place. They had locked the office since 8 September and declared that they would keep wake at the forecourt of the party office until Samuel Ofosu-Ampofo rescinds his decision not to contest the primary.

column8: Let my Vote Count Alliance; AAG: Alliance for Accountable Governance
column22: Ghanaian Chronicle (Accra); Media Foundation for West Africa
column23: Disagreement over approved routes during demonstrations by pressure groups Let my Vote Count and Alliance for Accountable Governance led to clashes between police and protesters. Several demonstrators were arrested, after warning shots, hot water and rubber bullets were fired at them. dozens sustained injuries. Demonstrators were demanding that the Electoral Commission of Ghana compiles a new voters' register

A chieftaincy dispute between factions of the Atulbabisi clan to the Bolga skin in the Bolgatanga Traditional Area was renewed as gunshots rocked Atulbabisi, leaving seven people injured and about ten houses burnt down. The Regional Police Command deployed officers to control the situation

Several wood traders hurled stones at the military in a bid to prevent the gun wielding soldiers from storming Timber Market. The army officer had jumped behind a commercial motor bike to chase three trucks, believed to be carrying illegal lumber to the Ashaiman Timber Market and killed one person.

The mob used machetes and clubs to beat the victims, killing two and setting their bodies on fire.
President Conde joined a demonstration of several hundred people to a sign a condolence book at the French embassy in light of the Charlie Hebdo attacks in France.

Authorities in Guinea say one person died and three others were seriously wounded after someone threw a grenade into a crowd of people watching a televised soccer match. Some media houses reported the number of fatalities as 3, though the police chief only confirmed 1 death.

column8: UFC: Union of Forces for Change
column23: Thousands of opposition activists rallied in the Guinean capital on Thursday demanding "anyone but Alpha" Conde be returned in presidential polls expected before the end of the year
Around 50 people were injured in riots in the town of Labé in northern Guinea when people protesting a shake-up in the civil service clashed with security forces, the government said on Wednesday

Around a dozen Guineans were wounded Monday in clashes with police after the arrest of an imam who led funeral prayers for a suspected victim of Ebola. Demonstrators put up barricades, burned tyres and overturned rubbish bins in the capital Conakry, before using sticks and stones to attack officers who responded with tear gas and baton charges.
Local media journalist Abdoulaye Oumou was assaulted by police forces while covering a civil society protest against insecurity

One protester was killed and several others shot and wounded Monday as Guinean police battled to control violent demonstrations in the capital Conakry against the regime of President Alpha Conde. The opposition had called for demonstrations across the capital against a lack of stability, which it blames on Conde's government.

column22: Agence France Presse; Radio France Internationale
column23: Fresh violence erupted in the Guinean capital Tuesday after a day of clashes between police and anti-government protesters that left one dead and several with gunshot wounds, AFP correspondents witnessed. A small girl who, according to the government, fell into a culvert when she was fleeing the violence, died during the protests.

At least five people were wounded by gunfire in Guinea’s capital, Conakry, on Monday during violent opposition protests against the timing of elections, an opposition leader and a witness said. Some opposition supporters erected barricades and burned tyres on the streets of the seaside capital while youths fought street battles with the police and gendarmes.
Clashes broke out at midday between demonstrators and police in the suburbs of Conakry, with at least five civilians sustaining minor injuries, witnesses told AFP.
Security forces in Labe killed a protester and wounded four others, witnesses said Thursday, as opposition supporters clashed with police at anti-government rallies in its largest towns and cities.

More than 20 people were wounded Monday in clashes between anti-government protesters and police in Guinea, the opposition said, as the regime of President Alpha Conde clamped down on nationwide demonstrations. Clashes broke out between youths and security forces in the capital Conakry as demonstrators burned tyres and threw stones at police, who responded with tear gas, witnesses said. Further reports claim one person died from injuries sustained during the protest

Guinean security forces on Thursday clashed with protesters in the capital Conakry who demanded a revision of an election timetable that they say stacks the odds in the regime's favour, an AFP journalist and witnesses said. Young men threw stones at the security forces, who responded with teargas in some areas.
Local media journalist Ibrahima Sory Diallo was seriously assaulted by police forces whle covering a protest in Cosa

Riot police in Guinea used tear gas to break up a rally on Saturday demanding the return of a former military ruler who wants to run for president despite facing charges related to a 2009 massacre.
Hundreds of women in in N'zerekore in Guinea’s southeast have gone on a hunger strike to demand the return of an ex-junta leader who wants to come home from exile and run for president.

Split of 100 million GNF offered by Condé to Labé region for women and youth led to clashes in Dalein, Tountouroun and Mali communes. In Tountouroun, young people held local officials captive to get their right share of the money.

Dozens of supporters of the National Coalition for Change protested in Gagnoa, Aboisso, Bonoua, and Guiglo. In Bonoua, they set up roadblocks and police dispersed them using tear gas.

column8: KANU: Kenya African National Union; FORD: Forum for the Restoration of Democracy
column23: KANU and FORD supporters protest in Bomet. Police fired tear gas to disperse crowds.
Clashes between cattle thieves and vigilante militia in Nyaimbitnu and Nyangusu. 3 killed.
After a police car veered off the road and killed a woman, 500 people armed with stones and weapons attacked police in Makombo market, Nyamira.  Polcie opened fire and killed 2. 6 officers injured.
Residents protest the police clashes with vigilante militia, which occurred the day before.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Police recovered and destroyed 9 motor bombs discovered on outskirts of Nairobi.
Cane cutters went on strike and burned the factory in Awendo. Police used tear gas and fired shots to disperse rioters. Several injured.
At least 10 killed, and women raped in June in Laikipia by unknown group in military uniforms.
Scrap metal dealers protest taxes through a boycott.
Students in Nakuru shattered windows protesting against a plan to cut a road through the school.

column11: IOM: International Organisation for Migration; Police Forces of Kenya (1978-2002)
column22: Agence France Presse; East African Standard
column23: Rioters storm Dadaab camp to protest against the IOM for job discrimination.  Rioters blocked roads, pelted IOM vehicles with stones, and smashed windows. Several injured and taken to hospital. Police used tear gas. 29 arrested.
200 workers of Lake Basin Develpoment Authority protested being fired.
Local imam shot and injured in his home.
Rioters closed Nairobi-Nakuru road for several hours to protest a hit-and-run incident.
Rioters set fire to a farm.

column22: Agence France Presse; UN Integrated Regional Information Networks
column23: Somali national lobbed a grenade at MSF offices in Mandera, killing 1 and injuring 4 others.
Somali women delegates to peace talks in Nairobi demonstrate, calling for a conclusion to the peace process.
Vigilante militia lynch 7 suspected criminals in Kisii.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Peace talks begin between Sudanese military and SPLA/M in Nakuru.
2 chief administrators in Kisii hacked to death and shot in their homes.
Rioters set fire to houses of a suspected hit squad that killed 2 chiefs earlier in the day, and rioters severely beat a teacher.  Police deployed.  Several arrested.
500 protesters demonstrated in Suneka town, Kisii, condemning the killing of two local chiefs.

column22: Kenyan KBC; UN Integrated Regional Information Networks
column23: Police officer and his driver killed by a landmine in Marsabit.  8 officers and 2 civilians seriously injured.

Eight people, among them six police officers and the Makutano-Sololo sub-chief were seriously injured in an attack organized by unknown people.The attackers armed with hand grenades and heavy machine-guns destroyed a dispensary at the Dambala Fachana area.
Kiambu residents protested Commission of Inquiry's decision to conduct meetings in private.
Kakamega residents and members of the Angican Church of Kenya protest increased insecurity.
200 residents of Kimoriot village in Baringo held a demonstration in support of the MP who was barred from entering Muchongoi.
Unknown gunmen kill The Nation journalist outside of his home in Nairobi, shot and injured the house watchman. Gunmen did not take any possessions.
2 policemen and 4 others killed, and 1 policeman wounded, in an ambush in Manyatta near Lokitaung.
Landlords in Eldoret demonstrate against farmers' attempts to claim plots.
Students go on a hunger strike to demand that the minister of education be fired.
Workers at Eldoret airport staged a demonstration against the ban on cargo flights.
Students at two schools in Kwale go on strike over accused nepotism by head priest.

column11: Private Security Forces (Kenya); Police Forces of Kenya (2002-2013)
column23: Rioters destroyed fences and raided a farm in Kiplombe. 5 watchmen injured and taken to the hospital. Rioters threw stones at police when they arrived.
Student riot by destroying school property.
Students go on strike.
Students go on strike.
Students go on strike.
Students go on strike.
Traders demonstrate to protest against transfer of British soldiers.
Students riot and destroy school property with stones, complaining of harsh punishment by deputy headmaster.
Students riot and destroy school property with stones, complaining of harsh punishment by deputy headmaster.
Busniessmen go on strike demanding salaries.
Muslims protest against proposed anti-terrorism bill, saying it targets Muslims.
Clashes between Galwina and Bana clans from Somalia in Eldoret. 8 arrested.
500 students at Chinga high school in Othaya rioted and destroyed windows at school, protesting lack of entertainment on weekends.
100 students at Mugunda secondary in Kieni broke school gates to protesting the arrest of their driver.
50 MPs walk out of parliament in protest over the rejected motion to discuss harassment of journalists.
Church members protested against the transfer of ministers.
Students burn down a dormitory in Taita Taveta district (coordinates of capital Mwatate used), in protest of the hiring policies of the school.
Anti-torture protests.
8 injured in clashes between Galwina and Bana clans from Somalia in Eldoret. Police deployed, 14 arrested.
Farmers protest a deduction in bonuses.
Former street children demonstrate demanding to be taken to the National Youth Service College.
Tea farmers in Kisii demonstrate against an order to take part in the election of new Kenya Tea Development Agency directors.
Students destroy school property in Kirinyaga.
Students destroy school property in Kiini.

Students destroy computers, lab equipment and windows at school, in protest of students being suspended the prior week. Police fire tear gas and bullets in the air. Students pelted police with stones.
Students destroy school property and burned dorms in protest of the decision to suspend video shows and discos. Several arrested.
Rioters destroyed a fence and raided forest land set aside for the construction of a memorial near Keiyo.
Truck drivers protest the arrest of colleagues.

column11: FORD-Asili: Forum for the Restoration of Democracy-Asili
column23: A Ford-Asili official is shot by suspected cattle rustlers at the controversial Masurura Farm in Migori county. The official survived the attack.
Unknown group from Ethiopia dressed in military uniforms attacked Anan village in Moyale, killing 3.
Nairobi City Council employees protest lack of pay.
100 supporters of defeated parliamentary nominee Wamalwa (RPK) demonstrate in Kitale, calling for nullification of results.
Vigilante militia lynch 6 suspected murderers in Matharite, Gatara and Kabanya (Gitiri) villages, all in Kiharu District.
Protests demanding the revocation of grabbed land that was allocated to government officials. Priest arrested and beat by police, suffered chest and arm injuries.
Gigiri residents protest over grabbing of land by private developers.
Gunmen attack MP in his home in Nairobi.
Public school lecturers go on strike for pay.
Public school lecturers go on strike for pay.

Students and staff of Utalii College boycotted classes in protest at appaointment of new principal.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Unexploded bomb found in Mikaru district in Nyandarua District.
Wamalwa (RPK) supporters protest his partliamentary election defeat. One protester beaten and injured by NARC opposition supporters. No reports of serious injuries.
Kenya Knit Garments Ltd workers went on strike demanding to be allowed to join a union. Rioters threw things at passing cars and police. Police fired tear gas.
Pro-Okemo (KANU) demonstrations.
Pro-Okemo (KANU) demonstrations.
Pro-Okemo (KANU) demonstrations.
Pro-Okemo (KANU) demonstrations.
Vigilante militia attack suspected robbers with sticks and crude weapons. 2 killed, 2 injured.
MP Joseph Korir (KANU) supporters riot against NARC supporters. Police intervened.
Following riots earlier in the day, NARC supporters demonstrated, carrying twigs and signs denouncing Korir (KANU).
Striking matatu operators called for resignation of cabinet minister.
Matatu drivers go on strike.
Matatu drivers go on strike.
Matatu drivers go on strike.

Matatu drivers go on strike.

Matatu drivers go on strike.
Protests against the removal of East African Portland Cement managing director.
Youth petrol-bombed a Metro shuttle bus on Jogoo road. One passenger injured.
Rioters involved in taxi strike blocked roads, lit bonfires and beat up motorists driving along Kilgoris-Kisii road.
Protesters allege governmnet cover up of murder of university worker.
Protests in Bondo against decision to suspend Yala River basin project.
Protests in Siaya against decision to suspend Yala River basin project.
Tea farmers go on strike against poor terms of employment.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: FNL and Burundi military enter peace talks in Nairobi.

Clashes between rioters from rival taxi driver teams. 20 passengers injured when rioters blocked the highway in Kirinyaga along Nyeri-Nairobi highway, and pelted cars with stones and broke windows. No reports of serious injuries. Police fired bullets in the air and used tear gas.
3,700 council workers on strike demanding November salaries. Cargo clearing agents also protested in Mombasa, protesting against bribery and shortage of staff.
Rice farmers protest exploitation by the national irrigation board.
Disabled hawkers blocked entrances to Jongoo House, Nairobi, demanding to see the VP over alleged harasment by security guards.
Woman prisoner raped and beat in cell.
Anti-US Marines protests by pastoralist that claim animals vaccinated by Marines died after treatment.
Mungiki militia raided Wakulima market, injuring traders.
5,000 traders marched in protest of Mungiki raid on Wakulima market earlier in the day.
Muslim rioters attempted to eject US Marines from a Garissa hotel, pelted people with stones and toched US flags, and mounted roadblocks. Riot police arrived. 40 injured.
Pirates attack and injure 14 fishermen in Got Rateng.
Protests against bus fare increases.
Hundreds of Sudanese demonstrate to press for peace in Sudan.
Kenya Bus Service drivers go on stroke for better pay.
Government employees rioted and set fires, blocked roads to protest against delayed payments.

column8: FORD-Kenya: Forum for the Restoration of Democracy Kenya
column23: Ford-Kenya youth stoned vehicles of VP along Bungoma-Mumias road. Windows shattered, no injuries.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: 3 unexploded bombs recovered in Gilgil.
Pokot and Marakwet herdsmen clash over pasture lands near Kombases, Tunyo. Several injured. Police intervened.
Vigilante militia killed 6 suspected thiefs in Kibera area. 3 beat to death and 3 burnt with tyres around their necks.
Gunmen shoot and injure deputy commissioner policeman outside of his home in Nairobi.
5 dead in land clashes in Kapchorwa near border of Uganda. Police deployed.
Gunmen shoot 1 policeman dead and injure another.
Riots after police shoot three suspected robbers in a nightclub in Molo.
MPs walk out of Kitui meetings of protest of National Alliance Party (NAK) member Ngilu attending.

column8: KMJA: Kenya Magistrates and Judges Association
column23: Judges and magistrates began a 25-day protests to press for justice for colleagues indicted by the Ringera report.
Shareholders for Lorian Ranching Company marched in the streets alleging that directors embezzled funds.
City council workers gather at Treasury Square protest salary arrears. Police fired tear gas.
City council workers gather at Treasury Square for the second day to protest salary arrears. Police fired tear gas.
Rioters blocked roads to protest development of land.

column11: LDP: Liberal Democratic Party; Police Forces of Kenya (2002-2013)
column23: LDP secretary general Kamotho's car was stoned by rioters in Mathioya. Police used tear gas. Before the convoy arrived, rioters blocked roads and stoned constitutency aid committee workers. One sustained head and leg injuries.
Christians protest the establishment of Muslim Kadhi courts. Police allegedly clobbered and injured protesters.
Kenyatta Hospital staff protested against businessmen operating on land next to the hospital.
Cane farmers protest the importation of cheap sugar.
Cane farmers protest the importation of cheap sugar.
Cane farmers protest the importation of cheap sugar.
Cane farmers protest the importation of cheap sugar.
Cane farmers protest the importation of cheap sugar.
MPs bodyguard shot and killed.
Demonstrations demanding the removal of the police administrators.
Farmers from Ol Kalou stormed the Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission headquarters in Nairobi to demand a report on a complaint lodged a year prior.
Protests against new charges for agricultural products.
Students hold peaceful demonstration to demand the construction of speed bumps.
University of Nairobi students blocked streets and stoned motorists to protest increased fees.
Kenyatta University students blocked Thika-Nairobi Highway in protest of rising costs of transport. Police fired tear gas. Minor injuries reported.
City council workers go on strike demanding payment.
Kenya Electricity Generating Company workers went on strike for better working conditions.
Kenya Electricity Generating Company workers went on strike for better working conditions.
Kenya Electricity Generating Company workers went on strike for better working conditions.

Farmers from Uasin-Gishu and North-Nandi districts protest milk price cuts.
