Lodwar residents protested the burning of two villages by prisoners and prison guards.
Nursing students go on strike over fee increase.
Nursing students protest increased fees.
Secondary school students riot and destroy property.
Students protest over lack of food. Pelted vehicles and offices with stones. Police used batons and seriously injured one student.
Students destroy property at a farm in Nakuru, protesting the withdrawal of food to the school. Police fired tear gas. Injured one student seriously with a baton.

column8: KPAWU: Kenya Plantation and Agricultural Workers' Union
column23: Union workers protest use of machines to pick tea.

column8: KPAWU: Kenya Plantation and Agricultural Workers' Union; Farmers (Kenya)
column23: Tea farmers union protest plans to use machines to pick tea.
6 Kenyas and 15 Somali injured in fighting between Merihan sub-clans in Bulahawa.
Sugar farmers protest delayed payments.
Sugar farmers protest delayed payments.
Former Mungiki Militia member was killed after leaving the militia and converting to Christianity. His head was found in a dumpster at a bus stop in Nairobi.

column8: KPAWU: Kenya Plantation and Agricultural Workers' Union; Farmers (Kenya)
column23: Tea farmers union protest plans to use machines to pick tea.

column8: KPAWU: Kenya Plantation and Agricultural Workers' Union; Farmers (Kenya)
column23: Tea farmers union protest plans to use machines to pick tea.
Secondary school students burn a dorm and library in protest of extra fees.
Students set fire to Nyang'ori High School.
Mungiki militia slashed residents with panga knives in Mlango Kubwa area of Pangani after police arrested seven militia leaders.
Mungiki kill a man with swords in Othaya bus terminal.
Residents of Bogiakumu destroyed property belonging to suspected murderers that the court released.
Sand trucks block roads at Mai Mahiu in protest of increased sand prices.
Parents protested against alleged grabbing of school land.
Students barricaded Bunyala Road and stoned motorist in protest of of school's alleged failure to pay medical costs of an injured colleague. Police fired tear gas.
Police shoot and injure two mourners who were protesting alleged police involvement in the killing of a resident.

column11: UNHCR: United Nations Refugee Agency; Refugees/IDPs (Sudan)
column23: 22 Sudanese refugees injured in riots at Kakuma camp, sparked by the alleged unfair distribution of bicycles by the UNHCR.
Demonstrations against government removal of security for certain ministers.
Woman killed on her farm by unknown group.
Rioters blocked road and lit bon fires in Mau Narok-Nairobi road to protest increased ethnic violence in the area. Police fired live bullets to disperse rioters.
Protests for increased security in Bondeni.
Traders protest closure of banks.
Vigilante youth with bows, arrows and spears injure civilians and burn houses in Munyes village near Bomet.
Protests against plans to build a sugar factory in Garsen.
Rioters stoned Oxfam offices in Wajir over high prices of food.
Lawyers gather to protest lack of magistrates.
Rioters attack and seriously injure farm guards.
Kenyatta National Hospital staff marched in streets and went on strike in protest of unpaid salaries.
Squatters threw stones at former Taveta MP Basil Criticos, damaged his vehicle, and burned houses and churches on Critico's farm land. 4 injured.
MPs boycott parliament in protest against a Consensus Bill.
Kenyatta National Hospital staff marched in streets and went on strike in protest of unpaid salaries.
Thousands of property owners gather at city hall to protest increased land rates.
Residents blocked Kitui road in Mwala to protest the entry of an alleged exorcist from Tanzania.
Human rights activists block VP Awori's motorcade and Harambee Ave in protest human rights record of police.

Somali MPs riot against each other in fight over no-confidence vote involving Somali MP of the Transitional Federal Government Ali Gedi, during a peace conference in Mbagathi in Nairobi. 1 MP seriously injured. 10 others injured.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Unknown group torched houses in Keiyo.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Unknown group torched houses in Makunga.
Rival supporters attack NLP supports at polling station. 5 injured and sent to hospital.

column11: NARC: National Rainbow Coalition; Police Forces of Kenya (2002-2013)
column23: Youth rioters attack voters in Kisauni alleging that they were buying votes for NARC candidates. Vehicles damaged. 8 injured. Police fired in the air, and polling station closed.
Non-teaching staff at Egerton's Njoro campus go on strike after two employees fired.
MP candidate Joseph Kingi and members of NARC injured by rioters at Bawan polling station in Mto Panga.
Wildlife activists marchi in Nairobi.
100 youths with crude weapons brought down a fence on former cabinet minister Nicholas Biwott's property. One guard injured.
Protests against the arrest of MP Moroto.  Police injure two people in dispersing the crowds.  No reports of serious injuries.
100 prisoners go on hunger strike against slow pace of their cases being handled in courts.
Teachers union protest occupation of primary schools by security forces.
Traders protest council's spending of state funds.
Rioters burned a farm owned by a British citizen in protest against UK travel ban on Kenyan MP.
University teachers go on strike over unpaid salaries. Students protests on campus over the boycott.

Rioters destroyed structures in a park in Kitale to protest the grabbing of land by private investors. Police fired live bullets and tear gas. 20 injured. No reports of serious injuries. Several arrested, including a priest.
Clashes between Ugandan cattle rustlers and Kenyan police. 3 killed.
Teachers march to protest being housed in dorms.
At least 4 killed in tribal clashes.
One man hacked to death in Kilia.
Protests against proposal to separate Narok and Kajiado districts.
Vigiliante militia killed 4 and burned houses of people suspected of witchcraft.
Youths protest against an LDP rally.
Export Processing Zone workers went on strike over their colleagues being fired. Stoned motorists and lit fires on the road in Athi River. Police fired tear gas.
Ethiopian armed forces abduct 16 Kenyans. Later released at after interrogation at the border in Ethiopia.
Clashes between police and Ethiopian armed group in Dukana.

column22: Agence France Presse; Kenyan KTN TV; East African Standard; The Nation
column23: Ethiopian raiders clash with police and civilians El Hadi. At least 19 killed over two day raid, including 2 police and 11 raiders (10 fatalities coded for July 6, and 9 coded for July 7). 18 missing.

column22: Agence France Presse; Kenyan KTN TV; East African Standard; The Nation
column23: Ethiopian raiders clash with police and civilians El Hadi. At least 19 killed over two day raid, including 2 police and 11 raiders (10 fatalities coded for July 6, and 9 coded for July 7). 18 missing.
Students burn a dorm in protest of lack of water at the school.
Sugar farmers boycott supply of sugar to Chemelil Sugar Factory.
Rioters attack and injure journalists.
Hawkers rioted, threw stones and lit bonfires. Police fired tear gas and live bullets. 1 rioter and 1 policeman killed.
Thousands protest against a new district headquarters at Nkubu.
Group supporting shariah courts in Somalia clashed with pro-Somali Government demonstrators and burn their placards.
Riots at City Hall broke out after Nairobi mayor re-elected. Councillors exchange blows and a gun is drawn during the melee.
LDP supporters beat up 3 youth during Nakuru by-election.

Vigilante militia lynch a suspected cattle rustler in Ndimu-Karai. In a revenge attack later in the day, another vigilante militia burn 20 houses and injure a woman with a machete in Murinduko village. (Murinduko coordinates used for both events).
Mortuary staff strike for better working conditions.
HIV-positive Kenyans march in protest against proposed amendments that would make treatments unaffordable.
Export Processing Zone workers continued protests in Athi River.
Officer killed at Kanyerus camp by a bomb fired by UPDF.
Clash between police and Ajuran militia in Ambalo in Moyale District. 2 police injured.
Protests against creation of new district in Narok
Protests against alleged misappropriation of development funds.
Protests against proposed power taiffs.
Attackers poured acid on five officials at the Nairobi liason office of the SPLM.

column8: KNUT: Kenya National Union of Teachers
column11: KNUT: Kenya National Union of Teachers
column23: Fights broke out between opposing members of the Kenya National Union of Teachers. 2 delegates servely injured.
Demonstrations against the Lebanon-Israeli war.
Demonstrations against the Lebanon-Israeli war.
LDP supporters protest the nullification of election results.
400 construction workers on the Miritini-Maji ya Chumyi section of Mombassa-Nairobi highway strike over pay.
3 Somali refugees killed by unknown group in Kakuma camp.
Teachers protest against ill treatment by training session organisers.
Rioters storm a voter registration centre in Gucha and beat up clerks.
Rioters raided Yala rice farm and whipped workers, demanding to be given their jobs back.
1 Somali killed, several injured when unknown group stormed Kakuma camp.
Demonstrations against alleged harassment by traffic officers.
Prisoners go on hunger strike in protest of alleged assaults when warders conducted searches.
Raiders from Samburu clash with police and civilians in Tangi area of Laikipia. 7 killed including one policeman.
Hawkers march to protest the alleged killing of a friend. Police fired tear gas.
A burnt man's body is discovered at a coffee plantation near Kangaru in Engu. Perpetrators not known. The time of death may have been up to three days before its discovery on 03/01.
Boda boda riders and traders protest a new law that prohibits animals to travel through the CBD of Bomet.

Youths took to Ngong Road in Nairobi and adjacent streets to protest the death of former Prime Minister Raila Odinga's son, who died in unclear circumstances. The protesters demanded to know the cause of death. The demo lasted several hours.
Pokot gunmen killed a school guard during the late morning hours. Motive unknown.
Teachers strike, protest over poor working conditions.
Hundreds of Athi River sub county workers protested over a irregular payment from Machakos county government.
Medical worker protesters clash with a group that was attempting to stop them. One man is injured after he was hit in the face with a stone.
Following an attack by armed robbers in Ol Moran village of Laikipia residents protest insecurity.
More than 1,000 teachers from Buuri, North Imenti, South Imenti and Meru Central sub counties protest in Meru. The teachers were on strike, calling for better salaries.
Traders at Kalundu market held a demonstration in Kitui town, protesting against high market charges by the county government.
Fishermen clash with police after officials closed a corridor leading to Lake Naivasha and Karagita beach in Naivasha. No reported injuries.
Two demonstrators were shot and injured by police in Mau Narok during a protest against increased road accidents.

An unidentified attacker targeted a crowded Mombasa church, but are repulsed by police guarding the door. Police engaged the assailant in a shootout before he escaped. The reason for the attack is not known. One church official was reported dead following the incident.

Pokot cattle rustlers struck Namawanga village inhabited by members of the Luhya community and shot dead a local farmer before stealing three bulls from his home. In revenge, Luhya tribesmen hacked to death a Pokot man who operates a motor cycle taxis after they found him ferrying two passengers to Karnyarkwat market. The killing of the man sparked off protest from members of the Pokot community who thronged to Kapkoi market vowing to revenge  over the killing of their tribesmen.

Pokot cattle rustlers struck Namawanga village inhabited by members of the Luhya community and shot dead a local farmer before stealing three bulls from his home. In revenge, Luhya tribesmen hacked to death a Pokot man who operates a motor cycle taxis after they found him ferrying two passengers to Karnyarkwat market. The killing of the man sparked off protest from members of the Pokot community who thronged to Kapkoi market vowing to revenge  over the killing of their tribesmen.
URP supporters disrupt a demonstration in Bomet concerning the location of a university, no reported violence. Police forces dispersed the two groups.

Pokot cattle rustlers struck Namawanga village inhabited by members of the Luhya community and shot dead a local farmer before stealing three bulls from his home. In revenge, Luhya tribesmen hacked to death a Pokot man after they found him ferrying two passengers to Karnyarkwat market. The killing of the man sparked off protest from members of the Pokot community who thronged to Kapkoi market vowing to revenge  over the killing of their tribesmen.
A group of Nairobi-based journalists were ejected from a reception area at the United Nations complex in Kenya's capital after launching a protest over Al-Jazeera journalists jailed in Egypt.
Suburban Nairobi residents set a suspected thief alight.
The Kenya Defence Forces killed eight al Shabaab and injured several others during an encounter with the insurgents in Basuba, Lamu county. A KDF soldier died while three others were injured.
Residents of Machakos hurled stones at county Askaris to stop them from towing away the deputy governor's car. A woman broke her leg when she was allegedly beaten by the Askaris.
Githurai residents on 15/01 morning lynched four people who they accused of engaging in criminal activities in the area.
A group of women protesting in support of circumcision of girls lured activists opposed to the practice and attacked them at Enoosaen Village in Transmara, Narok County. Injuries not known.
Two groups of protesters clash - those for and against a withdrawal of Sh60 million annual sponsorship for four schools in Mtwapa. Injuries not known.

Students and activists protesting against a school land dispute clash with police Lang'ata. Rocks thrown, tear gas implemented. Five pupils, two journalists and a police officer were injured and two activists arrested during the incident. The event became a scandal in the following days after it was learned that several of the injured students were young children.
Three unidentified gunmen shoot and kill an Imam at a construction site in Likoni. Investigators have not established a motive.
Boda boda operators in Amagoro town protest alleged police harassment.
Protesting the availability of jobs offered by a power company, residents block the a road leading to work site in Kargi for several days, holding hostage a truck driver ferrying supplies.
Three men are killed when Kikuyu and Maasai groups clashed over a farm's ownership.
Protesting the availability of jobs offered by a power company, residents block the a road leading to work site in Kargi for several days, holding hostage a truck driver ferrying supplies.
Protesting the availability of jobs offered by a power company, residents block the a road leading to work site in Kargi for several days, holding hostage a truck driver ferrying supplies.
Students of Limuko Secondary School in Bahati protest, demanding the transfer of their principal alleging "highhandedness."
Protesting the availability of jobs offered by a power company, residents block the a road leading to work site in Kargi for several days, holding hostage a truck driver ferrying supplies.
Transporters blocked the highway near Mlolongo on 26/01 to protest the closing of access roads by police, who they charged with corruption.

At least two people were feared dead and dozens others wounded in Narok when protests to oust Governor Samuel Tunai turned chaotic. The protesters accused the governor of corruption. Among those wounded was area police chief Paul Letting and two of his juniors, police said of the protests, which brought Narok town to a standstill for several hours. At least one of the dead was shot by police. Several arrests were recorded in the following days, including five Senators.
A group of Boba Boda operators lynch a 16-year old girl of suspected theft.

Protestors in Narok county on Wednesday night blocked roads in the area after Senator Stephen Ole Ntutu and four legislators were earlier arrested over demonstrations that occurred on Monday.  The protestors who were armed with sticks and arrows blocked the road in Ololunga area and another in Katagala for more than two hours over the arrests, demanding their release. Police had to fire tear gas at the protestors to disperse them.

Protestors in Narok county on Wednesday night blocked roads in the area after Senator Stephen Ole Ntutu and four legislators were earlier arrested over demonstrations that occurred on Monday.  The protestors who were armed with sticks and arrows blocked the road in Ololunga area and another in Katagala for more than two hours over the arrests, demanding their release. Police had to fire tear gas at the protestors to disperse them.

Protesters continue their demonstration against the detention of a group of lawmakers. Protestors blocked traffic on the Nairobi-Narok highway, police responded with teargas and live fire, clashes followed. No reported deaths.
Students in Wajir protest a teacher shortage in the area.
Political activists (affiliation not known) march in Kapsabet for unknown reason.

Nairobi Aviation College students blocked Kimathi Street to protest an unflattering expose on sale of certificates aired on television. The students, who carried twigs and college banners, threw stones at Nation Centre breaking doors and windows and chased journalists who were taking pictures. Police dispersed the students twice, the second time after they had regrouped. Tear gas used. 12 arrests reported.
800 Mandera teachers protest al Shabaab spurred insecurity in their region at the KNUT headquarters in Nairobi. After several hours the group marched to the parliament building.
A suspect in the murder of a boda boda operator in Sindo, Suba subcounty, was snatched from the police by residents and beaten to death in Sindo.

Four killed and several injured during a Pokot raid on a Turkana village. Authorities claimed the attacks were meant to scare members of the Turkana community into leaving Lomelo, Silale and Nadome villages, which Pokots have laid claim.

Police fired teargas at students of Kenya Medical Training College who were protesting over the death of their classmate. The student had committed suicide after being removed from an exam over unpaid fees.

Police have fired in the air and lobbed teargas to disperse hundreds of City Park Market traders who are protesting the burning down of their stalls, which they claim was sabotage. The traders blocked Limuru Road to traffic, demanding compensation from the government after the fire destroyed their goods and other properties. The rioters threw stones at passing motorists and police.

Three people were critically injured after a hand grenade was hurled at a food kiosk in Mandera town. The reason for the attack is not known. The perpetrators escaped. Authorities suspect one of the victims may have been linked to al Shabaab.

Traders pelted Nairobi Governor Evans Kidero with mud during an appearance. The trader's stalls were burned the previous evening for which the traders blamed the local government. The governor's bodyguards shot into the air to disperse the mob.

A group of cattle herdsmen blocked the Mai Mahiu-Narok road (B3) for several hours after several of the herd were killed when they were hit with a lorry. The herdsmen demanded compensation for their loss by the colliding driver. They barred police officers from removing the truck or the carcasses until the matter was resolved.

A prominent Kenyan MP of the Jubilee Coalition (George Muchai) was shot dead along with two bodyguards and a driver in the centre of Nairobi in the early hours of 07/02. The masked perpetrators, who were driving an automobile with Ugandan licence plates, escaped. A senior police officer said the killing looked like an execution-style hit.

Traders in Molo town held a demonstration to protest against the poor state of the Molo-Kibunjia road. The traders barricaded the road with stones and flaming tyres, saying the government is deliberately ignoring them.
Residents of Kabete constituency held a demonstration at Wangige trading centre over the pace of investigations into area MP George Muchai's murder, which occurred on 07/02.

Traders of Burma Market, Nairobi used flaming tyres to block Jogoo Road in a demo against alleged land grabbing on [the morning of 13/02]. The traders hurled stones at motorists preventing access to the road and causing a traffic snarl up. [The rioters] engaged police in running battles as tear gas canisters were lobbed to disperse them.
Police in Thika shot in the air to disperse a crowd who had planned on attacking an officer who they believed had earlier assaulted a woman.
Unknown assailants on the evening of 13/02 hurled two hand grenades at police officers on patrol in Wajir town. No reported injuries.

Embu Governor Martin Wambora's supporters (TNA) and those of Runyenjes MP Cecily Mbarire (Party of National Unity) clash. Wambora's supporters were demonstrating against the High Court's decision to remove Wambora from office when those supporters of Mbarire attacked the group leading to melee. The two groups engaged in running battles before riot police intervened. Injuries not reported.
Residents of Umande, Laikipia East sub county, held a demonstration against the abstraction of Sirimon River by a privately held dam.
A mob stones a suspected murderer to death.

Groups of students clashed along ethnic lines with "members of the community" over the removal of the university's vice chancellor over alleged sexual misconduct and murder. The identities of the ethnic groups are not known. No reported injuries or causalities in the second melee.
A boda boda operator was killed by colleagues and his body set on fire (18/02) on the Webuye-Malaba road at Chekulo, Bungoma. The victim was suspected of murder.

A Senator and ten others are assaulted by riot police when they staged a protest at the University of Eldoret in an effort to force the removal of the vice chancellor Teresa Akenga, whom area leaders accused of nepotism and skewed employment. The protest was reported as peaceful.
Hundreds of Voi residents took to the streets on 19/02 in a protest for the arrest of a Marungu ward rep over alleged sexual abuse.
Students protest violently for a second day against sexual misconduct alleged against a school leader.
Residents of Ukasi, Mwingi Central, hold a peaceful demonstration to protest against prolonged water shortage.

Farmers blocked the Nairobi-Naivasha highway in Kinangop for more than four hours protesting a wind project which they allege would displace several families. During the protest, a house and a vehicle were burnt down as the farmers engaged police in running battles. There were unconfirmed reports that two women and a boy were rushed to a private hospital with bullet wounds.
Street traders hold a "mostly peaceful" demonstration in Kutui over a tax levied against them. No report of violence.
Farmers protest in Kinangop for a second day, engage in running battles with police. One dead, several others injured.

University of Nairobi students protested the death of their colleague who succumbed to injuries following an pedestrian-auto accident last week. The students pelted vehicles passing through Waiyaki Way and University Way with stones, causing a traffic problems.
Tugan and Pokot militias exchange fire over grazing land and cattle ownership at Kapndasum in Marigat. An unarmed bystander was killed in the shootout, several others missing.

More than 200 businesspeople in Kisii town staged a demonstration to protest against grabbing of land where they operate. The traders protested against a decision by the county government to move them from outside the Kisii Municipal Market.
Three quarters of students at Leshau Boys' High School boycotted classes, protesting alleged poor hygiene in the institution. The students marched peacefully to the Nyahururu-Nyeri highway.
Boda boda drivers protest a tax increase over two consecutive days in Mumias.

One person was killed and two others injured in an attack by suspected Al-Shabaab gunmen in Mandera Town on the night of 25/02. The victims were witnessed crossing from nearby Somalia at an earlier date and are suspected to be Somalis
Boda boda drivers protest a tax increase over two consecutive days in Mumias.
Television viewers protest analogue signal switch off at outside Communications Authority offices on Waiyaki Way, Nairobi. The switch off forces viewers to purchase a digital apparatus.
A vigilante group attack and sets alight four robbery suspects at different nearby locations: Three in Kathiani and one in Kituvu.
A vigilante group attack and sets alight four robbery suspects at different nearby locations: Three in Kathiani and one in Kituvu.

Students of ST Mathias Busia Boys' Secondary School strike over test grades, vandalise school property, broke into teachers' residential houses, staff rooms, offices, and stores, the canteen and laboratories. No reported injury.
Following an road accident involving students, students of Thiru Secondary School barricade a road in protest.
Students of Chebara Boys' Secondary School, Marakwet West, held a demonstration, demanding the removal of principal, whom they accused of mismanagement.
Teachers of a Mandera school are attacked and injured when students from a neighbouring school targeted them in blame for the cancellation of recent exams.
Students of Kilgoris Boys National School pelt their principal's home with stones following learning of poor exam results.
Residents of Mukurwe-ini marched to the sub-county hospital's mortuary and took away the body of a man who was allegedly shot by a police officer in protest of the killing.
Residents of Tseikuru protest, demand the removal of the local district commissioner. Police dispersed the group.
Two unidentified sub tribes clash over land at Kathanje (Kathangei), Chuka Igambangombe constituency. One death, plus other injuries reported.
More than 200 Kisii county government employees demonstrated at Governor James Ongwae's office protesting they have not been paid for nine months.
A vigilante mob attacks and nearly killed a suspected cattle thief at Likuyani subcounty, Kakamega.

West Pokot county residents held a demonstration to protest against increase in road accidents on the Kitale-Lodwar road. The residents barricaded the road for the better part of the day, halting transport. They felled big trees on the road, blocking it completely at Kamatira market. Kamatira Primary School pupils also joined the demonstration, saying many of their colleagues have died on the road.
Traders protest an eviction notice along the Malaba-Eldoret road.
Al Shabaab attack, and then later claim responsibility for the death of four in Wajir. Three other injured.

Three people were killed and eight more wounded when al Shabaab launched a cross-border raid on a convoy carrying Mandera county governor Ali Roba. The governor escaped unharmed. The convoy was travelling either to or from Nairobi.
Employees of Kenya Methodist University protest a reduction of their allowances by the institution.
Al Shabaab carries out the second attack in two days in Mandera. One death, three injuries reported. In the following days the death total was raised from 1 to 4.
An IED explodes in Mandera following a similar attack across the Somali border in Beled Hawo. No reported causalities.
Four are killed and their bodies burnt in a grenade attack on a Wajir shop. Perpetrators not known.
The Member of County Assembly for Korogocho was shot and killed during an attack in Ruaraka, Nairobi on the morning of 18/03. The motive for the attack is not known.
Hundreds of Mandera County residents took to the streets of the border town on 20/03 protesting over recent insecurity in the area. The protesters called for the removal of the county commissioner.

A riotous mob attacked a man, killed him and burnt down his house (in Itumbu) after suspecting him of being in a criminal gang. The attack came after villagers carried out a violent protest against insecurity in the region. A protester was injured after the suspect's son tried to stop them from burning their house. A similarly motivated protest occurred the previous day. The protesters burnt three houses belonging to a family suspected of harbouring a criminal gang.

A riotous mob attacked a man, killed him and burnt down his house (in Itumbu) after suspecting him of being in a criminal gang. The attack came after villagers carried out a violent protest against insecurity in the region. A protester was injured after the suspect's son tried to stop them from burning their house. A similarly motivated protest occurred the previous day. The protesters burnt three houses belonging to a family suspected of harbouring a criminal gang.
Residents of Mandera County demonstrate against recent area violence by al Shabaab. Date not known: source dated 21/03.

A riotous mob attacked a man, killed him and burnt down his house (in Itumbu) after suspecting him of being in a criminal gang. The attack came after villagers carried out a violent protest against insecurity in the region. A protester was injured after the suspect's son tried to stop them from burning their house. A similarly motivated protest occurred the previous day. The protesters burnt three houses belonging to a family suspected of harbouring a criminal gang.
A groups of youths protest the Mandera Deputy Governor during a rally in Mandara.
Students of Rongo University College state a protest after a residential hall is burned. The protest and fire may be related to a recent election which caused tension in the area.
Parents of two schools in Nakuru hold a demonstration to protest the grabbing of a section of the school land by a private developer.

Residents violently protest the release of two murder suspects on bond. The protesters blocked the nearby Eldoret-Chavakali road for hours and injured one police officer. Additionally, several shops and houses were burned.
A woman was killed, allegedly by police, during a demonstration in Malindi to protest against the tax increase by the Kilifi county government. Police deny they used live rounds.
A suspected murderer is lynched by a vigilante group in Mukuro.
Fruit factory workers protest poor working conditions in Bibirioni, Limuru. Date not clear - source dated 24/03.
A senior Mombasa police detective is gunned down in an apparent well organized assassination. The perpetrator is not unknown, though the source cites al Shabaab presence in the area.
Traders blocked the Eldoret-Nakuru highway at Burnt Forest, protesting against increased licence fees and poor services.
A vigilante mob "last week" lynched a criminal suspect. Source dated 31/03.

A group of Kenyan youths protest a Chinese Restaurant's policy of refusing entry to local people during the nigh time hours. The protest turned violent, however, when the group began looting the restaurant. No injury reported.
Baringo county residents protest reoccurring attack by Pokot bandits. The protesters marched throughout the county, eventually ending in Kabarnet.
Hundreds of travellers heading to either Tanzania or Kenya are stranded at Namanga border after Kajiado residents blocked the road to protest over a missing taxi driver.
Three suspected carjackers are lynched by a mob in Kariene, Meru County.
Two groups of demonstrators in Kilifi clashed outside the Kilifi police station as they differed over whether Governor Amason Kingi should step aside over corruption allegations.

At least one person was killed and three others injured on the morning of 01/04 when masked gunmen attacked a non-governmental organisation's compound at the Dadaab Refugee Camp. The attack occurred during the early morning hours, perpetrators not known.

Al Shabaab gunmen attack Garissa University during the morning hours in an operation that lasted the majority of the day. Four attackers were killed during the siege, and the police are holding another five individuals for questioning.

Al Shabaab gunmen attack Garissa University during the morning hours in an operation that lasted the majority of the day. Almost all of the 148 people killed were students and another 79 people were injured.
Garissa residents protest a recent al Shabaab attack on a school in their town. Date unknown - source dated 04/04.
Hundreds of Kenyan residents have rallied at a state sponsored protest in the capital Nairobi to condemn recent Al-Shabaab attack on Gaarisa University premises.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Police impounded a suspicious vehicle and arrested a unidentified woman when it is suspected she was to bomb an Easter church service in Mombasa. Two additional suspects fled the area. No injuries reported.
Hundreds of Somalis took to the streets in the Nairobi's Somali-dominated Eastleigh neighbourhood on Sunday [5 April] to protest against the recent deadly attack on Garissa university.
Factory workers protest a dispute with management.
Students protest the Garissa attack in Nairobi, calling on the government to do more for security.
Traders in Limuru protest increased fees. Date(s) not known - the protest was described as "ongoing."

The bodies of two men are discovered in Kamirithu village on the morning of 08/04. Their deaths may have occurred the evening before. The motive of the attack as well as their identifies of the victims are not known.
Traders in Kisii protest a tax increase.
Protesters of police practices stone a journalist covering the event. The journalist suffered a head and knee injury.
Kenyan police on 11/04 shot dead two al Shabaab suspects in an incident that left one police officer injured in Kwale.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Police uncover and remove an IED in Mandera County, near the Somali border on 12/04.
Pokot militia kill a goat herder in Chemoe.
A mob lynched two suspected cattle thieves in Likuyani subcounty, Kakamega.
A suspected rustler was killed by a mob in Central Kanyamkago ward, Uriri subcounty in Migori county. One of his accomplices was injured while the rest escaped.

Transport on the Nairobi-Mai Mahiu road in Lari constituency, Kiambu county was disrupted by a four hour demonstration (it is not clear if the demonstrators blocked the roadway) by transporters of building materials. They were protesting the new Sh400 per trip levy.
Traders protest county taxes in Thika.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Ten armed members of al Shabaab hijack a bus carrying ten passengers, deboard them and take the bus across the border into Somalia. No violence reported.
Hospital workers protest unpaid dues.

Boda Boda operators block a road and light fires in protest against a police "crackdown" against them. They said police ask for bribes and frequently arrest them for no genuine reason. A similar protest was held the following day in a nearby area.
Boda Boda operators protest alleged police harassment by barricading the Narok-Bomet road.
10,000 members of the National Hospital Insurance Fund in Nyandarua county protest against a rate increase in Ndunyu Nderu.

Heavily armed gunmen suspected to be members of Al-Shabaab on the morning of 23/04 kidnapped senior Arabia chief in Mandera County along the Mandera-Arabia road. The chief was driven across the border into Somalia where he was killed at Gadoon Dhowe, Beled Xawo District.
Suspected Somali Al-Shabaab kidnapped two Kenyan teachers on the evening of 24/04 in the Mandera border town.
The more than 100 traders held a demonstration in Gakindu town over a closed slaughterhouse that they claim cannot be reopened due to bureaucratic oversight.
Residents of Ndagani, in Igambang'ombe constituency on the morning of 27/04 blocked the Meru- Nairobi highway to protest against the poor sate of Ndagani-Gicusa road.
Workers protest poor working conditions and pay in Jomvu.
Hundreds of traders from Nairobi's Woodley-Jamhuri market protested alleged grabbing of their market by a private developer.

At least fifteen people are feared dead in fresh attack among rival villages or groups in Baragoi, Samburu County. Eight people were reportedly killed during a raid at Lomirok early Sunday morning (03/05). Unconfirmed reports indicate that another six, among them women and children, were killed at Sarma along the Samburu-Marsabit border that evening.

Turkana raiders attack a Pokot village close to Nadome along the Turkana-East Pokot district border, killing 18 residents. Following the attack a Pokot militia assembled, chasing the attackers to nearby Kogh-Tuw village and killing 36.
Residents protest against Baringo county insecurity in Marigat.

Turkana raiders attack a Pokot village close to Nadome along the Turkana-East Pokot district border, killing 18 residents. Following the attack a Pokot militia assembled, chasing the attackers to nearby Kogh-Tuw village and killing 36.
A resident is shot and killed when a group resisted a forced eviction. Following the shooting tenants lit fires and sang anti-oppression themed songs.
Tenants continue protests for a second day following a forced eviction and resident shooting. No violence reported.
Nurses at Meru teaching hospital protest over non-payment of salaries.
Women in Makueni county held a peaceful demonstration to oppose a bill on the implementation of the two-thirds gender rule. The protest took place in Wote town.
Two suspected Al-Shabab gunmen and a police officer killed in shoot out at Dadaab Hamey Patrol Base in Garissa.
Residents protest the removal of a roadblock by police believing the action to be "suspect."
Police clash with students protesting the death of colleague, seven injuries reported.
Ethiopian soldiers armed with AK-47 rifles cross into Kenya aboard 10 vehicles and reportedly take over a police station in North Horr.

Following the disappearance of three people residents of Kinna protest, accusing the Kenya Wildlife Service of kidnapping. The residents marched to the Meru National Park and allegedly set a fire at the park. One is killed and eleven injured after the police engaged the protesters.
Al Shabaab "catches two military posts (in Sangailu and Hulugho) by surprise," no violence reported.
Al Shabaab "catches two military posts (in Sangailu and Hulugho) by surprise," no violence reported.
Residents of Muoroto Kamiti village in Kiambu Town constituency protest against the grabbing of 2,400 acres by a private developer.
Residents of Kiangage in Murang'a on the night of 19/05 set ablaze a matatu driver that killed a boda boda rider in a recent accident.
Al Shabaab gunmen attack Yumbis and Wel Marer villages in Fafi, each about 80 Km north east of Garissa. Security forces pushed back the attackers, no reported causalities.
Al Shabaab gunmen attack Yumbis and Wel Marer villages in Fafi, each about 80 Km north east of Garissa. Security forces pushed back the attackers, no reported causalities.
Al Shabaab attacks a police post Yumbis on the night of 25/05, killing 20. Al Shabaab had also attacked the area the previous week.

Transport on Moi South Lake road in Naivasha was paralysed for more than three hours as residents protested the closure of a public corridor leading to Lake Naivasha. The more than 400 residents blocked the road using boulders and light fires to protest the closure demanded justice. Police entered the area and engaged the demonstrators in running battles. Spats of violence continued into the second day. "Scores" injured.

Residents protested for a second day against the closure of a public corridor leading to Lake Naivasha. The more than 400 residents blocked the road using boulders and light fires to protest the closure demanded justice. Police entered the area and engaged the demonstrators in running battles. Spats of violence continued into the second day. "Scores" injured.
Unidentified gunmen shoot and kill an off-duty police officer of the anti-radicalisation squad at close range in Kibokoni, outside of Mombasa.
Al Shabaab creates a heavy presence in Lafey village effectively "taking over" the village. The presence of al Shabaab caused several villagers to flee for safety.

Two non-local residents of Marsabit are killed in mysterious circumstances by unidentified assailants. Non-locals claim that they are being targeted in assassinations by police. The police deny the allegations.
At least three people were killed and several others injured on the morning of 06/06 in inter-community clashes at Lowangila in Isiolo County. The clash may be related to rights to cattle or land.

Suspected al Shabaab opened fire at a residential area of Wajir on 06/06, killing three persons. Officials and residents said the attackers were believed to have been seeking to kill a local administrator who lives close to the scene of the attack and is known to be on an al Shabaab "wanted" list for speaking out against the sect's activities in the region.

At least 10 pastoralists from Isiolo have been killed in clashes with Laikipia residents after the herders invade the area with hundreds of animals. The herders also shot two security personnel after they were ordered to vacate the land during the clashes.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Al Shabaab reportedly erects a series of road blocks between Garba Tula and Modogashe townships [north-eastern Kenya] for purposes of extorting money from motorists. Despite these assertions, the local government denies these claims. Exact date unknown.

Hundreds of residents of Dadaab took to the streets on 06/08 to protest over the alleged sacking of 13 local employees by the World Food Programme (WFP). Waving placards, demonstrators marched through the town before heading to the main UNHCR headquarters offices gate where they camped for several hours.
Youth employed to repair roads at Jomvu in Mikindani, Mombasa county held a protest march on 08/06 over delayed pay.
Residents of Baraka Estate protest over poor roads in their area.
Marsabit non-local residents protest over insecurity following a recent spate of killings in which they were targeted.

Al Shabaab attacks several locations of Lamu Island and were able to briefly overtake the area known as "Mangai," an area they found with little resistance. Other places attacked included a school and a military camp. Military forces eventually repelled the attackers. "Several" casualties reported, eleven of which were recorded as al Shabaab. Later reports suggest a British-born member of al Shabaab (known as Thomas Evans or Abdul Akim) may have been a leader in the attack and is among the dead. Another suspect of the attack was apprehended on 20/06.
Residents of Salgaa Township, Nakuru blocked Nakuru-Eldoret highway accusing the Governor of denying them development. Several vehicles were reportedly burnt during the protest.

Five pastoralists are killed by unidentified gunmen at Wari walo village some 10 kilometres from Kenya border. Those killed were three children (two boys and a girl), their father and a close relative. The five had recently left Elmole in pursuit of pasture and water for their animals.

Police in Siaya were forced to shoot in the air several times when a group of "rowdy" youths disrupted a meeting chaired by Governor Cornel Rasanga in Yala. Chanting anti-Rasanga slogans, the group claimed the governor had no place in Yala, which is in Gem constituency. No causalities reported.

20 people are killed in Durogo [phonetic] in Mandera County in what has been described as revenge attacks by Garre [clan] fighters following the killings of their clansmen. Perpetrators are not known. Date unclear - source dated 17/06.
Hospital staff protest staff leadership in the suburban Nairobi area of Moi on 19/06.
Two university students are lynched by a vigilante group over suspected theft "at the weekend."
Suspected al Shabaab shot and killed a chief of Erib location in Wajir on 20/06.
Three KDF members are injured in an al Shabaab IED attack Milimani on 21/06.

Youth demonstrators protesting against National Youth Service slum projects as well as against Devolution Cabinet Secretary Ann Waiguru. The youth started demonstrating at 7pm at Kibera's Olympic stage, where they lit bonfires and barricaded the road. The group believed the NYS and Waiguru are corrupt. The protests may have continued the following day, as there was a reported heavy police presence.
Residents from Obunga slums in Kisumu on 22/06 held demonstrations in support of a politician they believed is being unfairly criticised.

Youths attached to the National Youth Service slum-upgrading project in Kisumu on 23/06 staged a demo in Nairobi centre to protest against calls by Cord leaders that the project be investigated on financial corruption grounds.
Staff of a garment company in Athi River protest after the suspension of their chief shop steward.
One person was killed and two others injured in an attack by suspected Al-Shabaab gunmen in Mandera Town on the night of 26/06. All of the victims are "non-locals," origin not known.
Parents of Muslim students in Kwale protest after it is alleged their children were forced to attend church services while attending school.

Youths from Chuka Igambang'ombe Constituency demonstrated in Chuka Town during recruitment by the National Youth Service, criticizing the criteria used to fill the 1,440 vacancies. The protest lasted the majority of the afternoon.

Residents of Isiolo town in Eastern Province held a demo on 30/06 over the disappearance and abduction of several men. Hundreds of women held a peaceful rally demanding answers from the government. Many of the protesters accused the Kenya Wildlife Services for the disappearance of the men.
Hundreds of boda boda operators hold a demonstration outside City Hall in Nairobi accusing city askaris of harassment.
Nine are killed and six others injured on 01/07 following an attack by members of the Marhani clan of Somalia on Arabia.
A senior, off-duty National Intelligence Service officer is shot and killed on 03/07 by two unidentified assailants in Mombasa.
A suspected murderer is lynched in Ganze.
A group protests against homosexuality in Nairobi.

Al Shabaab attacks Mandera town, throwing grenades into homes while people slept on 07/07. 14 dead. Al Shabaab later officially claimed responsibility, declaring they were specifically targeting Christians.

Armed men attacked a passenger bus on 07/07 at Mpekatoni border town. There were no immediate reports of any casualties. Police later report the attack was not carried out by al Shabaab, but rather an unidentified group of locals.
Al Shabaab attacks a police convoy, including a civilian bus travelling in Mkunumbi, no reported causalities.
Students from Nguviu Boys High School in Embu North shattered window panes of their buildings for allegedly being refused to eat directly from sufurias.
One person dies in a clash between the Kabasiran and Kapkeny clans in Elgeyo Marakwet.
Al Shabaab targets police with an IED in Lamu on 13/07. Three deaths reported.
Another person dies in a clan war over land on 12/07.
Students in Likoni violently protest over delayed syllabus completion ahead of an exam.
Groups students of Moi University clash violently over forthcoming student elections, destroying property. Police engaged the rioters and made several arrests.
Students of Gatamaiyu Boys High School riot, destroy school property. Authorities were not clear as to the reason of the protest.
Reports indicate that Al Shabaab overtook Milimani village in Lamu on the night of 18/07. No violence was reported.

More than 600 workers of the China Road and Bridges Company demonstrated on 20/07 against denial of a pay rise to 500 workers. The protest blocked the Nairobi - Mombasa highway at Athi River Steel Plant for an hour. Protesting workers were dispersed by police.
Students from Njoro Boys High School in Nakuru riot over a water supply problem.
Students of Technical University of Kenya embark of a violent protest over "a stalemate surrounding the validity of the courses." Police dispersed the protesters following some property damage.
Residents of Athi River protest the police release of a man accused of rape.
Students of St Paul's Kiwanjani Secondary School protest violently after several students were sent home over disciplinary action. A teacher was reportedly assaulted.
KDF soldiers killed three al Shabaab when they repulsed an attack at Basuba, Lamu county, on Wednesday (29/07) morning. Three members of the military forces were injured.
A tussle over the leadership of a church in Vihiga. A house and automobile were destroyed the subsequent unrest.
A members of the National Intelligence Service is killed when a vigilante mob mistook him for a criminal in the Bu_ruburu area.

Nine are dead and six are injured in a fight between pastoralists and farmers in Tana River. Additionally, several houses were destroyed. The clashes between Wardei pastoralists and Mijikenda farmers occurred in Wachu Oda in Garsen. A reported 1,500 people displaced as a result of the clashes.
An al Shabaab-planted explosive attached to a military vehicle causes seven soldier deaths.
Turkana attackers kill five in a suspected cattle rustling operation. The attack caused tension in the area.
Al Shabaab forces briefly take over Basuba in Lamu Country. Once there, al Shabaab leaders addressed the town and met with elders before retreating.
Two groups of churchgoers clash over the rights to a building.

A young boy is killed during clashes over land between Kapkeny and Kabasirian clans in Kerio Valley. Later reported suggest the battle caused the destructions of many homes and displaced hundreds. Fighting also spilled over into Shaban and Kachesoom areas.
Female APs took to the streets of Kakamega town on 17/08, in a protest against elections from which their representative was allegedly barred.
Teachers in Garissa protested over deteriorating education standards in Northeastern.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Police forces foil a planned terror attack from al Shabaab. Two arrested made, weapons recovered.
Mandera residents held a demonstration to press the government into deploying teachers to the region.
A suspected cattle thief is lynched by a mob at Archers' Post location.
Farmers in North Rift on 24/08 held a peaceful demonstration on the Iten-Eldoret road, Eldoret to protest over the planned introduction of genetically modified crops.
Boda boda motorcyclists in Limuru town protested after one of them was ordered to pay a bond after the individual is accused of a crime. The protesters lit fires and were later dispersed by police.
Election violence among the ODM caused two deaths, one in Awendo and the other in Rongo.
Election violence among the ODM caused two deaths, one in Awendo and the other in Rongo.
Residents of Murang'a county blocked MCAs from entering the assembly in Muranga to table an impeachment motion against a preferred politician.
A group of youths carrying "Maendeleo Chap Chap" banners attack people at a WDM rally in Kasikeu. Date unknown - source dated 03/09.

Nyeri residents protest, forcibly entering the officer of the governor and lighting fires in solidarity with striking nurses. The protesters called on the governor to help end the weeks long strike. Police engaged in "running battles" with the protesters.

One person injured after being hit by a bullet when garment workers protested poor working conditions at the firm in Mombasa. The workers lit tyres on the road blocking flow of traffic for over two hours before order was restored by police who fired into the air.
Striking teachers protest over pay in Nairobi. The teachers had been striking for two weeks.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Kenyan police arrested three men found with a suspected homemade bomb as they entered a Nairobi shopping mall. The affiliations of those arrested are not known, though investigators are considering links to al Shabaab.
Teachers in Eldoret protest over pay, cause schools to close.
Striking teachers renew a protest over pay at Uhuru Park.
Striking Bondo subcounty teachers protest at the TSC office after a threat to dismiss several of their colleagues.
Teachers protest for pay increase in Muranga.
Residents of Bula Rahma village in the outskirts of Garissa town protest a water shortage in their area.
National Youth Service employees protest the termination of colleagues in Nairobi.
Residents lynch a suspected motorcycle thief in the Manyatta section of the city.
A group protests against genetic food mortification in Nairobi.
A group protests in Tetu against the actions of an ODM politician who had derided one they support.

Following the killing of a businessman by suspected gangsters, residents of Eldoret violently protest the violence, blocking the Eldoret-Kapsabet highway paralysing transport for hours. Police fired tear gas and rubber bullets against them, who then attempted to storm Langas Police Station in turn.
Health workers strike and protest in Kisumu  over non-payment of saleries.
Students violently protest over delayed loans. Police use tear gas to disperse the group, make ten arrests.
ODM elections in Kisumu county were aborted after violence broke out: a group of rowdy youths attacked a former education minister for unknown reason. "Scores" injured.

Maseno University's administration block was burnt on the night on 07/10 by student arsonists and rioters angry they were barred from campus elections after they failed to meet the election requirements. No injuries reported.
A vigilante group attacked and killed a suspected criminal in Nairobi.

The Jaramogi Oginga Odinga University of Science and Technology in Bondo has been closed indefinitely after students rioted following controversial elections. The students blocked the Kisumu-Usenge road engaging police in running battles for the better part of 09/10 and 10/10.
Residents of Kiang'ombe village in Thika held demonstrations to protest against land grabbing by a private developer.

The Jaramogi Oginga Odinga University of Science and Technology in Bondo has been closed indefinitely after students rioted following controversial elections. The students blocked the Kisumu-Usenge road engaging police in running battles for the better part of 09/10 and 10/10.
Residents of Kabete, Nairobi area hold a protest demonstration over poor roads. Police dispersed the group.
A teacher is kidnapped by suspected al Shabaab in Hagadera refugee camp. The teacher was later rescued by Kenyan forces across the border into Somalia.

On 12/10 at 10:30, an INGO vehicle travelling without escort was stopped by a group of five armed men who had fired shots in their direction. The men kidnapped a non-local female Kenyan from the vehicle and fled after coming under fire by police.

Maseno University students run riot in protest of a fellow student who had fallen and died. Running battles reported with police, teargas and other implements used. Several injuries, one death reported.
Boda Boda operators block a road in protest of a colleague who had died as a result of suspected police neglect.

The Mombasa Technical University has been closed indefinitely after students went on the rampage to protest increased fees and other management issues they say are hampering learning at the institution.
Turkana militia attack a Pokot camp in Narengmor, killing three in revenge of cattle theft.

Pwani University students who attempted to disrupt Mashujaa Day celebrations at Karisa Maitha Grounds were driven back by police. They were demonstrating against the closure of the university due to a water shortage.

column22: Agence France Presse; Missoulian; Times Live
column23: Clash between Lesotho Defence Forces and two soldiers that were former bodyguards for Lesotho's Prime Minister Tom Thabane.  The former bodyguards refused to stop at a security checkpoint and started shooting at Lesotho Defence Force soliders controlling access to the SADC offices near the presidential palace.  LDF soldiers returned fire, the two soldiers/fomer bodyguards were wounded and one private security guard was shot and killed.  The former bodyguards are thought to be responsible for tipping off Thabane of the failed coup in August 2014, which allowed Thabane to flee his residence before it was attacked by suspected army soldiers.
A local radio presenter was physically attacked by a chairperson of All Basotho Convention (ABC) Youth League at an ABC political party rally at Setsoto Stadium in Maseru.

Protesters gathered in the street after a court postponed judgment in a case involving All Basotho Convention leader Thabane  and the appointment of Kanalelo Mosito as president of the Court of Appeal.

column22: UN News Service; African News Agency
column23: Maaparankoe Mahao, former commander of the Defence Force Lesotho, was assassinated by soldiers at his home on the outskirts of Maseru, allegedly part of a military campaign to rid the country of those loyal to Prime Minister Thabane.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Body of a solider found in a dam. He had been recently arrested for suspected coup plotting.
Vigilante militia kill the wife of a man on trial for murder and sexual assault.

Over the weekend of Dec. 27-28, hundreds of Muslim community members protested against the clearing of Zwedru Central Cemetary for new use as a burial site for Ebola victims. County authorities immediately ordered the relocation of the site to nearer the Ebola Treatment Center.

Towards the end of December 2014, rioters attacked and looted the homes of managers of the No Way Camp, Marloi Township, in Grand Bassa County, after paying to obtain jobs at the gold mine but being denied work and refund of fees paid.  Security guards at the mining site opened fire on the rioters and allegedly killed an unspecified number of people.  A dozen men fled and jumped into a 40-foot gold pit and died when a dirt wall fell on top of them.  Government security has been deployed to the camp and the camp has been closed indefinitely.  At least 20 dead.
Marketeers of the Public Works market on Bushrod Island allegedly attacked court officers to resist eviction.
A group of school-aged children protested on the grounds of the capitol building in Monrovia, demanding free education.

Police allegedly beat up civilians and a pregnant woman during eviction raids in the Public Works market on Bushrod Island. Police officers were sent to carry out evictions after court officers were allegedly attacked by marketers during an initial eviction exercise.

Employees at the Liberia Agricultural Company (LAC) have staged a non-violent protest on the premises of the company, demanding that management addresses the health condition of seventeen of their colleagues who reportedly sustained inuries as a result of explosion.

Several aggrieved workers of the Liberia Maritime Authority (LiMA) Beach and Waterway Project on Tuesday, March 3 protested at the Capitol Building in Monrovia in demand payment of eight months' salary arrears

Scores of individuals under the banner of the Paynesville Business Association Incorporated (PABA) are accusing the City Corporation of arbitrarily hiking taxes in the municipality. The Association protested at the main entrance to the Capitol Building yesterday holding placards.

Relative calm has returned to Zorzor, Lofa County following the intervention of the Liberia National Police after angry youths set ablaze two houses and several cell phones booths in the Zorzor Lutheran Church community

Several students of Catholic schools on March 6 demonstrated in front of the Catholic Education Secretariat in Monrovia, demanding authority of the institution to pay five-month arrears owed their teachers.

Protesting students, under the banner "Grand Bassa University Student Union" or GBUSU Tuesday converged on the grounds of the Capitol Building and barricaded lawmakers from the county in demand of scholarship funds to enable them return to school.

The start of the national Constitutional Review Conference in Gbarnga was Monday marred by a series of protests. Placard-wielding youths stormed the Gbarnga administration building demanding representations at the event while Christians and Muslims clashed.

The ongoing constitutional review conference in Gbarnga, Bong County was marred by protest action Tuesday when delegates complained of the omission of several proposals earmarked for deliberation. Representatives of youth and student groups who also joined the protest, chanted 'revolutionary slogans' and sang songs which delayed the conference for several hours. The protesters accused the Constitution Review Committee (CRC) of advancing nine views instead of the 25 recurring views expressed by the people of Liberia during its nationwide consultations and meetings

Muslim Community of Bong County stormed the grounds of the Gbarnga Administrative building Wednesday morning in protest, demanding removal of count 24 of views being validated at the ongoing National Constitutional Conference. Count 24 is being proffered by a Christian group, which wants Liberia to be legislated as a Christian State

A 30-year-old physically challenged man has died, days after allegedly being flogged by a team of Action Agents of Liberia’s Drugs Enforcement Agency or DEA led by a commander in Dartorken town, Tiempo District, River Gee County. The jury team that went to investigate was unable to interview people on the crime scene because the area was hostile, and protests were ongoing

A "corroner jury" team that went to investigate the death of a disabled man who was beaten by DEA officials was unable to interview people on the crime scene because the area was hostile, and protests were ongoing.

Several aggrieved citizens of Giah Town, Disco Hill, Margibi County on Tuesday, April 7 blocked the only road leading to a place where Ebola bodies are buried. The citizens say the Government of Liberia owes them a balance of US$25,000 for the 25 acres of land, which they provided to the government.

Students of Cestos High School in Rivercess County yesterday morning stormed the county administration building to express their anger and frustration, chanting, "No renovation, no school, no By-Election." According to the reports, the students broke doors, windows, chairs and other furniture in the administrative building housing the Superintendent's compound. Just before the day ended, the police gained control of the crowd and managed to arrest a student who is believed to be the leader of the demonstration.

Workers of almost all of Liberia's Ebola Treatment Units (ETUs) have staged a major protest in Monrovia, demanding benefits owed them by the Government of Liberia. The workers, predominantly healthcare practitioners, gathered at the seat of the Liberian legislature early Thursday morning to inform lawmakers about their over four month's unpaid benefits.

A motorcyclist was killed by a soldier of the Armed Forces of Liberia following a scuffle on Tuesday in Thinker Village Community in Paynesville. Meanwhile, police have arrested the soldier and are investigating the event.

Enraged motorcyclists resorted to violence in Redlight, Paynesville yesterday in retaliation for the alleged killing of their fellow rider by a police officer. The rioting resulted in the burning down of a police substation. Several police officers reportedly sustained serious injuries and were taken to a nearby health facility.

A Liberian police officer allegedly beat a motorcyclist to death following a heated dispute between the police officer (not named) and a rider only identified as Alfred. Government claims the motorist fell from his bike when he was fleeing from Police after he allegedly assaulted one of them at the GSA Road intersection.

Seven hundred Liberian Ebola workers took to the streets of the capital Monrovia for a second day on Saturday to demand promised hazard pay. The workers hired by MSF on Saturday blocked the entrance to Liberia's biggest Ebola facility.

A major check point in Kolahun District, Lofa County has been completely vandalized by some motorcyclists in defense of one of their colleagues who was said to have been flogged allegedly by an officer of the Liberia National Police (LNP) in Lofa County.
Workers of China Union in Bong Mines, Bong County went on a go-slow protest from 1st to 6th May demanding better conditions at work.
Mine workers of the G-5 group of Companies instituted a two-day peaceful strike action from Monday on the compound of the company in Kinjor, Grand Cape Mount County over payment of benefits

A group of young people, mainly women and carrying placards, blocked the main entrance of the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning in Monrovia Monday during the early morning hours and prevented people from entering and leaving the building, in demand for eight months salary arrears. Police were deployed on the scene to prevent violence which nearly ensued.

Residents of Butaw staged a protest demanding to meet a visiting senior official of the Golden Veroleum Company, which resulted to the throwing of stones and destruction of some of GVL properties. 20 people involved in the rioting were arrested by the police.

column6: Non-violent activity by a conflict actor
column23: Armed men have crossed into Liberia from Ivory Coast and occupied an area of forest, spreading alarm in the remote border region, a lawmaker said on Wednesday.

Members of the ex-ruling National Patriotic Party staged a protest on the former ruling party headquarters for about three days, in an attempt to prevent the national chairman and his team of leaders from entering the premises. The protesters are demanding that he steps down.
Several local business owners in Kakata, Margibi County under the banner "Margibi Muslim Council" mostly Fulani's closed their stores and shops over the weekend in protest to Christianizing Liberia.

Members of the ex-ruling National Patriotic Party staged a protest on the former ruling party headquarters for about three days, in an attempt to prevent the national chairman and his team of leaders from entering the premises. The protesters are demanding that he steps down.

Members of the ex-ruling National Patriotic Party staged a protest on the former ruling party headquarters for about three days, in an attempt to prevent the national chairman and his team of leaders from entering the premises. The protesters are demanding that he steps down.

More than 100 Ebola center workers stormed the Ministry of Health in eastern Monrovia on Wednesday demanding hazard pay that they said they haven't received since the country was declared Ebola-free May 9 by the World Health Organization

A multitude of protesting students besieged the Presidential Convoy outside the Monrovia City Hall in Monrovia, while departing from a function Thursday. They persistently disallowed her convoy to drive through from the Monrovia City Hall resulting to her resolve to speak with them amid unending slogans. Officers of the elite Executive Protective Service peacefully pulled back the students to create an enabling environment for the President- also heavily flanked by EPS officers, riot police and UN peacekeepers as she approached her temporary office at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs

Riots broke out in River Gee where some people burnt a police station, a Liberian flag and a privately-owned transport truck, in reaction to the death of a motorcyclist, who died in an accident that occurred near Kilepo Jowroken, Chedepo District in River Gee.

Several healthcare workers who worked at the Ebola treatment units (ETU) in and around Monrovia on Monday staged another round of strikes at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in demand of hazard pay they claim the Government of Liberia owes them.

A civic group under the banner, "Water, Sanitation and Hygiene Network on Friday staged a sit in action at the offices of the Liberia Water and Sewer Corporation (LWSC) in Monrovia, demanding concrete action to improve service, governance and financing for water, sanitation and hygiene
Press Union of Liberia notified the Liberia National Police regarding the alleged brutalization of the journalists while performing their reportorial duties in Kakata, Margibi County

Students of the Bong County Technical College and some citizens on Tuesday staged a peaceful demonstration to draw the attention of the county leadership to the perpetual delay in the completion of the college's facilities.

Angry youths gathered on Carey Street on 16 September calling for the prosecution of a senior state security officer and his subordinates after they reportedly physically brutalized an unarmed civilianon 13 September. The angry crowd chased and chanted anti violence slogan. Darlington George was dismissed of his functions and later arrested
Hundreds of Liberians stormed the courtyard of the Capitol Building in a peaceful protest to demand changes to the "2015 Liberia Electricity Act" last week passed by the Liberian Senate.

The Muslim community dominated by the Mandingo ethnic groups has disrupted a team of surveyors backed by the 8th Judiciary Circuit Court Sheriff over surveying of a land. The Surveyors went to the Police Station for rescue on ground that angry Muslim youths obstructed the court order to survey the disputed land.

violent demonstration carried out on 28 September by some individuals who claimed that they were hired and worked at various Ebola treatment units (ETUs) but have not been paid by the Liberian Government.

column11: UNMIL: United Nations Mission in Liberia
column22: Liberia News Agency; The New Dawn; Liberian Observer
column23: Violent demonstration led to burning and looting of properties and thousands of dollars after the arrest of the murderes of a man for ritualistic purposes. Several security offices, including the Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA) sub-office in Ganta, were looted during the violence. The arrival of police and UNMIL forces did not deter the rioters. A 3-day curfew was imposed on the county. 47 people were arraigned in connection with the riots
A man accused of ritually beheading a motorcyclist is killed by a mob during riots in Ganta.

Eight traditional "Bushmasters" besieged Jungle Jean Village in Fuamah District, Bong County in protest against the desecration of the Poro and Sande societies by a pastor in his sermon. The incident led to the closure of all businesses in the area and forced people to stay indoors with no one allowed to enter the town. No reports of violence.

Eight traditional "Bushmasters" besieged Jungle Jean Village in Fuamah District, Bong County in protest against the desecration of the Poro and Sande societies by a pastor in his sermon. The incident led to the closure of all businesses in the area and forced people to stay indoors with no one allowed to enter the town. No reports of violence.
Police flog and abuse some of individuals accused of taking part in rioting and vigilante violence in Ganta.

Former Ebola Treatment Unit workers protested against government's inaction regarding hazard payment when President Sirleaf was to deliver a special Hand Washing Day message at the William V. S. Tubman High School in Sinkor. riot police officers from the Police Support Unit or PSU of the Liberia National Police were immediately called to move the rioters across the street but the protesters remain adamant. Situation remained peaceful
Students from the Student Unification Party (SUP)  disrupted classes on Fendell campus to protest against Student Alvin Wesseh's expulsion

Students at the Robertsport High School in Grand Cape Mount County staged a violent protest against their parents' decision to underwrite the salaries of six teachers assigned to the school. Some buildings were looted and important documents taken by the demonstrators. Members of the joint security were called in to calm the situation.

About 45,000 residents, particularly squatters from the Industrial Park in Gardnersville have staged street protests in front of the UNMIL office in Sinkor against a planned demolition on 26 October by the Ministry of Public Works.

A multitude of protesters from the Worwee Community (Montserrado County District #8) gathered near the Ministry of Foreign Affairs after resisting an eviction order on 17 October and defying a Supreme Court ruling that grants 48 acres of land to a former lawmaker, Jesse C. Payne.

column22: The New Republic Liberia; The New Dawn; FrontPageAfrica
column23: Tens of thousands of students of the University of Liberia stormed its two campuses in demand of the reinstatement of one of their colleagues, Student Alvin Wesseh who has been expelled. They first staged a sit-in at the main street leading to the Fendell Campus until riot officers from the  PSU were deployed in battle ready positions to ease tensions.

column22: The New Republic Liberia; The New Dawn; FrontPageAfrica
column23: Tens of thousands of students of the University of Liberia stormed its two campuses in demand of the reinstatement of one of their colleagues, Student Alvin Wesseh who has been expelled. After roadblocking the Fendell Campus, they marched to the Monrovia campus. Riot officers from the PSU were deployed in battle ready positions, and were later reinforced. Angry students began throwing stones into the university compound and also on the main street. students accused the Police of throwing stones from within the university fence
Placards carrying Liberia Marketing Association (LMA) members marched on the Capitol Building to protest the alleged seizure of a land
In March, the bodies of seven Christian Egyptians were found in the eastern city of Benghazi, killed by gunshots to the head while handcuffed.

column11: Government of Libya (2014-) General National Congress
column15: Tajura' wa an Nawahi al Arba
column23: A former member of the General National Congress (GNC) was abducted in the Janzur area of Tripoli on 20 July 2014 alongside another GNC colleague by the Zintan-affiliated Barq al-Nasser Brigade. He was reportedly subjected to torture and other ill-treatment, including by being shot in the leg and having hot water poured on his body after being taken to Ajmi prison in Zintan.

On 5 August 2014, the son of a retired judge who was abducted was executed in Benghazi a few days after his enforced disappearance in a neighbourhood of Benghazi controlled by Zintan militias belonging to Haftar's armed forces.

column7: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Special Forces
column23: On 17 October 2014, members of the Al Saiqa 21st battalion attacked a house with RPGs. Four brothers, suspected of being heavily involved in the 17 February Revolution, were then taken to the battalion HQ in Benghazi where one of them was shot in the head and the others detained and severely tortured for several days.

column7: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Special Forces
column23: Two brothers suspected of being involved in the 17 February Revolution were taken by members of both the 21st battalion and another militia to a school in Bersis, a village 50km north of Benghazi. The following day, they were both taken to the village of Al Rajma, 30km east of Benghazi, where they were held together for three days before being separated. There, they were tortured with electric shocks and severely beaten on all parts of their bodies for being from the region of Misrata, a city located 200km east of Tripoli known for its support of the Government of Tripoli and not of the internationally-recognised Government of Tobruk, whose armed forces are headed by General Haftar. One was released but the other's body was found on 6 November 2014, dumped in the streets of Al Marj, a town 100km northeast of Benghazi. According to his forensic medical report, his death was due to a gunshot in the head.

column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Special Forces
column23: A prosecutor was abducted on 21 October 2014 by the Zawiya Martyrs Brigade while on his way home from an outing. He was abducted in the Fuwaihat area of Benghazi, in front of the al-Arab Medical University. It is believed he continues to be detained at the Zawiya Martyrs Brigade base in Tabalino and has suffered an injury to his hand from ill-treatment in detention.
A detainee was beaten at Bersis Prison in November 2014 with a plastic pipe to his head.
In November 2014 a detainee at Garnada Prison was tortured for four days at their headquarters in Tobruk for allegedly "inciting public opinion" against Libya's House of Representatives.

column15: Tajura' wa an Nawahi al Arba
column23: A co-pilot for United, a government-owned aviation company affiliated with the interim government, the House of Representatives (HoR), was abducted by unknown assailants on 27 November 2014. He was forcibly taken from his own car as he was parking it outside of his house in al-Hani area of Tripoli. His fate and exact whereabouts have remained unknown. However, reports suggest that he is being held in a detention facility in Abu Salim area under the authority of Salah Burki, a field commander with the Libya Dawn coalition.
21 Tawargha men were abducted in early December 2014 while fleeing violence in Benghazi. Their whereabouts remains unknown.
A 50-year old man was arrested and taken to Tocra facility after his son was accused of belonging to Ansar al-Sharia. He was beaten with plastic pipe by army officials.
Ten Egyptians were reported to have gone missing on 25 December 2014 near Beni Walid. According to the report they were kidnapped by men in police uniforms.
A woman was arrested on 27 December 2014 and taken to al-Fuweihat facility where she was severely beaten and tortured by members of the Libyan Army's special forces unit Brigade 21.

column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column23: Several areas, including the districts of Al-Laythi and Al-Huwari reported heavy fighting.

column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column23: Several areas, including the districts of Al-Laythi and Al-Huwari reported heavy fighting.

column22: Associated Press International; Libya Herald; Agence France Presse
column23: 17 soldiers and 1 civilian were killed at a checkpoint in Jufra by Islamist militants.
Demonstrations were staged in several Libyan towns on [2 January] to denounce aerial bombardments carried out by Khalifah Haftar's forces. Towns included Tripoli, Misratah, Gharyan, Sabha and Zlitin.
Demonstrations were staged in several Libyan towns on [2 January] to denounce aerial bombardments carried out by Khalifah Haftar's forces. Towns included Tripoli, Misratah, Gharyan, Sabha and Zlitin.
